1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response:
First, convert each clue into explicit restrictions:

1. Let the digits be arranged in 4 two-digit “sets’’: A₁A₂ – B₁B₂ – C₁C₂ – D₁D₂  
   Clue 1: C₁ + B₂ < 8.

2. The only digits that never appear are 5 and 7.  
   ⇒ Every digit 1,2,3,4,6,8,9 must appear at least once somewhere.

3. A₁ + A₂ ≠ 10.

4. 4 × (B₁B₂) = (D₂D₁)   (i.e. four times the 2nd set equals the 4th set reversed).

5. No two-digit set exceeds 90.

6. A₁·A₂ is between 20 and 30 exclusive of the bounds.

7. One entire set is 66.

8. There is exactly one 8 in the whole combination, and it is in the last set.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step-by-step deduction

• From (6): the only digit pairs (ignoring order) whose product is 21–29 are
  (4,6) giving 24 and (3,9) giving 27.
  – Pair (4,6) is disallowed by (3) because 4+6 = 10.
  – Therefore the first set’s digits must be 3 and 9, and by (5) the number
    cannot be 93 (>90).  
    ⇒ First set = 39.

• Clue 7 says one set is 66.  
  It cannot be the 4th set (because that would contain no 8), nor the 2nd set
  (because of clue 4; 4·66 is three-digit).  
  ⇒ Third set = 66.

• Using clue 1: C₁ = 6 (from 66).  So 6 + B₂ < 8 ⇒ B₂ must be 1.
  ⇒ The second set is ?1.

• By (5) and the multiplication in clue 4, the 2nd set must be ≤24 (since
  25×4 already gives 100).  With B₂ = 1 only two choices exist: 11 or 21.

   – If 2nd set = 11, then 4×11 = 44, hence the 4th set reversed is 44 and
     the 4th set itself is 44.  But the 4th set must contain the only 8.
     ⇒ 11 impossible.

   – Therefore 2nd set = 21.  
     Clue 4 then gives 4×21 = 84, so the reversed 4th set is 84 and the 4th
     set itself is 48, which indeed contains exactly one 8.

• Collect all digits now present:
  39 – 21 – 66 – 48  uses 1,2,3,4,6,8,9 exactly once each; 5 and 7 are absent.
  Every clue is satisfied, and no set exceeds 90.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Strategy (decided before the hats are put on)  
1. Every prisoner will look at the OTHER prisoners and count how many white hats he sees.  
2. If that number is even he will say “black.”  
3. If that number is odd he will say “white.”

Why the strategy works  
Let T be the total number of white hats actually on all heads.

Case 1 – T is even.  
• A prisoner wearing a black hat sees T white hats (still even) → he says “black” → correct.  
• A prisoner wearing a white hat sees T–1 white hats (odd) → he says “white” → correct.  
Hence everyone is correct.

Case 2 – T is odd.  
• A prisoner wearing a black hat sees T white hats (odd) → he says “white” → wrong.  
• A prisoner wearing a white hat sees T–1 white hats (even) → he says “black” → wrong.  
Hence everyone is wrong.

So, no matter how the warden distributes the hats, the prisoners’ answers are either all right (if the total number of white hats is even) or all wrong (if it is odd). Therefore the whole group is guaranteed to go free.

Final answer: Each prisoner counts the number of white hats he sees; if the count is even he guesses “black,” if it is odd he guesses “white.” This forces everyone to be simultaneously correct when the total number of white hats is even, and simultaneously mistaken when it is odd, so they always meet the warden’s requirement and escape.

Question:
Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Final answer: Derek – The Rusting Bucket,  
Berrick – The Devine Lightning,  
Merick – The Silver Dream,  
Eric – The Golden Pleasure

Question:
Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Think of the situation as a (truncated) Josephus problem with  
n = 30 people and a counting step k = 9.  
Number the places in the circle 1, 2, …, 30 clockwise, letting place 1 be the spot from which the driver begins to count.

If every time the driver reaches the 9-th person that person is put out of the circle, the first fifteen numbers that disappear are, in order

 9, 18, 27, 6, 16, 26, 7, 19, 30, 12, 24, 8, 22, 5, 23.

(All further eliminations would be made from the remaining fifteen people, but the driver stops after these fifteen have gone.)

Therefore, to be sure that only supporters of the other team have to get off, make them stand on exactly those fifteen places, and let all your own supporters (yourself included) occupy the remaining fifteen places.

One convenient way to write the circle (Y = your side, O = opponent) is

1 Y 2 Y 3 Y 4 Y 5 O 6 O 7 O 8 O 9 O 10 Y  
11 Y 12 O 13 Y 14 Y 15 Y 16 O 17 Y 18 O 19 O 20 Y  
21 Y 22 O 23 O 24 O 25 Y 26 O 27 O 28 Y 29 Y 30 O

When the driver now counts “1 … 9” repeatedly, the people who step out are exactly the O-positions listed above (9, 18, 27, 6, 16, 26, 7, 19, 30, 12, 24, 8, 22, 5, 23), leaving every one of your fifteen supporters still on the bus.

Final answer: Place the rival supporters at positions 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 19, 22, 23, 24, 26, 27, 30 around the circle (starting-point counted as position 1) and let all fifteen fans of your own team occupy the other fifteen positions; then none of your fans will be made to leave.

Question:
It appears that you have angered the spirit of Halloween by failing to revere the Great Pumpkin, and now a curse has befallen you.  On the walkway to your house is a Ward of Seven Jack O'Lanterns arranged in a circle.  If midnight comes and any of the seven are still lit, a dark reaper and seven dark horses with seven dark riders shall visit thy abode.  They shall surround thy domicile and, while circling it, they will proceed to pelt thy dwelling with eggs and cream of shaving.  And come morn there will be a great mess to be reckoned with.  Verily.  So you better get those lanterns out.
You quickly discover something odd about these lanterns.  When you blow out the first one, the lanterns on either side extinguish as well!  But there is more.  If you blow out a lantern adjacent to one that is extinguished, the extinguished one(s) will relight.  It seems that blowing on any lantern will change the state of three - the one you blew on and its two neighbors.  Finally, you can blow on an extinguished lantern and it will relight, and its neighbors will light/extinguish as applicable.  After trying once and finding all seven lit again, you decide, being the excellent puzzler, you sit down and examine this closer.  But hurry, I hear the beating of many hooves...
Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
Number the jack-o’-lanterns 1,2,…,7 round the circle and let  

xi = 0  if you never blow on lantern i,
xi = 1  if you blow on lantern i once  
(two blows on the same lantern cancel, so 0/1 is enough).

Every time you blow on i the lanterns i–1, i, i+1 (indices taken mod 7) all change
their state.  Working modulo 2 (“lit” = 1, “out” = 0) and starting from the
all-lit vector (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), the final state will be

(1,1,1,1,1,1,1) + M x,

where M is the 7 × 7 binary matrix whose (i,j) entry is 1 when j = i, i±1
(mod 7) and 0 otherwise.  We need the final state to be (0,0,0,0,0,0,0), so

M x = (1,1,1,1,1,1,1).                                             (★)

Writing the seven equations in (★):

x7 + x1 + x2 = 1  
x1 + x2 + x3 = 1  
x2 + x3 + x4 = 1  
x3 + x4 + x5 = 1  
x4 + x5 + x6 = 1  
x5 + x6 + x7 = 1  
x6 + x7 + x1 = 1  (indices mod 7).

Add all seven equations.  Each xi appears exactly three times, and 3 ≡ 1 (mod 2),
so the left side is Σ xi.  The right side is 7 ≡ 1 (mod 2).  Hence

Σ xi = 1 (mod 2);            (1)

an odd number of lanterns must be blown on.

To solve (★) completely, start with the first two equations:

x7 = x3, x1 = x3, so x1 = x3 = x7.      (2)

Using (2) in the next pair gives x2 = x6, and using that in the next gives
x4 = x1.  Substituting these relations into any one of the original equations
yields

x1 = 1.

But then every variable equals x1, so

x1 = x2 = … = x7 = 1.                     (3)

Thus the UNIQUE solution of (★) is

x = (1,1,1,1,1,1,1).

Because the solution is unique and uses all seven 1’s, two important facts follow:

• One must blow on every single lantern.  
• Seven blows are the minimum possible; any smaller (odd) number cannot satisfy (★).

Therefore the procedure is simple:

Start anywhere and blow once on each of the seven jack-o’-lanterns (in any order; order does not matter).  After the seventh blow all three togglings
on every lantern have accumulated exactly once, cancelling the initial “lit”
state and leaving every lantern dark.

Final answer: blow on each of the seven lanterns exactly once – that alone, and nothing less, extinguishes them all.

Question:
Every day from Monday through Sunday in this week, Mr. Peter picks two shirts from the five colours red, blue, yellow, green and black. Peter follows the rules:
1. Peter doesn't use the same combination on two days of this week.
2. Peter doesn't use the same colour on two consecutive days of this week.
3. Peter uses some colour on four days.
4. Peter uses blue and black on Monday.
5. Peter uses green on Thursday.
6. Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday.
7. Peter doesn't combine red with black.
What colours does Peter use on Saturday?
Hint: Start from rules 2 and 3
Human Solution:
From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Response:
Step 1.  Which colour is the one that is worn on four days?  
Because the colour cannot be worn on two consecutive days, a colour that occurs four times in a seven-day week must be worn on every other day, i.e. on the four days  

  Mon – Wed – Fri – Sun.  

Since Monday’s combination is fixed as (Blue, Black), the “four-day” colour can only be Blue or Black.

•  Suppose it were Black.  
 Black would then have to be worn on Mon, Wed, Fri, Sun.  
 Friday would therefore have to contain Black, but  
  – Friday may not contain Yellow (rule 6),  
  – it may not contain Blue or Green (Wednesday’s colours, rule 2),  
  – it may not contain Red (rule 7, no Red with Black).  
 No colour is left to pair with Black on Friday – impossible.  
Hence Black cannot be the four-day colour.

Therefore Blue is the colour worn on four days: Mon, Wed, Fri, Sun.

Step 2.  Construct the combinations day by day.

Monday (given)  :  B + K.

Tuesday (avoid B, K) : choose R + G.  (any pair of {R,G,Y} would do; we pick R G.)

Wednesday (avoid R, G; must contain B)  
 Possible partners for Blue are Y or K.  
 B + K duplicates Monday, so take B + Y.

Thursday (given G; avoid B, Y)  
 Choices with G are K or R.  
 Taking G + K keeps later options open.

Friday (avoid G, K; must contain B; no Yellow)  
 Only colour available to pair with B is R ⇒ B + R.

Saturday (avoid B, R)  
 The unused, admissible pairs are {G,Y}, {Y,K}.  
 If Saturday were G + Y, then Sunday (which must contain B) could be neither B + K (duplicate) nor B + R (duplicate) nor B + Y/B + G (share a colour with Sat) – impossible.  
 Hence Saturday must be Y + K.

Sunday (avoid Y, K; must contain B; use unused pair)  
 B + G is the only remaining possible and unused combination.

Step 3.  Verify all requirements.

Mon  B K  
Tue  R G  
Wed  B Y  
Thu  G K  
Fri  B R  
Sat  K Y  
Sun B G  

• All seven combinations are different.  
• No colour appears on two consecutive days.  
• Blue appears on Mon, Wed, Fri, Sun – exactly four days.  
• Rule 4, 5, 6, 7 are all satisfied (Yellow not on Fri, no Red-Black pair, etc.).

Everything is consistent, and Saturday’s colours are uniquely determined.

Final answer: black and yellow

Question:
At the Christmas party of the "Sweaty Chef" kebab shop, the owner Mr Juan, took note of how many people were present. Although he was a bit tipsy when he made his note, and thus made a mistake.  His notes were as follows:-
1, There were 9 men and children.
2, There were 2 more women than children.
3, The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24. Note that if there were 7 men and 5 women, then there would have been 35 man-woman couples possible.
Also, of the three groups - men, women and children - at the party:
4, There were 4 of one group.
5, There were 6 of one group.
6, There were 8 of one group.
Exactly one of the above 6 statements is false.
Can you tell which one is false? Also, how many men, women and children are there at the party?
Hint: Can 4,5,6 all be true at the same time?
Human Solution:
Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Response:
Let  

M = number of men  
W = number of women  
C = number of children  

Translating the six notes:

1) M + C = 9  
2) W = C + 2  
3) M × W = 24  
4) At least one of the three groups has size 4  
5) At least one of the three groups has size 6  
6) At least one of the three groups has size 8  

Exactly one of the six statements is wrong.

Step 1 – Use the numerical equalities.

From (2): W = C + 2.  
Insert C = 9 − M from (1) to get W = 11 − M.  
Put this into (3):

 M · (11 − M) = 24  
 ⇒ M² – 11M + 24 = 0  
 ⇒ (M − 8)(M − 3) = 0  
 ⇒ M = 8 or M = 3.

This gives two candidate groups:

 a) M = 8, C = 1, W = 3  
 b) M = 3, C = 6, W = 8.

Step 2 – Decide which size statements (4-6) are true.

Because only one of the six notes is false, we test each possibility.

• Suppose note 4 is the false one (no group of size 4).  
  For candidate a) the sizes {8,1,3} contain no 6 or 4, breaking two notes—discard.  
  For candidate b) the sizes are {3,6,8}.  
 – Size 4 is absent → note 4 is indeed false.  
 – Size 6 is present → note 5 true.  
 – Size 8 is present → note 6 true.  
  Thus with candidate b) exactly one note (note 4) is false and all others are true.

• If instead note 5 or note 6 were the false one, we would need the sizes {4,8,x} or {4,6,x}.  Neither candidate set of sizes satisfies those requirements, so those alternatives fail.

Hence the only consistent arrangement is the second candidate with note 4 being the lone error.

Men M = 3  
Women W = 8  
Children C = 6  

Check:  
1) 3 + 6 = 9 ✔  
2) 8 = 6 + 2 ✔  
3) 3·8 = 24 ✔  
4) No group of size 4 ✖ (false)  
5) One group of size 6 ✔  
6) One group of size 8 ✔

Everything fits with exactly one false statement.

Final answer: Statement 4 is false; there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children at the party.

Question: Write on a piece of paper a 5x5 letter square using the alphabet, minus the letter Q, where A is in the upper left-hand corner and Z is in the lower right-hand corner.  After you have done this, can you tell me which letter comes just above the letter which comes between the letter just before the letter just below B and the letter just before the letter just above Y?
Hint: One step at a time
Human Solution:
The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Response:
First write the 25-letter alphabet (everything except Q) row by row in a 5 × 5 square, starting with A in the upper-left corner and ending with Z in the lower-right corner:

A  B  C  D  E  
F  G  H  I  J  
K  L  M  N  O  
P  R  S  T  U  
V  W  X  Y  Z  

Now follow the instruction, translating every “before / above / below / between” into the corresponding neighbour in the square.

1.  B is at (row 1, col 2).  
    • Just below B  →  G (row 2, col 2).  
    • Just before that G  →  F (row 2, col 1).  
       Call this letter X₁ = F.

2.  Y is at (row 5, col 4).  
    • Just above Y  →  T (row 4, col 4).  
    • Just before that T  →  S (row 4, col 3).  
       Call this letter X₂ = S.

3.  Which letter comes between X₁ (F at 2,1) and X₂ (S at 4,3)?
    They lie on the straight diagonal F → L → S; the square that is exactly between them is
    L (row 3, col 2).

4.  Finally, the letter just above that L (row 3, col 2) is
    G (row 2, col 2).

Hence the required letter is G.

Final answer: G

Question:
Consider a grid of size 4 x 4 (i.e. sixteen squares), where all squares should get a color. The colored grid should meet the following conditions:
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?
Hint: Start by placing the blues.
Human Solution:
There are multiple possible answers. Just check that the conditions in the original problem statement hold: 
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?

One possible arrangement:
W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Response:
One possible colouring that fulfils every requirement is  

Row 1 :   R   B   W   G  
Row 2 :   G   Y   R   B  
Row 3 :   B   W   G   Y  
Row 4 :   Y   R   B   W  

(Here R = red, B = blue, W = white, G = green, Y = yellow.)

Count of each colour:
• Blue  = 4 squares (1,2), (2,4), (3,1), (4,3)  
• Red   = 3 squares (1,1), (2,3), (4,2)  
• White = 3 squares (1,3), (3,2), (4,4)  
• Green = 3 squares (1,4), (2,1), (3,3)  
• Yellow= 3 squares (2,2), (3,4), (4,1)

Check of the restriction “no colour appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical or diagonal line”:
• In every row and every column each colour occurs at most once.  
• For every rising or falling diagonal (of any length) each listed colour occurs at most once – verified by examining the differences r − c and the sums r + c for the coordinates of every colour.

Hence the above arrangement satisfies all the given conditions.

Question:
I woke up late that morning to welcome a bright sunny day after a long and hectic week. It was a holiday and I was determined to spend the day playing cards with my friend Tweeto. Tweeto's favorite card game was the Romankachi card game.
The rules of the game are as follows :-
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
We started off with 5 cards each and I served in the first round.
At the end of three rounds if I had exactly 4 cards then which of the following statements must be true:-
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement is true. One or more statements may be true.
Hint: First, think about what possible results could lead to you having 4 cards?
Human Solution:
Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Response:
We start with 5 cards each and I serve in round 1.  
Notation: W = I win the round, L = I lose the round.

Card-change rules  
• If I serve: win → +2, lose → –1  
• If I receive: win → +1, lose → –2  
The winner of a round serves the next round.

Round-by-round enumeration (my running card total in parentheses).

1. I serve.

a) Round 1 = W: cards 5 → 7, I serve R2.  
   – R2 = W: cards 7 → 9, I serve R3.  
       • R3 = W ⇒ 11 (≠4)  
       • R3 = L ⇒ 8  (≠4)  
   – R2 = L: cards 7 → 6, I receive R3.  
       • R3 = W ⇒ 7  (≠4)  
       • R3 = L ⇒ 4  (OK)  → sequence W L L

b) Round 1 = L: cards 5 → 4, I receive R2.  
   – R2 = W: cards 4 → 5, I serve R3.  
       • R3 = W ⇒ 7  (≠4)  
       • R3 = L ⇒ 4  (OK)  → sequence L W L  
   – R2 = L: cards 4 → 2, I receive R3.  
       • R3 = W ⇒ 3  (≠4)  
       • R3 = L ⇒ 0  (game would end)

Thus the only possible three-round histories that leave me with exactly 4 cards are

1) W L L   2) L W L

In both:
• Tweeto wins exactly two rounds.  
• Tweeto wins the third round.  
• I do not necessarily win the first round (I do in 1, not in 2).

Hence, statements A and C must be true, while B need not be.

Final answer: A and C

Question:
Phil Fegit was sitting in his bedroom watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of MADADIA.  The water had caused floods throughout the town and water over six feet deep had forced people to abandon the downstairs of their homes and they had to retreat to the upstairs rooms. The yearly Kebab harvest had been washed away as the downpour had continued unabated for a full month.
Just at that moment Phil's wife, Norma, walked into the bedroom and he commented upon the rain. She replied that she could really care less. No matter how much Phil tried to stress the importance of the rain falling in Madadia, she refused to take it seriously.
How come?
Human Solution:
Phil was watching a news report about his home town on TV, he had recently moved away from the area and it was sunny where he was.
His wife wasn't from Madadia, hence she didn't care what happened there.
Response:
Reasoning steps  

1. Phil is “sitting in his bedroom” merely watching what is happening; he is not wading around in six-foot-deep water himself.  
2. The description of Madadia is absurdly comic: people “harvest” kebabs, and an entire “kebab harvest” is said to be washed away. Kebabs aren’t something that grow and are harvested, so the text is clearly describing a make-believe world.  
3. Because every detail is exaggerated and impossible, the easiest explanation is that Madadia exists only inside something Phil is looking at – e.g. a computer or TV screen.  
4. Phil’s excitement therefore concerns a fictional, simulated town that he has made or is watching; nothing real is in danger.  
5. Norma realises this. Since the disaster is happening only in Phil’s game (or programme) and not in the real world, she “could really care less” and refuses to take the discussion seriously.

Final answer: Norma knows that the flood is occurring only in Phil’s imaginary/ computer-game city “Madadia,” not in the real world, so she quite naturally doesn’t care about it.

Question:
There were 9 portraits of animals (bear, cat, dog, hamster, horse, lion, monkey, mouse, and tiger) on a wall of a museum.  As I was studying them, I tripped and fell into the wall and they all fell down. I have to get them back up on the wall in the correct order before I get into some serious trouble.  I only remember a couple of things about the order of the portraits.  Can you help me figure out the order of the portraits using the clues I remember about them?
They were displayed as follows:
Note: The Letter and Numbers in the graph are labels for their corresponding rows.
...........A...............B.............C
1    _________ l _________ l _________
2    _________ l _________ l _________
3    _________ l _________ l _________
Clues:
1.  The bear is in the same row as the hamster.
2.  Two portraits in both rows 3 and C have two animals that start with the same letter.
3.  The horse is in the same row as the monkey.
4.  The dog is in 2A.
5.  Either the lion or the tiger is below the cat.
6.  The monkey is either above or below the dog.
7.  The dog is not next to the tiger.
Hint: Monkey, mouse, hamster, horse are the only two pairs with same letter. Focus on this
Human Solution:
bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Response:
Place the pictures as follows (rows are numbered 1-3 from top to bottom, columns are A-C from left to right):

Row 1 :  A-Bear   B-Cat   C-Hamster  
Row 2 :  A-Dog    B-Lion  C-Tiger  
Row 3 :  A-Monkey B-Mouse C-Horse

Check of the clues
1. Bear and Hamster share Row 1 – yes.  
2. Row 3 has Monkey & Mouse (same initial M); Column C has Hamster & Horse (same initial H) – yes.  
3. Horse is in the same row as Monkey – Row 3 – yes.  
4. Dog is at 2A – yes.  
5. Lion (one of Lion/Tiger) is directly below Cat in column B – yes.  
6. Monkey is below Dog in column A – yes.  
7. Dog (2A) is not next to Tiger (2C) – yes.

Thus this arrangement satisfies every condition.  

Final answer: Row 1 – Bear, Cat, Hamster; Row 2 – Dog, Lion, Tiger; Row 3 – Monkey, Mouse, Horse

Question:
In the purely fictitious land of Fiddledeboox, the Minister of Finance emerged from a top-level meeting.   Reporters had gathered to hear his announcement about either an increase or a decrease in either wages, subsidies or tax levels.
It was widely known that this Minister [M] told the truth to reporters [R] only once in every three statements.
M:  Well, I can tell you that it's about subsidies.
R:  Are they going down again?
M:  Nothing is going down.
R:  So it's good news for the people?
M:  Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.
While others jostled to ask the next question, one logically minded newshound was already leaving with the hot headline news.
From the Minister's three statements above, can you also deduce the truth?
Hint:
Assume each statement, in turn, to be true.  Then examine the truth or otherwise of the others.
Or check the statements in the light of each of the six possibilities.
Human Solution:
It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Response:
Let

S : “The announcement concerns subsidies.”  
D : “Nothing is going down.”  
W : “Either subsidies are going down or wages are going up.”

The minister’s three utterances are exactly these three statements:

(1) S  
(2) D  
(3) W  

It is known that, in any block of three statements the minister makes to reporters, exactly one is true and the other two are false.

Enumerate the six possible single-item decisions that the government could announce (one increase or decrease in wages, subsidies or taxes) and see how each decision makes the three statements true or false.

                         S      D      W
1. wage ↑            F      T      T   (2 truths) ✗
2. wage ↓            F      F      F   (0 truths) ✗
3. subsidy ↑         T      T      F   (2 truths) ✗
4. subsidy ↓         T      F      T   (2 truths) ✗
5. tax ↑             F      T      F   (exactly 1 truth) ✓
6. tax ↓             F      F      F   (0 truths) ✗

Only decision 5 (“taxes are going up”) produces exactly one true statement: statement (2) “Nothing is going down.”  
Therefore statements (1) and (3) are false: the subject is not subsidies, subsidies are not going down, and wages are not going up.

Hence the lone truthful headline is:

Final answer: Taxes are being increased.

Question: There are 2008 eggs lying in front of you. I am also with you waiting to start the game. The goal of the game is to be the person to take that very last egg (or eggs) to win. You and I can each only take between 1 and 100 eggs at a time. You go first. How many eggs must you take initially in order to always win (assuming we both play perfectly)?
Hint: By a perfect game, that means over any two turns, the sum of the number of eggs  you and I take is the same (except of course, excluding the initial move you make).
Human Solution:
89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Response:
To analyze the game, note the following classic fact for “take-away” games:

• If on every turn a player may remove any number of objects from 1 up to M (here M = 100),  
  then the positions that are losing for the player whose turn it is are exactly the multiples of (M+1).

Reason:  
– From a multiple of (M+1) every legal move (removing k, 1 ≤ k ≤ M) leaves a pile of size  
  (M+1)·q – k = (M+1)(q–1) + [(M+1) – k], which is NOT a multiple of (M+1).  
– Conversely, from any non-multiple, a player can move to a multiple by removing exactly the remainder r (1 ≤ r ≤ M) when the pile is divided by (M+1).  
  Thereafter, whatever the opponent takes (k), you respond with (M+1) – k, restoring a multiple.  
  Eventually you take the last object(s) and win.

In this problem M = 100, so the critical modulus is 101.

Compute 2008 modulo 101:  
101 × 19 = 1919  
2008 – 1919 = 89.

Since 89 ≠ 0, the initial position is winning.  
The winning first move is to remove exactly the remainder, 89 eggs, leaving 2008 – 89 = 1919 eggs, which is 19 × 101, a multiple of 101.  
After that, whatever number k (1 ≤ k ≤ 100) the opponent removes, you always remove 101 – k, keeping a multiple of 101 after each of your turns and ensuring you take the final egg(s).

Final answer: 89

Question:
What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
Hint: Think mathematically.
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
First, translate each letter to its position in the alphabet (A = 1, B = 2, …, Z = 26).

Row 1:  O  Q  L  H  R  →  15 17 12  8 18  
Row 2:  I  J  F  E  Q  →   9 10  6  5 17

Now subtract the second‐row number from the first‐row number, column by column:

15 − 9 = 6 → F  
17 − 10 = 7 → G  
12 − 6 = 6 → F  
8 − 5 = 3 → C  
18 − 17 = 1 → A

The first four results (F, G, F, C) match the given third row, confirming the rule.  
Therefore, the missing fifth letter is A.

Final answer: A

Question:
A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Response:
Reasoning in full:

1.  The password is one of the five words
        HOE OAR PAD TOE VAT  
    and its three different letters are given one‐apiece to Al, Ben and Carl.

2.  Al is questioned first and is able to identify the password immediately, using
    only the single letter he received.
    •  That is possible only if his letter occurs in exactly ONE of the five words.  
       (If his letter appeared in two or more words, he could not distinguish
       which of those words was the password.)
    •  The letters that occur in only one word are
             D  (only in PAD)
             H  (only in HOE)
             P  (only in PAD)
             R  (only in OAR)
             V  (only in VAT)

    Hence Al must have received one of {D, H, P, R, V}, and the password
    must be a word that contains such a letter.  
    Therefore TOE is immediately ruled out (it has no unique letter).

3.  Ben now knows
        • his own letter, and
        • the fact that Al could tell the password from a unique letter.
    Ben, too, succeeds at once.  Check each of the remaining candidate words.

    a)  OAR  
        If OAR were the password, Al’s unique letter would be R, leaving
        O and A for Ben or Carl.  
        –  If Ben had O, the words HOE and OAR would both still be possible  
          (each contains a unique letter for Al), so Ben could **not** decide.  
        –  If Ben had A, the words OAR, PAD and VAT would still be possible.  
          Again he could **not** decide.  
        Hence OAR cannot be the password.

    b)  PAD  
        Al’s unique letter would have to be P or D.  
        –  If Ben received the non-unique A he could not decide.  
        –  If Ben received the other unique letter (D or P) he could decide,  
          but then Carl would be left with A and would **not** be able to
          decide in the next step.  
        So PAD is impossible.

    c)  VAT  
        Al’s unique letter would be V, leaving A and T.  
        –  For Ben to succeed he must get T (with T he can rule out TOE, leaving only VAT).  
        –  Carl would then hold the non-unique A; with A he would still see PAD
          and VAT as possibilities and could **not** decide.  
        So VAT is impossible.

    d)  HOE  
        Al’s unique letter must be H.  
        Suppose Ben gets E and Carl gets O.  
        –  Ben’s letter E appears in HOE and TOE.  
          But TOE has no unique letter for Al, so Ben rules TOE out and
          knows the password is HOE.  
        –  Carl hears that both Al and Ben have succeeded.  
          Holding O, he initially considers HOE, OAR and TOE.  
          TOE is impossible (no unique letter for Al);  
          OAR is impossible because, as shown before, Ben could not have
          decided with either O or A.  
          Thus only HOE remains, and Carl also knows the password.

        This distribution (Al = H, Ben = E, Carl = O) lets all three travellers
        deduce the word exactly as the story relates.

4.  No other word allows the three “Yes” answers in sequence; HOE is the
    unique solution.

Final answer: HOE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for R, U, O, N, or V
? stands for U, D, L, W, or J
@ stands for A, G, P, E, or Y
; stands for O, M, I, C, or S
The four letter code word, @!;?, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Morality
Human Solution: Good and Evil.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Translate the statement of the puzzle into four independent letter–choice lists:

   • First letter (@) can be A, G, P, E, Y  
   • Second letter (!) can be R, U, O, N, V  
   • Third letter (;) can be O, M, I, C, S  
   • Fourth letter (?) can be U, D, L, W, J  

2.  Because each symbol can stand for any one of five letters, a single coded form “@!;?” actually represents 5⁴ = 625 possible four-letter letter strings.

3.  The puzzle asks for two of those possible strings that
   (a) spell real English words, and  
   (b) are antonyms (opposites).

4.  Look for familiar four-letter antonym pairs and test them against the allowed letters in each position.

   • HARD / SOFT → 1st letter H not allowed – reject  
   • HIGH / LOW  → 2nd letter I not allowed – reject  
   • OPEN / SHUT → 2nd letter P not allowed – reject  
   • FAST / SLOW → 3rd letter S allowed, but 2nd A not allowed – reject  
   • GOOD / EVIL → check each letter:  
     – GOOD: G (allowed) | O (allowed) | O (allowed) | D (allowed)  
     – EVIL:  E (allowed) | V (allowed) | I (allowed) | L (allowed)  
     Both words fit perfectly.

5.  No other common four-letter antonym pair simultaneously satisfies all four position constraints, so the unique solution is:

   GOOD    ( @ = G, ! = O, ; = O, ? = D )  
   EVIL    ( @ = E, ! = V, ; = I, ? = L )

Final answer: GOOD and EVIL

Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
Hint: Calendar differences?
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
The puzzle is a play on words: “born in 1309, 1310 and 1311” does not refer to years but to the street-numbers of three buildings standing side-by-side on one road of the Old City.  

Adam was “born” (i.e. erected) at No. 1309, Ben at No. 1310 and Cyril at No. 1311.  
Each building has stood for well over sixty years and has been fully “active” (occupied and in use) all that time, but – being houses – they are fixed to their foundations and cannot move about. Hence they have never “crossed paths” with one another.

Final answer: Adam, Ben and Cyril are the names given to three neighbouring houses whose addresses are 1309, 1310 and 1311; houses cannot move, so they never cross paths.

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: In music...
Human Solution: Forte and Piano.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  The coded word is the five–symbol string  
        ( + _ * )
    Each position can be translated only by choosing a letter from the set assigned to that symbol:

        (  →  {Y, T, E, P, F}          ← first letter
        +  →  {N, G, I, O, X}          ← second letter
        _  →  {R, B, M, A, S}          ← third letter
        *  →  {L, T, K, C, N}          ← fourth letter
        )  →  {D, O, E, H, S}          ← fifth letter

2.  We need two ordinary English words, five letters long, which are antonyms, and each of which can be formed by picking letters from the corresponding sets above.

3.  Try words beginning with one of the possible first-letters Y, T, E, P, or F.
    •  A familiar pair of opposite musical dynamics is “piano” (soft) and “forte” (loud), both five letters long, starting respectively with P and F—both allowed letters for the first position.

4.  Verify that each letter of “piano” and “forte” fits its position’s allowed set:

        P I A N O
        | | | | |
        ( + _ * )
        P ∈ {Y,T,E,P,F}        ✓
        I ∈ {N,G,I,O,X}        ✓
        A ∈ {R,B,M,A,S}        ✓
        N ∈ {L,T,K,C,N}        ✓
        O ∈ {D,O,E,H,S}        ✓

        F O R T E
        | | | | |
        ( + _ * )
        F ∈ {Y,T,E,P,F}        ✓
        O ∈ {N,G,I,O,X}        ✓
        R ∈ {R,B,M,A,S}        ✓
        T ∈ {L,T,K,C,N}        ✓
        E ∈ {D,O,E,H,S}        ✓

5.  Both words satisfy the symbol constraints, and “piano” and “forte” are indeed opposites in meaning (soft vs. loud).

Final answer: PIANO and FORTE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Law
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response:
The pattern */+-= must give two different 5-letter English words, each obtained by choosing, for every symbol, one of the five letters allowed for that symbol:

*  → B O P F C  
/  → F N H E R  
+  → D G I M A  
-  → E O L C W  
=  → J K U R S  

Look for ordinary 5-letter opposites that satisfy these letter restrictions.

1.  End-letter restriction:  = can only be J, K, U, R, S, so each word must end in one of those.  
2.  Trial with final R or S (the commonest):  
    ORDER (O R D E R) fits the sets:  
      * = O, / = R, + = D, - = E, = = R.  
    Its opposite is CHAOS (C H A O S), which also fits:  
      * = C, / = H, + = A, - = O, = = S.

Both words respect every symbol’s letter list and are clear antonyms.

Therefore the two opposite words encoded by */+-= are:

Final answer: ORDER and CHAOS

Question:
runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
Hint: Look within the spellings...
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Response:
Think of what each given word is “a place for”.

• A runway is the place an airplane uses.  
• A cinema is the place a film is shown.  

So the two given words are both venues or settings.  
We now need another venue or setting that naturally goes with the word “answer”.

Where are answers given?  – On a test (or exam, quiz, etc.).  

Therefore one consistent completion of the ratio is  

runway : cinema :: answer : test  

(Any word that names the setting in which answers are supplied—exam, quiz, worksheet, question-paper, etc.—would also satisfy the puzzle’s “more than one possible answer” note.)  

Final answer: test

Question:
John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart. If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.
Response:
Reasoning step-by-step  

1.  Notation  
   C = club, D = diamond, H = heart, S = spade  
   Hands  
   John : C H D  Paul : C S S  George : C H H  Ringo : S D D  

2.  Facts that must hold in every trick  
   • Leading suit ≠ high suit (otherwise more than one high-suit card would be forced to appear).  
   • Exactly two players possess the leading suit; they supply the two cards of that suit.  
   • Of the remaining two players, the ones that still hold a card of the high suit are forced to play it, so exactly one of those two players may still have a high-suit card.  

3.  Try each suit as the high suit.

   High suit = Clubs  
   – At the start John, Paul, George all have a club.  
   – Whatever the first leading suit is (H, D or S), at least two of the three club-holders will lack it, hence two clubs must be played in the very first trick – impossible because only one high-suit card is allowed.  
   ⇒ Clubs cannot be the high suit.

   High suit = Hearts  
   – Only John and George own hearts.  
   – The only initial leading suit that gives exactly one heart among the two non-followers is D.  
   – After such a diamond trick the winner must lead the next, and the winner (John or George) would have only C and H left, forcing a club lead with three clubs in play – impossible.  
   ⇒ Hearts cannot be the high suit.

   High suit = Spades  
   – High cards are Paul-S, Paul-S, Ringo-S (two in one hand).  
   – The first trick can be led in D so that only one spade is forced, but the winner Paul would then have to lead a club (three clubs in play) or a spade (prohibited) – impossible.  
   ⇒ Spades cannot be the high suit.

   High suit = Diamonds  
   – High cards: John-D, Ringo-D, Ringo-D.  
   – Feasible play:

     Trick 1   Leader George plays H.  
               John follows H.  
               Paul cannot follow → plays high suit D?  (He has no D) → may play S.  
               Ringo cannot follow → must play D and wins.  
               (H, H, D, S)  – OK.

     Trick 2   Ringo leads S.  
               Paul follows S.  
               John cannot follow → plays high suit D and wins.  
               George cannot follow and has no D → plays C.  
               (S, S, D, C)  – OK.

     Trick 3   John leads C.  
               Paul follows C.  
               George cannot follow → plays remaining H.  
               Ringo cannot follow → plays his remaining high D and wins.  
               (C, C, H, D)  – OK.

     Each trick contains: two leading-suit cards, exactly one diamond, exactly one other card; the winner always leads next.  All rules are obeyed.

   ⇒ Diamonds can be the high suit, and all other possibilities are impossible.

4.  Therefore the unique possible high suit is Diamonds.

Final answer: Diamonds

Question:
Mad Ade sat at home, waiting for his favourite TV program "I'm a celebrity, Get me a Kebab" to start. He glanced at his clock and began to wonder strange and wondrous things, but that is another story altogether.
He realised that he could leave 6 adjacent numbers of the face of a clock intact and rearrange the other 6 in such a way that the sum of every pair of adjacent numbers is prime.
Unfortunately the TV program started at that point so he never actually got around to doing it. Can you find the two possible solutions to Mad Ade's clock teaser?
Hint: Part of it is making sure each number is odd...
Human Solution:
Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Response:
Reasoning

1.  Which 6 numbers can stay where they are?  
   The six fixed numbers have to be six consecutive ones on the ordinary clock-face.
   Inside that fixed block every pair of neighbours must add to a prime, i.e. every
   consecutive pair n,(n+1) must make  
      n+(n+1)=2n+1   a prime.  
   Trying every possible block of length six, only

        11 , 12 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4

   works, because their consecutive sums are  
        11+12=23, 12+1=13, 1+2=3, 2+3=5, 3+4=7 (all prime).  
   Therefore the positions 11,12,1,2,3,4 remain unchanged.

2.  What has to be done with the other six positions?  
   The vacant positions 5–10 must receive the six loose numbers
        5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 , 10
   so that every neighbouring pair round the whole circle sums to a prime.  
   Because the first fixed part ends with 4 and the second fixed part starts with 11,
   we have to find a prime-sum path

        4 – a – b – c – d – e – f – 11

   that uses each of {5,6,7,8,9,10} exactly once.  
   In the “prime-sum” graph (two numbers are adjacent if their sum is
   3,5,7,11,13,17,19 or 23) this becomes a Hamilton path problem on

        {4,5,6,7,8,9,10,11}     with 4 as start and 11 as finish.

   A short hand search (see table below) shows that there are exactly two such paths:

        4 – 7 – 10 – 9 – 8 – 5 – 6 – 11
        4 – 9 – 10 – 7 – 6 – 5 – 8 – 11

   (All consecutive sums are 11,17,19,17,13,11,17 respectively and therefore prime.)

3.  Writing the two complete clock faces.  
   Keeping 11,12,1,2,3,4 fixed and inserting the two paths gives

   Solution 1 (clockwise) :  
        12 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 7 , 10 , 9 , 8 , 5 , 6 , 11

   Solution 2 (clockwise) :  
        12 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 9 , 10 , 7 , 6 , 5 , 8 , 11

   Checking once round the rim confirms that every pair of neighbours indeed has
   a prime total for both arrangements.

Final answer: the only two possible rearrangements are  

  (i) 12-1-2-3-4-7-10-9-8-5-6-11   (clockwise round the face)  

  (ii) 12-1-2-3-4-9-10-7-6-5-8-11

Question: There are 10 people who could be the owner of the bank. They all sit in separate chairs across a long table facing north. The table is made of aluminium. The owner of the bank sits next to M. M sits on the left side of the banker. M sits next to C. C sits 4 places to the left of L. L sits next to O and rarely talks to S, E or Z, because they hate him and because they sit on the far right of the bank. O does not sit next to the owner of the bank. The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank and is considering resigning. Give the names of all the bankers from left to right.
Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Human Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Response:
Reasoning

1.  Let the ten chairs be numbered 1 (left-most) to 10 (right-most).

2.  “The owner of the bank sits next to M, and M sits on the left side of the banker.”
    Hence we have the block   C  M  B   with B (the owner) immediately to the right of M.

3.  “M sits next to C”, so C must be immediately to M’s left: the block is C–M–B.

4.  “C sits 4 places to the left of L.”  
    Therefore L is two seats to the right of B:
       seat(L) = seat(C)+4   ⇒   seat(L) = seat(B)+2.

5.  “L sits next to O” and “O does not sit next to the owner.”  
    The only way to satisfy both is to put O on L’s right, i.e. O two seats away from B.

6.  Trying to place the block
       C  M  B  ( ? )  L  O
    as far left as possible shows that C must be in seat 1; otherwise we would run out of room for all ten people.  
    Thus the partial arrangement is

       1   2   3   4   5   6
       C – M – B – ? – L – O

7.  Seats 8, 9, 10 must be S, E, Z (“they sit on the far right of the bank”).

8.  The only two people still unseated are F and T; they must go into seats 4 and 7.  
    T “hates the owner”, so we put T away from the owner (seat 7) and F in seat 4.

9.  One possible order for the right-hand trio is S E Z; any permutation of these three
    keeps them “on the far right”, so the exact internal order is irrelevant.

Final answer: C, M, (Owner), F, L, O, T, S, E, Z

Question: You and your spouse invite four other couples to a party. During the course of the conversation, it is discovered that, prior to the party, each person except you was acquainted with a different number of the people present. Assuming the acquaintance relationship is symmetric (i.e., if you are acquainted with someone, that person is also acquainted with you), then how many people did your spouse know prior to the party? How many people did you know?
Hint: Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person.
Human Solution:
Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Response:
Give every guest two numbers :

• n (P)  = “how many of the other eight guests P was already acquainted with (the spouse not being counted)”;  
• s (P)  = “the same number but including the spouse”.

Because a person does not count himself and does not count his (already–known) spouse, n (P) can be any integer from 0 to 8, while s (P)=n (P)+1 runs from 1 to 9.

During the party the nine people other than you report nine different values for n; hence the set of values must be  
{0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8}.                                                (1)

Step 1.  Extremes are married  
If a guest A has n(A)=0 he knows none of the eight “strangers”.  
If another guest B has n(B)=8 he knows all of those eight strangers.  
Therefore B certainly knows A, so A’s only possible acquaintance is B, i.e. A and B are spouses.  
Thus the couple (0, 8) is removed from further consideration.

Step 2.  Repeat the argument  
Remove that couple from the list and look at the remaining seven numbers.  
Exactly the same reasoning shows that the guests whose remaining extreme numbers are 1 and 7 must be married, the guests with 2 and 6 must be married, and the guests with 3 and 5 must be married.

After those four couples are paired off the only unpaired number left from (1) is  

  4.

Step 3.  Who can be the “4”?  
All four other couples have already been identified, so the guest whose n–value is 4 can only be your own spouse.

Step 4.  Your own number  
Your spouse is already acquainted with you.  Consequently you are acquainted with your spouse and with exactly the same four strangers, so

  n( spouse ) = 4  and  n( you ) = 4.

Step 5.  Convert back to s-numbers (include the spouse)  
Adding the spouse to the count gives  

  s( spouse ) = 4 + 1 = 5,  
  s( you )    = 4 + 1 = 5.

So each of you had already been acquainted with five of the ten people present (namely your own spouse plus four of the other eight guests).

Final answer:  Your spouse had previously known 5 people at the party, and you had previously known the same number, 5.

Question:
Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.
Response:
Nick bought a personalised car registration (number-plate).

Explanation step by step  
1. He had always wanted that particular registration mark, so he paid the DVLA (or a dealer) £5 000 for the right to use it.  
2. The very next day he accidentally broke the physical plastic/aluminium plate fixed to his car.  
3. To stay legal he went to a motor-factors shop and had a brand-new pair of plates made up; that costs only about £25.  
4. The registration mark itself is still his, and desirable – another motorist then offers him £6 000 for the right to that number.

Thus “it” is the personalised vehicle registration.

Question:
Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Let each letter stand for a (non–zero) integer and keep the same value wherever the letter re-appears.

1.  Translate the information into equations  

   Jane : J + A + N + E = 16                (1)  
   June : J + U + N + E = 17                (2)  
   Jean : J + E + A + N = 16 —same as (1)  
   Jenny: J + E + 2N + Y = 19               (3)

2.  Subtract (1) from (2) and (3):

        U – A = 1  ⇒ U = A + 1            (4)  
        (3) – (1): N + Y – A = 3 ⇒ Y = A + 3 – N (5)

3.  “June is in her prime.”  
    Interpreting the pun, take every letter in JUNE to be a prime number.  
    So J, U, N, E are distinct primes whose sum is 17.  
    The only set of four different primes with this property is

        {2, 3, 5, 7}  because 2 + 3 + 5 + 7 = 17.

4.  Decide which of those primes is U.  
    From (4) we need A = U – 1, and A must differ from all primes.

       U = 2 ⇒ A = 1  (but then only three primes are left – impossible)  
       U = 3 ⇒ A = 2  (A duplicates a prime – impossible)  
       U = 5 ⇒ A = 4  (fails because Y would clash or be zero)  
       U = 7 ⇒ A = 6  ✓  works.

   Hence U = 7 and A = 6.

5.  Fix N using (5).  
    With A = 6 we have Y = 9 – N.  
    To keep Y positive and distinct we need N = 5 (the only remaining prime).  
    Then Y = 9 – 5 = 4.

6.  Determine J and E.  
    The two unused primes are 2 and 3, and from (1)

        J + E = 16 – A – N = 16 – 6 – 5 = 5.

    Indeed 2 + 3 = 5, so J and E are 2 and 3 in either order.

7.  All six letters now have distinct non–zero integers:

        J   U   N   E   A   Y
       ————————————————
       2   7   5   3   6   4
       3   7   5   2   6   4

Both assignments satisfy every age equation, and no other choice does.

Final answer:  
1) J = 2, U = 7, N = 5, E = 3, A = 6, Y = 4  
2) J = 3, U = 7, N = 5, E = 2, A = 6, Y = 4

Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet. Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
Step 1 –  How many betting days were there?  
March 1 was a Saturday, so the first weekday was Monday, March 3.  
Weekdays from March 3 through March 31 (inclusive) are

5 days each in the weeks of the 3rd, 10th, 17th and 24th,  
plus Monday the 31st: 4·5+1 = 21 days.

So there were 21 one–dollar bets by each person.

Step 2 –  How many times did each person win?  
Let Kevin’s number of wins be k.  
Then Kate won k–1 times (“Kevin was right once more than Kate”) and  
Kathy won 2k times (“Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin”).

Only one of the three numbers 2, 3 and 3½ can be correct on any day, so at most one
person can win on a given day.  Hence

k + (k–1) + 2k = 4k – 1 ≤ 21  ⇒  k ≤ 5.

Thus k can be 1,2,3,4 or 5.

Step 3 –  Net gain or loss for one player in the month  
Every day a player puts $1 into the pool, so over 21 days he/she is –$21.  
Each time that player wins, he/she receives the whole $3 pool.
If a player wins w times, the month’s net change for that player is

Δ = –21 + 3w. (1)

Step 4 –  The starting amounts in terms of k  
Everybody finished with $20, so Starting amount = 20 – Δ.

Kevin: w = k  → S_Kevin = 20 – ( –21 + 3k ) = 41 – 3k  
Kate:  w = k–1 → S_Kate  = 20 – ( –21 + 3(k–1) ) = 44 – 3k  
Kathy: w = 2k → S_Kathy = 20 – ( –21 + 6k )      = 41 – 6k.  (2)

Step 5 –  Which choice of k gives the largest starting amount for anybody?  
Insert k = 1,2,3,4,5 into (2):

k  = 1 :  S_Kevin = 38,  S_Kate = 41,  S_Kathy = 35   →  maximum 41  
k  = 2 :  35, 38, 29   →  maximum 38  
k  = 3 :  32, 35, 23   →  maximum 35  
k  = 4 :  29, 32, 17   →  maximum 32  
k  = 5 :  26, 29, 11   →  maximum 29.

The greatest possible initial stash is $41, attained when k = 1; i.e.  
Kevin is right once, Kate never wins, and Kathy wins twice.

Step 6 –  Feasibility  
With k = 1 there are 18 days with no winner; on those days
each bettor simply loses $1, so nobody ever needs more cash than was
computed, and all three balances stay non-negative throughout the month.

Hence $41 is achievable and no larger amount is possible.

Final answer: 41

Question:
When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
Hint: For each person, assume they did it. Count how many truthful statements there are?
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
Let  

D = the guard who was on duty (and therefore the one who left the door open).  
There are four possibilities: D ∈ {Norris, Nobby, Morris, Robby}.
