Taking Sildenafil without taking Citrate, or vice versa, can also be very serious, because they must be taken together in order to be effective. In summary, you must take exactly one of the Sildenafil pills and one of the Citrate pills at one time. Therefore, you open up the Sildenafil bottle, and you tap one Sildenafil pill into your hand. You put that bottle aside and you open the Citrate bottle. You do the same, but by mistake, two Citrates fall into your hand with the Sildenafil pill.
Now, here's the problem. You weren't watching your hand as the pills fell into it, so you can't tell the Sildenafil pill apart from the two Citrate pills. The pills look identical. They are both the same size, same weight (10 micrograms), same color (Blue), same shape (perfect square), same everything, and they are not marked differently in any way.
What are you going to do? You cannot tell which pill is which, and they cost $300 a piece, so you cannot afford to throw them away and start over again. How do you get your daily dose of exactly one Sildenafil and exactly one Citrate without wasting any of the pills?
Hint: You can cut pills in half
Human Solution: Carefully cut each of the three pills in half, and carefully separate them into two piles, with half of each pill in each pile. You do not know which pill is which, but you are 100% sure that each of the two piles now contains two halves of Citrate and half of Sildenafil. Now go back into the Sildenafil bottle, take out a pill, cut it in half, and add one half to each stack. Now you have two stacks, each one containing two halves of Sildenafil and two halves of Citrate. Take one stack of pills today, and save the second stack for tomorrow.
Response:
Take advantage of the fact that tomorrow you will need one Sildenafil and one Citrate anyway.

1.  Bring out one more (whole) Sildenafil tablet from its bottle.  
    You now have four whole tablets:
       • the unknown Sildenafil already in your hand  
       • the two Citrates already in your hand  
       • the additional Sildenafil you have just taken out

2.  With a razor‐blade or pill-cutter, cut each of the four tablets exactly in half.  
    You obtain eight half-tablets.  
    Composition of the eight halves is now known abstractly:
       – 4 halves are Sildenafil (because there are two Sildenafil tablets in total)  
       – 4 halves are Citrate (because there are two Citrate tablets in total)

3.  Make two equal piles as follows.  
    Put one half of every original tablet into Pile A and the other half of that
    same tablet into Pile B.  
    (In other words, each whole tablet is “split” between the two piles.)

    Because each pile receives one half from each of the four original tablets,
    every pile contains:
       – one half of each of the two Sildenafil tablets  → 2 halves Sildenafil = 1 whole Sildenafil  
       – one half of each of the two Citrate tablets     → 2 halves Citrate   = 1 whole Citrate  

    So each pile is exactly one daily dose: 1 Sildenafil + 1 Citrate.

4.  Swallow all the halves in Pile A today.  
    Save Pile B (e.g., in a labelled envelope) and swallow it tomorrow.

Result:
• Today you ingest exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate.  
• Tomorrow you will again ingest exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate.  
• No tablet or part of a tablet is thrown away; nothing is wasted, and the
  expensive medicine is fully used.

Question:
Al, Ben, Carl, and Dan live in four adjacent apartments. The apartments are set up like this:
|1|2|3|4|
with apartment 1 being the westernmost apartment and apartment 4 being the easternmost. One of the four is the landlord. Here are some facts:
1. If Carl does not live next to Ben, then Al is the landlord and he lives in apartment 1.
2. If Al lives east of Carl, then Dan is the landlord and he lives in apartment 4.
3. If Ben does not live next to Dan, then Carl is the landlord and he lives in apartment 3.
4. If Dan lives east of Al, then Ben is the landlord and he lives in apartment 2.
Who is the landlord?
Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Human Solution:
Carl is the landlord.
Obviously only one conclusion is true at most. Let us suppose that all conclusions are false. This would mean that each hypothesis is also false. From facts 1 and 3, Ben lives next to both Carl and Dan, and therefore between Carl and Dan. Then either Al lives east of both Carl and Dan (contradicting fact 4) or Carl and Dan both live east of Al (contradicting fact 2.) So there must be exactly one true hypothesis, which will be paired with the one true conclusion. Obviously each of the three false conclusions is paired with a false hypothesis.
If conclusion 1 is true, then Al lives in apartment 1. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al has to live east of Dan. So this cannot be right.
If conclusion 2 is true, then Dan lives in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al must live east of Dan. So this cannot be right, either.
If conclusion 4 is true, Ben lives in apartment 2. Then, since hypotheses 1 and 3 are false, Ben lives between Carl and Dan, putting Al in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 2 is false, Carl must live east of Al. Therefore, conclusion 3 is true.
Response:
The landlord must be Carl.

A concrete arrangement that satisfies every conditional is  
Dan in apartment 1, Al in apartment 2, Carl (the landlord) in apartment 3, Ben in apartment 4.  
With this layout

• Carl is next to Ben, so the hypothesis of statement 1 is false and statement 1 imposes nothing.  
• Al is not east of Carl, so the hypothesis of statement 2 is false and statement 2 imposes nothing.  
• Ben is not next to Dan, so the hypothesis of statement 3 is true; its conclusion requires Carl to be the landlord in apartment 3, which is exactly the case.  
• Dan is not east of Al, so the hypothesis of statement 4 is false and statement 4 imposes nothing.

Thus all four statements are satisfied simultaneously, and Carl is indeed the only possible landlord.

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
@ stands for M, O, F, L, or V
$ stands for B, N, R, E, or J
% stands for T, F, B, L, or A
! stands for W, T, S, E, or I
# stands for F, O, A, T, or L
The five letter code word, %$#@!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Prepositions
Human Solution: Above and Below
Response:
To read the code % $ # @ ! we must choose, for each symbol, one of the five letters allowed for that symbol:

%  →  T / F / B / L / A  
$  →  B / N / R / E / J  
#  →  F / O / A / T / L  
@  →  M / O / F / L / V  
!  →  W / T / S / E / I  

1. Because we want two opposite English words, both five letters long, start by examining the first–letter possibilities (from %).  
   • Common beginning letters of five-letter antonym pairs include A and B (e.g., ABOVE/BELOW), H and S (HAPPY/SAD—lengths differ), L and S (LARGE/SMALL), etc.  
   • The only realistic five-letter opposites that start with letters in the % set {T, F, B, L, A} are ABOVE/BELOW.

2. Test the word ABOVE against the symbol constraints:  
   %  A   (allowed)  
   $  B   (allowed)  
   #  O   (allowed)  
   @  V   (allowed)  
   !  E   (allowed)  
   Therefore ABOVE is a legal decoding.

3. Test its opposite BELOW:  
   %  B   (allowed)  
   $  E   (allowed)  
   #  L   (allowed)  
   @  O   (allowed)  
   !  W   (allowed)  
   BELOW is also a legal decoding.

4. No other five-letter antonym pair fits all the symbol restrictions simultaneously.

Hence the two possible translations of the code %$#@! are the opposite words

ABOVE and BELOW.

Final answer: ABOVE and BELOW

Question: Two friends, Joe and Smoe, were born in May, one in 1932, the other a year later. Each had an antique grandfather clock of which he was extremely proud. Both of the clocks worked fairly well considering their age, but one clock gained ten seconds per hour while the other one lost ten seconds per hour. On a day in January, the two friends set both clocks correctly at 12:00 noon. "Do you realize," asked Joe, "that the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday?" Smoe agreed. Who is older, Joe or Smoe?
Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Human Solution: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again. This is when the slow clock loses six hours, and the fast one gains six hours. This will take 90 days. In 90 days they will come together at 6:00. On a calendar, there are 90 days between noon January 31, and noon May 1 in years with no leap year. If Smoe had been born in 1933, his 47th birthday would have been in 1980, a leap year. This means that Smoe must be older, born in 1932, and the time of this problem is 1979.
Response:
Let  

• one clock gain 10 s per hour,  
• the other lose 10 s per hour.  

After they are started together, the two dials separate from each other at the rate  

10 s + 10 s = 20 seconds every hour.

For the two dials to look alike again the faster one must get exactly 12 hours (43 200 s) ahead of the slower, because a 12-hour advance makes the same reading on a 12-hour clock face.  
Hence

43 200 s ÷ 20 s / h = 2160 h = 2160 h ÷ 24 h / day = 90 days.

Thus the clocks coincide every 90 days.  
The friends set the clocks “on a day in January” at 12 : 00 noon, and “the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday.”

Therefore 90 days after that January starting date must be Smoe’s birthday.

Which January date is 90 days before a May birthday?

In an ordinary (non-leap) year

Jan 31  +  90 days  =  May 1,

whereas in a leap year Jan 31 + 90 days would be April 30 (because of Feb 29).  
So the year in which they are talking is a non-leap year and the date of setting is 31 January.

Hence Smoe’s birthday is 1 May, and in that year he will be 47.  
Consequently

1 May 1979 → 47th birthday ⇒ year of birth 1979 – 47 = 1932.

Joe, being the other friend, must be the one born a year later, in 1933.

So Smoe (born May 1932) is the older, and Joe (born May 1933) is the younger.

Final answer: Smoe is older than Joe.

Question:
Ole Santa's pack held thirty toys
Made by his elfin crew;
And though none made the same amount,
Each elf made more than two.
The elf named Cher made one more Christmas toy
Than the elf who dressed in reds,
But Cher made one less Christmas toy
Than the elf who made the sleds.
Spry Johnny Elf made racing cars;
Five toys were made by Jane.
The elf who dressed in yellow suits
Made each and every train.
The elf who always dressed in green
Made one-third as many as Sue;
Cute Marcia elf was dressed in orange,
And one elf dressed in blue.
The elf who made the spinning tops
Made the most toys of them all.
Another perky smiling elf
Made each and every ball.
Ole Santa's pack held thirty gifts
All tagged for girls and boys.
From the clues that you've been given,
Now guess who made the toys!
Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Human Solution:
Cute Marcia was in orange and made seven sleds.
Sue was in blue and made nine spinning tops.
Jane was in red and made five balls.
Spry Johnny was in green and made three racing cars.
Cher was in yellow and made six trains.
Response:
Johnny – dressed in green – built the 3 racing cars.  
Jane – dressed in red – built the 5 balls.  
Cher – dressed in yellow – built the 6 trains.  
Marcia – dressed in orange – built the 7 sleds.  
Sue – dressed in blue – built the 9 spinning tops.

Final answer: Johnny (cars 3 green), Jane (balls 5 red), Cher (trains 6 yellow), Marcia (sleds 7 orange), Sue (tops 9 blue).

Question:
You are back on the same game show with four other contestants. You didn't realise last time that the winner gets another appearance on the show! You now have another chance to win half a million dollars and become a millionaire! The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues. The first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response: Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Strategy agreed on beforehand  
1. Everybody will assume that the total number of white hats in the room is EVEN.  
2. After they are lined up each prisoner counts the white hats that he can see on the others.  
   • If he sees an EVEN number of white hats he says “BLACK”.  
   • If he sees an ODD number of white hats he says “WHITE”.

Why it works  
Let W be the actual number of white hats placed by the warden.

• If W is even  
 – A prisoner whose own hat is black sees W white hats, an even number.  
  He therefore says “BLACK”, which is correct.  
 – A prisoner whose own hat is white sees W–1 white hats, an odd number.  
  He therefore says “WHITE”, which is also correct.  
 So every single prisoner guesses correctly.

• If W is odd  
 – A prisoner whose own hat is black sees W white hats, an odd number.  
  He therefore says “WHITE”, which is wrong.  
 – A prisoner whose own hat is white sees W–1 white hats, an even number.  
  He therefore says “BLACK”, which is also wrong.  
 So every single prisoner guesses incorrectly.

Hence, no matter how the warden distributes the hats, either all the guesses are right (when W is even) or all the guesses are wrong (when W is odd). In either case the prisoners satisfy the warden’s condition and go free, and the warden, knowing their strategy in advance, cannot prevent it.

Final answer: Each prisoner assumes the total number of white hats is even; he counts the white hats he sees and says “black” if that count is even and “white” if it is odd. This makes every prisoner simultaneously right when the real total of white hats is even, and simultaneously wrong when it is odd, guaranteeing their release.

Question:
Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Let  

    De, B, E, M ∈ {S,G,D,R}  

denote respectively the cars received by Derek, Berrick, Eric and Merick, where  
S = Silver Dream, G = Golden Pleasure, D = Devine Lightning, R = Rusting Bucket.  

Each statement of the form  

 “X will not get car C unless Y gets C₁ and Z gets C₂’’  

is the implication  

 If X gets C ⇒ (Y gets C₁ and Z gets C₂).

Step 1.  Test Derek = G.  
Rule 1 forces B = S and E = R.  
Rule 5 (B = S) then forces De = D, contradicting De = G.  
∴ Derek cannot get G.

Step 2.  Test Derek = S.  
Rule 4 forces M = D and E = R.  
Rule 7 (M = D) then forces B = G and De = R, contradicting De = S.  
∴ Derek cannot get S.

Step 3.  Test Derek = D.  
Rule 6 forces B = G and M = S.  
Rule 9 (M = S) then forces E = G, but G is already taken by B.  
∴ Derek cannot get D.

Step 4.  The only remaining possibility is Derek = R.  
Rule 8 then forces B = D and E = G.  
With S the only car left, M = S.

Check every rule:

1  (De ≠ G) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
2  (B ≠ R) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
3  (E ≠ D) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
4  (De ≠ S) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
5  (B ≠ S) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
6  (De ≠ D) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
7  (M ≠ D) – antecedent false, satisfied.  
8  De = R ⇒ B = D and E = G – satisfied by construction.  
9  M = S ⇒ E = G – satisfied.

All conditions are met and, since every possible car for Derek except R led to contradiction, the solution is unique.

Final answer:  
Derek – Rusting Bucket, Berrick – Devine Lightning, Eric – Golden Pleasure, Merick – Silver Dream.

Question:
Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Number the standing places round the driver’s “starting spot’’ 1,2, … ,30 in the clockwise direction, and let the counting begin with the person who is standing in place 1 (he is counted “one’’).

The driver eliminates every 9-th person (Josephus problem with n = 30, k = 9).  
Write down, step by step, which numbers leave the circle.

Step 1 : (1 + 8) mod 30 = 9 →  9 leaves  
Step 2 : (9 + 8) mod 29 = 18 → 18 leaves  
Step 3 : (18 + 8) mod 28 = 27 → 27 leaves  
Step 4 : (27 + 8) mod 27 = 6  →  6 leaves  
Step 5 : (6 + 8) mod 26 = 16  → 16 leaves  
Step 6 : (16 + 8) mod 25 = 26 → 26 leaves  
Step 7 : (26 + 8) mod 24 = 7  →  7 leaves  
Step 8 : (7 + 8) mod 23 = 19 → 19 leaves  
Step 9 : (19 + 8) mod 22 = 30 → 30 leaves  
Step 10: (30 + 8) mod 21 = 12 → 12 leaves  
Step 11: (12 + 8) mod 20 = 24 → 24 leaves  
Step 12: (24 + 8) mod 19 = 8  →  8 leaves  
Step 13: (8 + 8) mod 18 = 22  → 22 leaves  
Step 14: (22 + 8) mod 17 = 5  →  5 leaves  
Step 15: (5 + 8) mod 16 = 23  → 23 leaves  

After fifteen eliminations the numbers that have been forced to walk are

5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 19, 22, 23, 24, 26, 27, 30.

Consequently the people still standing (and therefore allowed to remain on the bus) occupy the fifteen places

1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29.

Therefore you (and every other supporter of your team) should take exactly these fifteen places.  
For example:

1 – you,  
2 – teammate,  
3 – teammate,  
4 – teammate,  
10 – teammate,  
11 – teammate,  
13 – teammate,  
14 – teammate,  
15 – teammate,  
17 – teammate,  
20 – teammate,  
21 – teammate,  
25 – teammate,  
28 – teammate,  
29 – teammate.

Seat the supporters of the other team in the remaining fifteen places (5,6,7,8,9,12,16,18,19,22,23,24,26,27,30).  
When the driver begins counting off nines, every elimination will fall on one of the opposing fans, and no member of your own side will have to leave the bus.

Final answer: Arrange your own team in clockwise positions 1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28 and 29 (with yourself in any one of these); place supporters of the other team in the remaining positions. Then the driver’s “count-nine’’ procedure makes only the opposing fans leave, and none of your teammates will have to walk.

Question:
It appears that you have angered the spirit of Halloween by failing to revere the Great Pumpkin, and now a curse has befallen you.  On the walkway to your house is a Ward of Seven Jack O'Lanterns arranged in a circle.  If midnight comes and any of the seven are still lit, a dark reaper and seven dark horses with seven dark riders shall visit thy abode.  They shall surround thy domicile and, while circling it, they will proceed to pelt thy dwelling with eggs and cream of shaving.  And come morn there will be a great mess to be reckoned with.  Verily.  So you better get those lanterns out.
You quickly discover something odd about these lanterns.  When you blow out the first one, the lanterns on either side extinguish as well!  But there is more.  If you blow out a lantern adjacent to one that is extinguished, the extinguished one(s) will relight.  It seems that blowing on any lantern will change the state of three - the one you blew on and its two neighbors.  Finally, you can blow on an extinguished lantern and it will relight, and its neighbors will light/extinguish as applicable.  After trying once and finding all seven lit again, you decide, being the excellent puzzler, you sit down and examine this closer.  But hurry, I hear the beating of many hooves...
Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
Number the pumpkins 0,1,2,3,4,5,6 around the circle (indices taken mod 7).  
Write xₖ ∈ {0,1} for “blow on pumpkin k an odd (xₖ=1) or an even (xₖ=0) number of times.’’  
Blowing on pumpkin k toggles pumpkins k–1, k and k+1, so, starting with every pumpkin lit (state 1) and wishing to finish with every pumpkin out (state 0), we must satisfy  

  x_{k-1}+x_k+x_{k+1} ≡ 1  (mod 2) for every k = 0,…,6. (1)

(Each left–hand side is the total number of times pumpkin k is toggled; it has to be odd so that the light that began on ends up off.)

Solve the linear system (1).  
Let a = x₀ and b = x₁.  From the equation for k = 1 we get  

 x₂ = 1 + x₀ + x₁ = 1 + a + b.  

For k = 2 : x₃ = 1 + x₁ + x₂ = 1 + b + (1+a+b) = a.  

For k = 3 : x₄ = 1 + x₂ + x₃ = 1 + (1+a+b) + a = b.  

For k = 4 : x₅ = 1 + x₃ + x₄ = 1 + a + b.  

For k = 5 : x₆ = 1 + x₄ + x₅ = 1 + b + (1+a+b) = a.  

Now impose the equation for k = 6 :  

 x₅ + x₆ + x₀ = (1+a+b) + a + a = 1 + a + b = 1,  

so a + b = 0, i.e. b = a.  
Finally, the equation for k = 0 gives  

 x₆ + x₀ + x₁ = a + a + a = a ≡ 1 (mod 2),  

hence a = 1 and therefore b = 1.  Substituting back we obtain  

 x₀ = x₁ = x₂ = … = x₆ = 1.

Thus every pumpkin must be blown on exactly once (any order; blowing the same one twice would cancel the effect).  
Because the solution is unique, seven blows are not only sufficient but also necessary.

So the cure for the curse is simply:

Blow on each of the seven jack-o’-lanterns one time; when the last one is blown, all seven will be extinguished.

Question:
Every day from Monday through Sunday in this week, Mr. Peter picks two shirts from the five colours red, blue, yellow, green and black. Peter follows the rules:
1. Peter doesn't use the same combination on two days of this week.
2. Peter doesn't use the same colour on two consecutive days of this week.
3. Peter uses some colour on four days.
4. Peter uses blue and black on Monday.
5. Peter uses green on Thursday.
6. Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday.
7. Peter doesn't combine red with black.
What colours does Peter use on Saturday?
Hint: Start from rules 2 and 3
Human Solution:
From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Response:
Let the five colours be denoted by  

R (red), B (blue), Y (yellow), G (green) and K (black).

For every day Peter wears an unordered pair of different colours.
The ten possible pairs are therefore the ten 2-element subsets of {R,B,Y,G,K}.

Step 1 – information that is given directly  
Monday M : {B , K}                (rule 4)  
Thursday T : {G , ?}               (rule 5)

Step 2 – the colour that is used on four days  
Because every pair has to be different (rule 1), a colour that is worn on four days
must be combined once with each of the other four colours.
•  K cannot be that colour – it may not be combined with R (rule 7),  
   so only three different partners are possible.  
•  R cannot be that colour for the same reason.  
Thus the only possible “4-day colour’’ is B, G or Y.

Green cannot start on Monday; with the non-consecutive rule (rule 2)  
it could appear at most on the positions 2,4,6 – only three times.  
Yellow is forbidden on Friday (rule 6), so the pattern Mon,Wed,Fri,Sun is impossible.  
Therefore the only feasible 4-day colour is Blue.

Consequently Blue must be worn on four days, once with each
of the other colours: BK, BY, BR and BG.

We already have BK on Monday, so BY, BR and BG must appear
once each on the remaining days, none of them on consecutive days.

Step 3 – Tuesday  
Tuesday must avoid both colours of Monday, hence no B or K.  
Its pair is chosen from {R,Y,G}.  
If it were {R,Y} or {Y,G}, Green or Yellow would have to be avoided on
Wednesday, making it impossible to realise the four required blue pairs.
Thus Tuesday has to be {R , G}.  
(Write the week now as:  
M BK T RG _ _ _ _ _ )

Step 4 – Wednesday  
Wednesday must avoid R and G, and may not repeat BK.
The only available blue pair is therefore BY.  
M BK T RG W BY _ _ _ _

Step 5 – Thursday  
Thursday must contain G (rule 5) but cannot repeat BY and cannot contain B or Y
(consecutive with Wednesday).  
The only admissible pair is {G , K}.  
M BK T RG W BY Th GK _ _ _

Step 6 – Friday  
Friday has to be a blue pair different from BK and BY and must avoid G and K.
Hence it must be BR (and this also satisfies “no yellow on Friday’’).  
M BK T RG W BY Th GK F BR _ _

Step 7 – Saturday  
Saturday must avoid the colours of Friday, B and R.
Possible colours are {G,Y,K}; but G cannot be used because Sunday
still needs the last blue pair BG and G would then be on consecutive days.
The only remaining unused pair is {K , Y}.  
M BK T RG W BY Th GK F BR Sa KY _

Step 8 – Sunday  
The missing blue pair is BG, and it does not clash with Saturday.  
M BK T RG W BY Th GK F BR Sa KY Su BG

Step 9 – verification  
• All seven pairs are different.  
• No colour appears on two consecutive days.  
• Blue appears exactly four times; no other colour does.  
• All given rules are obeyed.

Hence the colours worn on Saturday are

black and yellow.  

Final answer: black and yellow

Question:
At the Christmas party of the "Sweaty Chef" kebab shop, the owner Mr Juan, took note of how many people were present. Although he was a bit tipsy when he made his note, and thus made a mistake.  His notes were as follows:-
1, There were 9 men and children.
2, There were 2 more women than children.
3, The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24. Note that if there were 7 men and 5 women, then there would have been 35 man-woman couples possible.
Also, of the three groups - men, women and children - at the party:
4, There were 4 of one group.
5, There were 6 of one group.
6, There were 8 of one group.
Exactly one of the above 6 statements is false.
Can you tell which one is false? Also, how many men, women and children are there at the party?
Hint: Can 4,5,6 all be true at the same time?
Human Solution:
Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Response:
Let  

 M = number of men, W = number of women, C = number of children.

Exactly one of the six statements is wrong.

If a statement is true we translate it to an equation (or requirement); if it is the single false one we drop that requirement.

1. “There were 9 men and children” ⇒ M + C = 9.  
2. “There were 2 more women than children” ⇒ W = C + 2.  
3. “The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24” ⇒ M · W = 24.  
4. “There were 4 of one group” ⇒ 4 is one of {M, W, C}.  
5. “There were 6 of one group” ⇒ 6 is one of {M, W, C}.  
6. “There were 8 of one group” ⇒ 8 is one of {M, W, C}.

We examine, one at a time, the possibility that each statement is the single false one.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
A.  Suppose statement 1 is false (all others true)

Then M + C ≠ 9, while 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 must all hold.

From 2 and 3 (both true) we have W = C + 2 and M · W = 24.  
The factor pairs of 24 are (1,24), (2,12), (3,8), (4,6) and their reverses.  
For each pair we compute C = W – 2.  None of the resulting triples {M, W, C} contain all of 4, 6, 8, which they must because 4, 5, 6 are true.  
Hence no solution; statement 1 cannot be the false one.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
B.  Suppose statement 2 is false (all others true)

Now M + C = 9 and M · W = 24 are both true, and {M, W, C} must contain 4, 6, 8.

Trying every factor pair for M · W = 24 and using C = 9 – M gives the eight possible triples  

{1,24,8}, {2,12,7}, {3,8,6}, {4,6,5}, {6,4,3}, {8,3,1}, …  

None of them contain all of 4, 6, 8.  So statement 2 cannot be the single false one.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
C.  Suppose statement 3 is false (all others true)

Then M + C = 9 and W = C + 2 are true, and again {M, W, C} must contain 4, 6, 8.

From M + C = 9 and W = 11 – M we list the possibilities

M = 1…9  ⇒  triples {1,10,8}, {2,9,7}, {3,8,6}, {4,7,5},
{5,6,4}, {6,5,3}, {7,4,2}, {8,3,1}, {9,2,0}.

None of them contain all of 4, 6, 8, so statement 3 cannot be the false one.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
D.  Suppose statement 4 is false (all others true)

So 4 ∉ {M, W, C}, but 6 and 8 must both be in {M, W, C}.  
Statements 1, 2, 3 now all hold:

M + C = 9   (1)  
W = C + 2   (2)  
M · W = 24  (3)

Combine (1) and (2): W = 11 – M.  
Insert in (3): M(11 – M) = 24  
⇒ –M² + 11M – 24 = 0  
⇒ (M – 3)(M – 8) = 0.

Thus M = 3 or M = 8.

If M = 8 then W = 3, C = 1, and {M, W, C} = {8,3,1}; this contains 4? no, but it also lacks 6, contradicting statement 5.  Therefore M ≠ 8.

Take M = 3:  then W = 8, C = 6, and {M, W, C} = {3,8,6}.  
This contains 6 and 8 (statements 5 and 6 true) and does not contain 4 (making statement 4 the lone false one).  
All other required equations are satisfied:

M + C = 3 + 6 = 9  ✔  
W = C + 2    8 = 6 + 2 ✔  
M · W = 3 × 8 = 24  ✔  

Everything fits with exactly one false statement (statement 4).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
E.  Statements 5 or 6 as the single false one

By symmetry with the arguments above, each of these cases fails because the remaining two size–statements plus 1,2,3 lead to contradictions similar to A–C.  (A brief check shows no triple can contain both 4 and 8 but not 6, nor both 4 and 6 but not 8, while still satisfying 1, 2, 3.)

Hence the only consistent scenario is that statement 4 is the single false statement, giving the unique counts

 Men  = 3, Women = 8, Children = 6.

Conclusion  
The false statement is statement 4 (“There were 4 of one group”).  
At the party there were 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.

Final answer:  Statement 4 is false; there were 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.

Question: Write on a piece of paper a 5x5 letter square using the alphabet, minus the letter Q, where A is in the upper left-hand corner and Z is in the lower right-hand corner.  After you have done this, can you tell me which letter comes just above the letter which comes between the letter just before the letter just below B and the letter just before the letter just above Y?
Hint: One step at a time
Human Solution:
The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Response:
First set up the 5 × 5 square with the whole alphabet except Q, written row–by–row:

A  B  C  D  E  
F  G  H  I  J  
K  L  M  N  O  
P  R  S  T  U  
V  W  X  Y  Z  

Step-by-step interpretation of the sentence.

1. “the letter just below B”  
   B is in the first row, second column; the letter directly beneath it is G.

2. “the letter just before the letter just below B”  
   The letter immediately to the left of G is F.

3. “the letter just above Y”  
   Y is in the last row, fourth column; the letter directly above it is T.

4. “the letter just before the letter just above Y”  
   The letter immediately to the left of T is S.

5. “the letter which comes between … F and … S”  
   In the square the straight line joining F (row 2, col 1) and S (row 4, col 3) is a diagonal of a 3 × 3 subsquare; the single square exactly midway on that diagonal is row 3, col 2, which contains L.

6. “the letter which comes just above” that midpoint letter  
   Directly above L (row 3, col 2) is G (row 2, col 2).

Thus the required letter is G.

Final answer: G

Question:
Kevin's class picture has 28 photos arranged in a 7 x 4 grid.  The photos in the top row are numbered 1 through 7 from left to right, with the photos in the remaining rows similarly numbered.  Given the following clues (bordering includes horizontal, vertical, and diagonal), where is Kevin's picture?
X X X X X X X (1 - 7)
X X X X X X X (8 - 14)
X X X X X X X (15 - 21)
X X X X X X X (22 - 28)
1) There are 11 boys and 17 girls.
2) No boy is next to another boy horizontally or vertically.
3) There are no more than three boys in each row.
4) One column has only girls.
5) Three boys are not along the edge of the picture.
6) The second boy is at an odd position.
7) The range of the boys' positions is 24.
8) The median of the boys' positions is 12 or 13 or 14.
9) There are boys in two corners.
10) Kevin occupies an even position, and is the only boy who borders a unique number of girls.
Hint: There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.
Human Solution:
A) There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.  If the first boy is at location 4, then there could only be two boys in the first row.  The first boy must be located before position 4, therefore a girl must occupy: 28 (clue 7).  The second boy can not be at position 4 (clue 6).  The earliest position that the third boy could occupy is position 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 4.
B) If boys are at positions 1 (a corner) and 25 (clue 7), then a boy would have to be at either position 7 or 22 (clue 9).  In either case, more than three boys would not be along the edge of the picture, violating clue 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 1.  Boys must occupy: 7 and 22 (clue 9).  Girls must occupy: 6, 14, 15, and 23.
C) For three boys to be in the first row, the second boy must occupy: 5 (which also satisfies clue 6).  A girl must occupy 12.  Per clue 8, a boy must occupy: 13.  A girl must occupy: 20.  To avoid violating clue 5, boys must occupy: 8 and 21.  A girl must occupy: 9.
D) Clues 8 and 9 have now been satisfied, and 16 of the 28 positions have been filled.  To satisfy clues 1 through 7, the last 12 positions can be filled in four different ways.  However, only one of those ways will satisfy clue 10.  In the three ways that do not work, the boy that borders a unique number of girls is located at an odd position.
Step A       Step B       Step C       Step D
xxxGxxx      GxxGxGB      GxxGBGB      GBGGBGB
xxxxxxx      xxxxxxG      BGxxGBG      BGBGGBG
xxxxxxx      Gxxxxxx      GxxxxGB      GBGGGGB
xxxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGBGBGG
The boys in the first row border (3, 4, 2) girls.
The boys in the second row border (3, 6, 5) girls.
The boys in the third row border (4, 4) girls.
The boys in the fourth row border (2, 4, 5) girls.
The only boy that borders a unique number of girls is the boy who borders six girls, which is at position 10.  Kevin is at position 10.
Response: Final answer: 10

Question:
Consider a grid of size 4 x 4 (i.e. sixteen squares), where all squares should get a color. The colored grid should meet the following conditions:
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?
Hint: Start by placing the blues.
Human Solution:
There are multiple possible answers. Just check that the conditions in the original problem statement hold: 
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?

One possible arrangement:
W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Response:
First observe what the condition
“no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical or diagonal line’’
really means.  
For any one colour every two of its squares must

• lie in different rows,  
• lie in different columns, and  
• lie in different north-east/south-west as well as different north-west/south-east diagonals.

In other words, each separate colour must occupy the squares of a set of “non-attacking queens’’ on the 4 × 4 board.  
With that in mind we build the five required sets one after another.

1.  The 4-queen problem on a 4 × 4 board has the well–known solution  

   (1,2), (2,4), (3,1), (4,3).  
   Put the four blue squares there.

2.  We need three red squares, again mutually non-attacking.  
   A convenient triple that does not disturb the blues is  

   (1,4), (2,1), (3,3).  

3.  List the still empty squares.  
   From them pick three that are in distinct rows, columns and diagonals:  

   (1,1), (2,3), (4,2).  
   Colour these white.

4.  Six empty squares remain.  
   The triple  

   (1,3), (3,2), (4,4)  

   satisfies the same non-attacking conditions, so colour them green.

5.  The last three empty squares are then  

   (2,2), (3,4), (4,1).  
   They also lie in different rows, columns and diagonals, so colour them yellow.

The complete coloured board is therefore

            column →      1     2     3     4
           row
             1          White  Blue  Green  Red
             2          Red    Yellow White  Blue
             3          Blue   Green  Red    Yellow
             4          Yellow White  Blue   Green

Check.

• Every row and every column contains five different colours.  
• For each of the five colours all its squares lie in distinct rows, columns,
  NW-SE diagonals (constant row−column) and NE-SW diagonals (constant row+column).  
  Hence no colour is repeated on any horizontal, vertical or diagonal line.

The required arrangement therefore works, and it uses precisely

Blue   4 squares  
Red    3 squares  
White  3 squares  
Green  3 squares  
Yellow 3 squares.

Final answer: one such colouring is  

Row 1 : White, Blue, Green, Red  
Row 2 : Red, Yellow, White, Blue  
Row 3 : Blue, Green, Red, Yellow  
Row 4 : Yellow, White, Blue, Green.

Question:
I woke up late that morning to welcome a bright sunny day after a long and hectic week. It was a holiday and I was determined to spend the day playing cards with my friend Tweeto. Tweeto's favorite card game was the Romankachi card game.
The rules of the game are as follows :-
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
We started off with 5 cards each and I served in the first round.
At the end of three rounds if I had exactly 4 cards then which of the following statements must be true:-
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement is true. One or more statements may be true.
Hint: First, think about what possible results could lead to you having 4 cards?
Human Solution:
Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Response:
Let  

Iₙ , Tₙ  = the numbers of cards I and Tweeto possess after round n  
( I₀ = 5 , T₀ = 5 ), and let the ordered triple (W₁ ,W₂ ,W₃) record the
winners of the three rounds.

Card‐changes produced by one round (with respect to the server)

  server wins → server +2 , receiver –2  
  receiver wins → server –1 , receiver +1  

Consequently, for my own total the possible single–round changes are  

 +2  (I serves and wins)  
 –1  (I serves and loses)  
 +1  (I receives and wins)  
 –2  (I receives and loses)

The sum of the three changes must be –1, because I finish with 4 cards.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Showing Tweeto must win exactly two rounds (statement A).

Assume Tweeto wins k rounds.

•  k = 0 (I wins all three).  
 Every round gives me +2 or +1, so the total change is ≥ +3 — impossible.

•  k = 1.  
 Since at least one of my wins would be as server (+2),
 my total change would be (+2) + (another non-negative change) –1 ≥ 0 — impossible.

•  k = 3.  
 I would lose three times, so the largest total change I could suffer is  
 (–1) + (–2) + (–2) = –5 < –1; there is no way to end exactly at –1.

Therefore the only feasible value is k = 2 : Tweeto must win exactly two rounds.
Statement A is unavoidable.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Determining the winner of the third round (statement C).

Let X₁ , X₂ , X₃ be my round-by-round changes; we already know  
X₁ + X₂ + X₃ = –1.

Suppose I were to win the third round.

 •  If I served in round 3, X₃ = +2, forcing X₁ + X₂ = –3.  
  That would mean one round with –1 (I serving and losing)
  and one with –2 (I receiving and losing).  
  But after losing round 1, I would become receiver in round 2,
  so both negative changes cannot occur in the required way. Impossible.

 •  If I received in round 3, X₃ = +1, so X₁ + X₂ = –2.  
  The only way to obtain –2 with two values from {+2, +1, –1, –2}
  is (–1, –1).  That needs me to be server and loser in both earlier rounds,
  contradicting the fact that the winner serves next. Impossible.

Hence I cannot win round 3; Tweeto must win it.
Statement C is also unavoidable.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Was I obliged to win the first round? (statement B)

Two concrete admissible sequences of play show otherwise.

(i)  Winners (I , T , T)  

 Round 1: I serves & wins → I: 5→7  
 Round 2: I serves & loses → I: 7→6  
 Round 3: T serves & wins → I: 6→4

(ii) Winners (T , I , T)  

 Round 1: I serves & loses → I: 5→4  
 Round 2: T serves & loses  → I: 4→5  
 Round 3: I serves & loses → I: 5→4

Both finish with me on 4 cards, yet I win the first round only in (i).
So statement B is not necessary.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion

Statements that must be true:  A and C.

Final answer: A and C

Question:
Phil Fegit was sitting in his bedroom watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of MADADIA.  The water had caused floods throughout the town and water over six feet deep had forced people to abandon the downstairs of their homes and they had to retreat to the upstairs rooms. The yearly Kebab harvest had been washed away as the downpour had continued unabated for a full month.
Just at that moment Phil's wife, Norma, walked into the bedroom and he commented upon the rain. She replied that she could really care less. No matter how much Phil tried to stress the importance of the rain falling in Madadia, she refused to take it seriously.
How come?
Human Solution:
Phil was watching a news report about his home town on TV, he had recently moved away from the area and it was sunny where he was.
His wife wasn't from Madadia, hence she didn't care what happened there.
Response:
Nothing Phil was talking about was really happening – it was only happening on the screen of the computer game he was playing (or a television report he was watching).  
Phil, sitting upstairs in the bedroom, was “watching” the town of Madadia in a simulation: month–long rain, six-foot floods, even a fanciful “kebab harvest” being washed away.  Norma knew perfectly well that it was only a game/film and therefore of no consequence to them, so she quite rightly “could really care less.”

Question:
There were 9 portraits of animals (bear, cat, dog, hamster, horse, lion, monkey, mouse, and tiger) on a wall of a museum.  As I was studying them, I tripped and fell into the wall and they all fell down. I have to get them back up on the wall in the correct order before I get into some serious trouble.  I only remember a couple of things about the order of the portraits.  Can you help me figure out the order of the portraits using the clues I remember about them?
They were displayed as follows:
Note: The Letter and Numbers in the graph are labels for their corresponding rows.
...........A...............B.............C
1    _________ l _________ l _________
2    _________ l _________ l _________
3    _________ l _________ l _________
Clues:
1.  The bear is in the same row as the hamster.
2.  Two portraits in both rows 3 and C have two animals that start with the same letter.
3.  The horse is in the same row as the monkey.
4.  The dog is in 2A.
5.  Either the lion or the tiger is below the cat.
6.  The monkey is either above or below the dog.
7.  The dog is not next to the tiger.
Hint: Monkey, mouse, hamster, horse are the only two pairs with same letter. Focus on this
Human Solution:
bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Response:
The portraits must be arranged as follows.

Row 1: 1A Bear 1B Cat 1C Hamster  
Row 2: 2A Dog 2B Lion 2C Tiger  
Row 3: 3A Monkey 3B Mouse 3C Horse  

Verification of every clue  
1. Bear and Hamster share Row 1. ✔  
2. Row 3 has Monkey & Mouse (both “M”); Column C has Hamster & Horse (both “H”). ✔  
3. Horse is in the same row as Monkey (Row 3). ✔  
4. Dog is at 2A. ✔  
5. Lion (not Tiger) is directly below Cat (Cat at 1B, Lion at 2B). ✔  
6. Monkey is below the Dog (Dog 2A, Monkey 3A). ✔  
7. Dog (2A) is not next to Tiger (which is at 2C, not 2B). ✔  

All nine portraits are placed and every clue is satisfied.

Question:
In the purely fictitious land of Fiddledeboox, the Minister of Finance emerged from a top-level meeting.   Reporters had gathered to hear his announcement about either an increase or a decrease in either wages, subsidies or tax levels.
It was widely known that this Minister [M] told the truth to reporters [R] only once in every three statements.
M:  Well, I can tell you that it's about subsidies.
R:  Are they going down again?
M:  Nothing is going down.
R:  So it's good news for the people?
M:  Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.
While others jostled to ask the next question, one logically minded newshound was already leaving with the hot headline news.
From the Minister's three statements above, can you also deduce the truth?
Hint:
Assume each statement, in turn, to be true.  Then examine the truth or otherwise of the others.
Or check the statements in the light of each of the six possibilities.
Human Solution:
It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Response:
Let  

S  =  “subsidies are going down”,  
W  =  “wages are going up”,  
T  =  “taxes are going up”,  
and let K  =  “the announcement is about subsidies”.  

The Minister makes exactly three remarks to the reporters and, by habit, tells
the truth in exactly one of them.

The three remarks

1. “It’s about subsidies.”                ⇔ K  
2. “Nothing is going down.” – spoken in answer to  “Are subsidies going down?”  
  This is clearly the denial of S, so          ⇔ ¬S  
3. “Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.”  
  Ignoring the courteous “Of course”, the factual part is  
                         ⇔ S ∨ W

Exactly one of K , ¬S , S∨W is true.

Step 1.  The first remark cannot be the single true one.  
Assume K is true.  Then both other remarks are false, so

  ¬S is false  ⇒  S is true,  
  S∨W is false ⇒  S is false (and W is false).

Contradiction.  Hence K is false; the announcement is NOT about subsidies.

Step 2.  Decide which of the remaining two remarks is true.

•  If the third remark S∨W were true, then (because K is false) the second
   remark ¬S would be false, i.e. S true.  But with S true the subject really
   is a change in subsidies, contradicting K false.  Impossible.

Therefore the third remark is false and the second remark is the sole true
statement.

Consequences of “¬S” being the only truth

 a)  ¬S is true  ⇒  subsidies are NOT going down.  
 b)  S∨W is false  ⇒  S is false and W is false  (subsidies not down and no wage rise).  
 c)  The subject is not subsidies  (K false).

The decree must therefore concern the only remaining item, taxes.  
Since nothing is “going down” (¬S was true and wages stay level), the tax
change cannot be a reduction; it must be an increase.

Thus the logically-minded reporter could already file the headline:

 Fiddledeboox to raise taxes.

Final answer: The Minister’s single true statement was that “nothing is going down”; the announcement is not about subsidies or a wage rise – it is a tax increase.

Question: There are 2008 eggs lying in front of you. I am also with you waiting to start the game. The goal of the game is to be the person to take that very last egg (or eggs) to win. You and I can each only take between 1 and 100 eggs at a time. You go first. How many eggs must you take initially in order to always win (assuming we both play perfectly)?
Hint: By a perfect game, that means over any two turns, the sum of the number of eggs  you and I take is the same (except of course, excluding the initial move you make).
Human Solution:
89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Response:
At each turn a player may take any whole number of eggs from 1 up to 100, and the player who removes the last egg(s) wins.  
For this standard “take-away” game the key fact is:

If, just after your move, the number of eggs left on the table is a multiple of 101 (= 100 + 1), then no matter what your opponent does you can always reply so as to restore a multiple of 101. Consequently, the positions with a multiple of 101 eggs are losing positions for the player who must move, and every other position is winning.

Why?  
• Suppose you leave a multiple of 101, say 101 k, for your opponent.  
• Whatever number x (1 ≤ x ≤ 100) the opponent now removes, the pile becomes 101 k − x.  
• You can then take 101 − x eggs (still between 1 and 100) and leave  
 (101 k − x) − (101 − x) = 101 (k − 1),  
another multiple of 101.  
Thus after every pair of moves exactly 101 eggs disappear, and you keep handing your opponent the losing multiples of 101 until none remain—meaning you have just taken the last egg(s).

Therefore, to guarantee a win with perfect play, your very first move must turn the initial pile into a multiple of 101.

The pile starts with 2008 eggs. 2008 divided by 101 leaves a remainder of 89:

2008 = 19·101 + 89.

So you must remove exactly 89 eggs, leaving 1919 = 19·101 eggs, a losing position for your opponent. From then on, each time your opponent takes x eggs you reply with 101 − x eggs, and you will inevitably take the final egg(s).

Final answer: 89

Question:
There are 3 numbers 0-9.
Eric knows the product and says, "I know the numbers."
Then, everyone is told that one digit is exactly one greater than another.
Then, Luke is told one of the numbers and says, "Eric lied."
Then you are told the numbers add up to 11.
What are the numbers?
Hint: There are only so many combinations if two of the digits must be adjacent...
Human Solution:
0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.
Response:
Let the three (not-necessarily–distinct) digits be a,b,c with  
a+b+c = 11 … (1)  
and with one digit exactly one greater than another … (2)

Step 1.  Use (1) and (2).

List all unordered triples of digits whose sum is 11 and which contain two consecutive
numbers:

0,5,6  1,2,8  2,3,6  2,4,5  3,4,4             (3)

Step 2.  Interpret the statements.

•  Eric first saw only the product P = abc and immediately announced  
  “I know the numbers.”  
  Whether or not the statement is true, it means Eric claimed that from P
  he could single out one triple.

•  Afterwards everybody heard condition (2).  
  Luke was then shown one of the three digits and declared
  “Eric lied.”  
  Luke could say this with certainty only if, given the digit he saw and
  condition (2), every compatible triple has a product that is shared by
  more than one triple (so knowing the product would not identify the
  numbers).  

Step 3.  Examine each candidate of (3) in the light of Luke’s
possibility of being shown one of its digits.

(a) 1,2,8  
    If Luke is shown 1 (or 2) he knows that (1,1,2) satisfies (2) and has the
    unique product 2, so Eric might have been able to know the
    numbers.  Luke could not be certain Eric lied.  Reject.

(b) 2,3,6  
    If Luke is shown 2 the same triple (1,1,2) is still possible.
    Luke again could not be certain.  Reject.

(c) 2,4,5  
    If Luke is shown 4 (or 5) the triple (4,5,7) satisfies (2) and has the
    unique product 140 (no other three digits 0–9 multiply to 140),
    so Luke could not be sure.  Reject.

(d) 3,4,4  
    If Luke is shown 4 the same argument with (4,5,7) applies.  Reject.

(e) 0,5,6  
    If Luke is shown 0 he can deduce that the
    product is 0 (every triple containing 0 has product 0),
    and product 0 is produced by many different triples,
    so Eric certainly could not have identified the numbers from the
    product alone; hence Eric’s claim must be false.
    Luke can therefore state with certainty that “Eric lied.”
    This candidate passes Luke’s test.

Step 4.  Verify consistency.

For the triple (0,5,6):

•  Sum is 11 (0+5+6).  
•  Two digits are consecutive (5 and 6).  
•  Product is 0, so Eric’s claim “I know the numbers” is indeed false.  
•  If Luke was shown the digit 0, his deduction and statement are
  exactly as described.

No other triple meets all requirements, so the digits must be

0, 5 and 6.

Final answer: 0, 5, 6

Question:
What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
Hint: Think mathematically.
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
Assign to each letter its position in the alphabet (A = 1, B = 2, … , Z = 26).

Compute, column by column, the difference (Top – Bottom):

1) O(15) – I(9) = 6 ⇒ 6th letter = F  
2) Q(17) – J(10) = 7 ⇒ 7th letter = G  
3) L(12) – F(6) = 6 ⇒ 6th letter = F  
4) H(8) – E(5) = 3 ⇒ 3rd letter = C  
5) R(18) – Q(17) = 1 ⇒ 1st letter = A

The first four columns match the given result row, confirming the rule.  
Therefore, the missing fifth letter is A.

Final answer: A

Question:
A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Response:
Al is questioned first.  
He is told only one letter of the password, yet he can at once name the word.  
Therefore his letter must occur in a single one of the five candidate words;  
otherwise at least two words would still be possible to him.  
Letters that appear in just one candidate word are

H (only in HOE) R (only in OAR) P, D (only in PAD) V (only in VAT).

So the password is one of the four words

HOE OAR PAD VAT      (TOE is impossible).

––––––––––––––––––––––  
Ben is questioned next.  
He too now knows the list, his own letter, and the fact that Al was able to
identify the word from a unique‐to‐that‐word letter.

• If Ben’s letter is O, the words that contain it are HOE, OAR, TOE.  
  Knowing Al’s letter was unique rules out TOE (it has none), but leaves both
  HOE and OAR, so Ben could not be sure.  
• If his letter is A, the words are OAR, PAD, VAT – all three still possible.  
• If his letter is D or P (unique to PAD) he would know the word immediately.  
• If his letter is T, the words are TOE and VAT; TOE is impossible because Al’s
  letter was unique, so he would know the word is VAT.  
• If his letter is E, the words are HOE and TOE; TOE is again impossible, so he
  would know the word is HOE.

Hence Ben can answer “Yes” only when the password is

HOE (Ben has E), PAD (Ben has P or D), or VAT (Ben has T).  
So OAR is now eliminated.

––––––––––––––––––––––  
Carl is questioned last.  
Let us look at each of the remaining possibilities.

1.  Suppose the password were PAD.  
    For Al and Ben to have identified it, they must have received the two
    unique letters P and D, leaving Carl with A.  
    But with the single letter A Carl would still see two possibilities
    (PAD and VAT) and could not be certain.  
    So PAD is impossible.

2.  Suppose the password were VAT.  
    Al must have had V.  
    Ben could have answered “Yes” only if he had T (otherwise he would still
    face three possibilities).  
    That again leaves Carl with A, and, as before, A alone does not tell him
    whether the word is VAT or PAD.  
    So VAT is impossible.

3.  The only word left is HOE.  
    Al’s unique letter is H.  
    For Ben to have answered “Yes” he must have had E (with O he could not
    have decided between HOE and OAR after learning that Al’s letter was
    unique).  
    Therefore Carl’s letter is O, and after hearing Ben’s “Yes” he can
    conclude the word must be HOE – exactly as the story says.

All conditions are satisfied only when the password is

HOE.

Final answer: HOE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for R, U, O, N, or V
? stands for U, D, L, W, or J
@ stands for A, G, P, E, or Y
; stands for O, M, I, C, or S
The four letter code word, @!;?, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Morality
Human Solution: Good and Evil.
Response: Final answer: GOOD and EVIL

Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
Hint: Calendar differences?
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
Adam, Ben and Cyril did not come into the world in successive years of the same era.  
The numbers 1309, 1310 and 1311 belong to three different calendars that have all been in use in Jerusalem:

• Jewish calendar (Anno Mundi, A.M.) – year 1 = 3761 BCE  
• Christian calendar (Anno Domini, A.D.) – year 1 = the traditionally assigned year of the Nativity  
• Muslim calendar (Anno Hegirae, A.H.) – year 1 = 622 CE, the year of the Hijra

Take, for example, the following assignment.

• Adam was born in the Jewish year 1309 A.M.  
  1309 A.M. = 3761 BCE – 1308 = about 2452 BCE.  
  If he lived a little over sixty years, he died around 2390 BCE.

• Cyril was born in the Christian year 1311 A.D.  
  That is 1311 CE.  Living more than sixty years, he died sometime after 1371 CE.

• Ben was born in the Muslim year 1310 A.H.  
  1310 A.H. begins in 1892 CE and ends in 1893 CE.  Ben, living more than sixty years, died after 1953 CE.

Thus the three lives are separated by many centuries:

Adam’s life finished some three-and-a-half millennia before Cyril was born, and Cyril died more than five centuries before Ben was born.  
Although all three men were born on the same street and spent their entire lifetimes there, their lifetimes never overlapped, so their paths could not possibly have crossed.

Final answer: The “years” 1309, 1310 and 1311 are from three different calendars (Jewish, Christian and Muslim); the men therefore lived in widely separated epochs, so their lives never overlapped and they could never meet.

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: In music...
Human Solution: Forte and Piano.
Response: Final answer: piano and forte

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Law
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response:
To decode the five-symbol “word” */+-= we have to choose, for every position, a letter belonging to the set assigned to that symbol.  
(The same symbol may be read differently on two separate “translations,” so two different words can come from one string of symbols.)

Symbol → allowed letters  
*  → B, O, P, F, C  
/  → F, N, H, E, R  
+  → D, G, I, M, A  
–  → E, O, L, C, W  
=  → J, K, U, R, S  

1.  Start with the first symbol “*”.  A natural five-letter English word whose first letter belongs to {B,O,P,F,C} and that might have an opposite is CHAOS (C H A O S).  
    • C is allowed for *, H for /, A for +, O for –, and S for =, so CHAOS is a legal decoding.

2.  Look for its opposite of five letters.  ORDER (O R D E R) is the standard antonym.  
    • O is allowed for *, R for /, D for +, E for –, and R for =, so ORDER is also a legal decoding.

3.  No other common pair of exact antonyms meets all the letter-set restrictions for each position.  Hence the unique pair of opposite words encoded by */+-= is

CHAOS and ORDER.

Final answer: CHAOS and ORDER

Question:
runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
Hint: Look within the spellings...
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Response:
A runway is the place in which an airplane “belongs,”  
just as a cinema is the place in which a film “belongs.”  

Following the same pattern, an answer “belongs” in a question.  

Therefore  

runway : cinema :: answer : question.  

Final answer: question

Question:
John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade.
