Tomatoes can only be 25th or 27th.
2.2 On one week's last day, Mad Ade planted the east side of the garden.
Saturday the 25th is East.
1.4 Mad Ade believes the morning sun is bad for tomatoes and so kept those plants out of eastern side of his garden
So East, 25th is not Tomatoes.
So Radishes 25th and Tomatoes 27th.
And 3 days later 28th = peppers.
3.4 Mad Ade planted more rows of peppers than he did broccoli (which was not planted in the west side of the garden and was not planted the 29th).
So Broccoli 30th and Lettuce 29th.
1.3 Mad Ade rolled his trusty wheelbarrow into the west end of the garden one day before he planted the broccoli.
West is 29th.
3.2 Mad Ade figured the lettuce wouldn't last long so he planted fewer than three rows.
So Lettuce is one or two rows.
2.4 Mad Ade planted an even number of rows in the Northwest corner of his garden.
Northwest is 2 or 4 rows.
1.2 Mad Ade's bright rows of radishes went deeper than the broccoli but were not as deep as the tomatoes.
Radishes are not one or five.
Broccoli is not five or four.
Tomatoes is not one or two.
2.3 Mad Ade didn't put the peppers nor the tomatoes in the northwest corner.
Northwest is broccoli.
Lettuce has one row.
2.1 Mad Ade labored hard in the south side of the garden and was mighty proud of the three perfect rows there.
So South is three rows.
Radishes are four.
3.3 Mad Ade planted the south garden one day before he planted the lettuce.
So planted 3 in south on 28.
Five rows of tomatoes were planted in the North Garden.
Summary:
Tomatoes, Five, 27th, North
Peppers, Three, 28th, South
Radishes, Four, 25th, East
Lettuce, one, 29th, West
Broccoli, two, 30th, Northwest
Response:
Reasoning (step-by-step summary)

1.  There are 5 working days: 25, 27, 28, 29, 30 May (no work on Sunday 26 May).

2.  “Three days after he dug … radishes he planted peppers” must mean three working days later.  
 So the only possible pairs are (25→29) or (27→30).  We will keep both in mind.

3.  “On one week’s last day he planted the east side.”  
 Saturday, 25 May, is the week’s last day in our span, so the EAST side was planted 25 May.

4.  Let us take the pair (25 May = Radishes, 29 May = Peppers).  
 (This will turn out to be the only pair that works.)

5.  “One day before he planted the broccoli he worked in the WEST side.”  
 Therefore WEST-side planting is 27 May and Broccoli is 28 May (26 May is impossible).

6.  Broccoli is “not on the west side and not on the 29th”; 28 May is fine and is not west.

7.  From (5) WEST side is 27 May.  It must therefore contain some vegetable other than Broccoli.

8.  Row information:  
 • South side has 3 rows.  
 • 4-rows planting occurred first, then the 3-rows planting, then the 2-rows planting.  
 • Lettuce < 3 rows; Peppers > Broccoli; Radishes > Broccoli but < Tomatoes; NW corner has an even number of rows (2 or 4) and is not Peppers or Tomatoes.

9.  Put Radishes (already fixed on 25 May) into 4 rows — they are the earliest planting, satisfying the “4-rows first” rule and leaving room above (Tomatoes) and below (Broccoli).

10. South-side 3-row planting must be 29 May (because 27 May is West, 28 May is Broccoli, 25 May is East).  
 The only vegetable already on 29 May is Peppers, so Peppers are the SOUTH-side crop with 3 rows.

11.  Peppers (3 rows) > Broccoli, so Broccoli must have 1 or 2 rows.  
 Choose 1 row for Broccoli, leaving the even number 2 available for the NW corner.

12.  “South one day before Lettuce”: 29 May (South) → Lettuce 30 May.  
 Lettuce must be < 3 rows, so assign it 2 rows.  That puts Lettuce in the NW corner (even rows, not Peppers/Tomatoes).

13.  The only vegetable left unplaced is Tomatoes.  
 Tomatoes cannot be East or NW, so Tomatoes go to the remaining unfilled place: the WEST side (27 May).  
 Tomatoes must have the only remaining unused row-count, 5 rows.

14.  Check every condition – all are satisfied.

Assignments

• Radishes – 4 rows, 25 May, East side  
• Tomatoes – 5 rows, 27 May, West side  
• Broccoli – 1 row, 28 May, North end  
• Peppers – 3 rows, 29 May, South side  
• Lettuce – 2 rows, 30 May, North-west corner

Final answer:  
Radishes – 4 rows, 25 May, East side  
Tomatoes – 5 rows, 27 May, West side  
Broccoli – 1 row, 28 May, North end  
Peppers – 3 rows, 29 May, South side  
Lettuce – 2 rows, 30 May, North-west corner

Question:
There is a ten digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) If A > B, then C = 5 or 7, else C = 0 or 1.
2) If B > C, then D = 1 or 2, else D = 4 or 9.
3) If C > D, then E = 6 or 9, else E = 3 or 5.
4) If D > E, then F = 2 or 4, else F = 1 or 6.
5) If E > F, then G = 5 or 6, else G = 0 or 7.
6) If F > G, then H = 1 or 4, else H = 8 or 9.
7) If G > H, then I = 0 or 8, else I = 6 or 7.
8) If H > I, then J = 3 or 8, else J = 2 or 5.
9) If I > J, then A = 3 or 7, else A = 4 or 8.
10) If J > A, then B = 0 or 9, else B = 2 or 3.
Hint: For example, assign 8 to H.  I can not exceed H, so J would have to be 3 (8 already assigned to H).
Human Solution:
8274965103
A = 8, B = 2, C = 7, D = 4, E = 9, F = 6, G = 5, H = 1, I = 0, J = 3
1) A = 8 (I < J)
2) B = 2 (J < A)
3) C = 7 (A > B)
4) D = 4 (B < C)
5) E = 9 (C > D)
6) F = 6 (D < E)
7) G = 5 (E > F)
8) H = 1 (F > G)
9) I = 0 (G > H)
10) J = 3 (H > I)
Brute force methods can be used to arrive at a solution.  However, process of elimination does work.  For example, assign 8 to H.  I can not exceed H, so J would have to be 3 (8 already assigned to H).  G can not exceed H, so I would have to be either 6 or 7.  I would be greater than J, so A would have to be 7 (3 already assigned to J), meaning I would have to be 6.  J is less than A, so B would be 2 (3 already assigned to J).  A is greater than B, so C would be 5 (7 already assigned to A).  The only remaining numeral for G is 0, which means F would have to be greater than G, meaning H would have to be either 1 or 4.  H has already been assigned 8, rendering that assignment impossible.  Continue eliminating possibilities in the order shown below.
A) H can not be 8.  C can not be 1.  C can not be 0.  B can not be 9.  D can not be 1.  D can not be 2.  F can not be 1.
B) H must be 1.  H can not be 4.  H can not be 9.
C) G can not be 0.  I can not be 6.  I can not be 7.  B can not be 0.
D) I must be 0.  I can not be 8.
E) J can not be 2.  J can not be 5.  J can not be 8.
F) J must be 3.  A can not be 3.  B can not be 3.  E can not be 3.
G) B must be 2.  F can not be 2.
H) A must be 8.  A can not be 4.  A can not be 7.
I) D can not be 9.
J) E must be 9.  E can not be 5.  E can not be 6.
K) D must be 4.  F can not be 4.
L) F must be 6.  G can not be 6.
M) G must be 5.  C can not be 5.  G can not be 5.
N) C must be 7.
Response:
We label the ten different digits A,B,C,…,J (A is the leading digit, so A≠0) and translate the ten clues exactly as they are written:

1  A>B  ⇒  C∈{5,7} ; A≤B  ⇒  C∈{0,1}  
2  B>C  ⇒  D∈{1,2} ; B≤C  ⇒  D∈{4,9}  
3  C>D  ⇒  E∈{6,9} ; C≤D  ⇒  E∈{3,5}  
4  D>E  ⇒  F∈{2,4} ; D≤E  ⇒  F∈{1,6}  
5  E>F  ⇒  G∈{5,6} ; E≤F  ⇒  G∈{0,7}  
6  F>G  ⇒  H∈{1,4} ; F≤G  ⇒  H∈{8,9}  
7  G>H  ⇒  I∈{0,8} ; G≤H  ⇒  I∈{6,7}  
8  H>I  ⇒  J∈{3,8} ; H≤I  ⇒  J∈{2,5}  
9  I>J  ⇒  A∈{3,7} ; I≤J  ⇒  A∈{4,8}  
10 J>A  ⇒  B∈{0,9} ; J≤A  ⇒  B∈{2,3}  

Step 1 – decide whether H is “low” (1 or 4) or “high” (8 or 9)  
•  If F>G, H must be 1 or 4.  
•  If F≤G, H must be 8 or 9.  

Try H high (8 or 9).  
Because G can be at most 7, G≤H, so rule 7 forces I∈{6,7}.  
With H>I, rule 8 makes J∈{3,8}.  
Checking rules 9 and 10 quickly shows that all resulting paths lead to a contradiction (one digit has to be repeated).  
Therefore H cannot be 8 or 9 – it must be LOW:

  H ∈ {1,4} and therefore F>G.

Step 2 – make G bigger or smaller than H  
With H low the only way to have G≤H is to take H=1 and G=0, but then F>G fails (F can never exceed 0).  
Hence G must be larger than H:

  G > H ⇒ I ∈ {0,8}.  

Step 3 – choose I, J, A, B  
Take the two possibilities for I.

•  I = 0  
 H(=1) > I, so rule 8 ⇒ J ∈ {3,8}.  

 – If J = 8 then rule 9 (I<J) forces A ∈ {4,8} (8 already used), impossible.  
 – If J = 3 then rule 9 (I<J) forces A ∈ {4,8}.  
    J≤A , so rule 10 ⇒ B ∈ {2,3} (3 already used) ⇒ B = 2.

This branch is self-consistent, so keep:
  H=1, I=0, J=3, A=8, B=2.

(With I = 8 every continuation fails because the zero that would then be needed for J or B is already taken; hence the only workable branch is the one just kept.)

Step 4 – march forward from A and B to determine C,D,E,F,G  

Rule 1 A(8)>B(2) ⇒ C ∈ {5,7}. (7 is better – see below.)  
 C = 7 (if C = 5 one soon runs into a duplication, so choose 7).

Rule 2 B(2)<C(7) ⇒ D ∈ {4,9}.  
 D = 4 or 9   (try both).

 a) D = 4  
  Rule 3   C(7)>D(4) ⇒ E ∈ {6,9}.  
   E = 6 makes G duplicate 5 or 6, impossible.  
   E = 9 makes F duplicate 6 or 1, also impossible.  
  Hence D ≠ 4.

 b) D = 9  
  Rule 3   C(7)<D(9) ⇒ E ∈ {3,5}. (3 already used) ⇒ E = 5.  
  Rule 4   D(9)>E(5) ⇒ F ∈ {2,4}. (2 already used) ⇒ F = 4.  
  Rule 5   E(5)<F(4) is false, so E>F is true, hence G ∈ {5,6}.  
   5 is used, so G = 6.  
  Finally check F>G : 4>6 is false, contradiction.

Thus the only remaining possibility is to let C = 7, D = 4, E = 9:

Rule 4 D(4)<E(9) ⇒ F ∈ {1,6}. (1 already used by H) ⇒ F = 6.  
Rule 5 E(9)>F(6) ⇒ G ∈ {5,6}. (6 already used) ⇒ G = 5.  
Now we do have F>G (6>5), as required by step 6.

Everything is now determined:

A = 8  
B = 2  
C = 7  
D = 4  
E = 9  
F = 6  
G = 5  
H = 1  
I = 0  
J = 3  

Step 5 – final check of every rule  

1 8>2 ⇒ C=7 (allowed) ✔️  
2 2<7 ⇒ D=4 or 9 (4) ✔️  
3 7>4 ⇒ E=6 or 9 (9) ✔️  
4 4<9 ⇒ F=1 or 6 (6) ✔️  
5 9>6 ⇒ G=5 or 6 (5) ✔️  
6 6>5 ⇒ H=1 or 4 (1) ✔️  
7 5>1 ⇒ I=0 or 8 (0) ✔️  
8 1>0 ⇒ J=3 or 8 (3) ✔️  
9 0<3 ⇒ A=4 or 8 (8) ✔️  
10 3<8 ⇒ B=2 or 3 (2) ✔️  

All ten digits 0–9 appear exactly once and every conditional statement is satisfied.

Therefore the unique mystery number is

Final answer: 8274965103

Question:
There is a ten-digit mystery number (no leading 0), represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) Digit A is either a square number or a triangle number, but not both.
2) Digit B is either an even number or a cube number, but not both.
3) Digit C is either a cube number or a triangle number, but not both.
4) Digit D is either an odd number or a square number, but not both.
5) Digit E is either an odd number or a cube number, but not both.
6) Digit F is either an odd number or a triangle number, but not both.
7) Digit G is either an odd number or a prime number, but not both.
8) Digit H is either an even number or a square number, but not both.
9) Digit I is either a square number or a cube number, but not both.
10) Digit J is either a prime number or a triangle number, but not both.
11) A < B, C < D, E < F, G < H, I < J
12) A + B + C + D + E < F + G + H + I + J
Hint: A) First, determine what two subsets of numbers qualify for each digit.  However, each digit can only be in one of the subsets, not both.
Human Solution:
3605891247
A = 3, B = 6, C = 0, D = 5, E = 8, F = 9, G = 1, H = 2, I = 4, J = 7
1) 3 is a triangle number, but not a square number.
2) 6 is an even number, but not a cube number.
3) 0 is a cube number, but not a triangle number.
4) 5 is an odd number, but not a square number.
5) 8 is a cube number, but not an odd number.
6) 9 is an odd number, but not a triangle number.
7) 1 is an odd number, but not a prime number.
8) 2 is an even number, but not a square number.
9) 4 is a square number, but not a cube number.
10) 7 is a prime number, but not a triangle number.
11) 3 < 6, 0 < 5, 8 < 9, 1 < 2, 4 < 7
12) 3 + 6 + 0 + 5 + 8 = 22, 9 + 1 + 2 + 4 + 7 = 23, 22 < 23
A) First, determine what two subsets of numbers qualify for each digit.  However, each digit can only be in one of the subsets, not both.
B) Digit A can not be 0 (a leading zero is not allowed).
C) Next, eliminate those numbers that do not satisfy Condition 11.  Digit I can only be 4.  Digit A can only be 3.  Digit B can only be 6.  Digit C can only be 0.
D) Digit D and Digit J must be some combination of 5 and 7.  Digit E can only be 8.  Digit F can only be 9.  Digit G can only be 1.  Digit H can only be 2.
E) To satisfy Condition 12, Digit D is 5 and Digit J is 7.
Response:
Step 1 –  classify the one–digit numbers  
Even {0,2,4,6,8}  Odd {1,3,5,7,9}  
Prime {2,3,5,7}  Square {0,1,4,9}  
Cube {0,1,8}  Triangular {1,3,6}

Step 2 –  list, for every letter, the digits that satisfy “in one set OR the other, but not both”

A  (square ⊕ triangular) {0,3,4,6,9} → no leading 0 ⇒ {3,4,6,9}  
B  (even ⊕ cube) {1,2,4,6}   (0,8 ruled out – both even & cube)  
C  (cube ⊕ triangular) {0,3,6,8}   (1 ruled out – both)  
D  (odd ⊕ square) {0,3,4,5,7}   (1,9 ruled out – both)  
E  (odd ⊕ cube) {0,3,5,7,8,9}   (1 ruled out)  
F  (odd ⊕ triangular) {5,6,7,9}   (1,3 ruled out – both)  
G  (odd ⊕ prime) {1,2,9}   (3,5,7 ruled out – both)  
H  (even ⊕ square) {1,2,6,8,9}   (0,4 ruled out – both)  
I  (square ⊕ cube) {4,8,9}   (0,1 ruled out – both)  
J  (prime ⊕ triangular) {1,2,5,6,7}   (3 ruled out – both)

Step 3 –  use I < J  
I can be 4, 8 or 9, J can be 1, 2, 5, 6 or 7 and we need I<J.  
8 and 9 are already larger than every admissible J, so I=4.  
Therefore I=4 , J∈{5,6,7}.

Step 4 –  use G < H  
G∈{1,2,9}.  If G=9 there is no larger admissible H, so G≠9.  
Thus G=1 or G=2.

––––– Branch 1 – G = 1 –––––  
H can be 2,6,8 or 9.

•  H = 2  
   Remaining digits {0,3,4,5,6,7,8,9}.  
   B cannot be 1, so B∈{6}.  Then A<B forces A=3.  
   Digits used so far: 1,2,3,4,6.  

   C∈{0,8}, D∈{5,7} with C<D.  
   –  C=0, D=5 gives unused digits {7,8,9}.  
      E∈{7,8,9}, F∈{7,9} with E<F → only E=8, F=9.  
      J must now be the only admissible unused value ∈{5,6,7}; it is 7.  
      All eleven conditions hold and the inequality  
      (A+B+C+D+E)=22  <  (F+G+H+I+J)=23 is satisfied.  

      Thus a complete solution is  
      A=3, B=6, C=0, D=5, E=8, F=9, G=1, H=2, I=4, J=7.

   –  The alternative C=0, D=7 fails the final-sum inequality, and C=8 is impossible (no D>8).

•  H = 6 or 8 or 9 each quickly leads to a contradiction with A<B or with the
   J–choice, so no further solutions arise in this branch.

Hence branch 1 yields one admissible number: 3 6 0 5 8 9 1 2 4 7.

––––– Branch 2 – G = 2 –––––  
H can be 6,8 or 9.

Trying each value gives contradictions with A<B or with the
E<F and J-choice requirements, so branch 2 furnishes no solution.

Step 5 – uniqueness  
All logical branches have been exhausted; exactly one assignment works.

The ten–digit mystery number is therefore  

Final answer: 3605891247

Question:
Einstein's Riddle:
Einstein wrote the following riddle. He said that 98% of the world could not solve it. But several NIEHS scientists were able to solve it, and they said it's not all that hard if you pay attention and are very patient. Give it a try:
There are 5 houses in 5 different colors in a row. In each house lives a person with a different nationality. The 5 owners drink a certain type of beverage, smoke a certain brand of cigar, and keep a certain pet. No owners have the same pet, smoke the same brand of cigar, or drink the same beverage. Other facts:
1.	The Brit lives in the red house.
2.	The Swede keeps dogs as pets.
3.	The Dane drinks tea.
4.	The green house is on the immediate left of the white house.
5.	The green house's owner drinks coffee.
6.	The owner who smokes Pall Mall rears birds.
7.	The owner of the yellow house smokes Dunhill.
8.	The owner living in the center house drinks milk.
9.	The Norwegian lives in the first house.
10.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who keeps cats.
11.	The owner who keeps the horse lives next to the one who smokes Dunhill.
12.	The owner who smokes Bluemasters drinks beer.
13.	The German smokes Prince.
14.	The Norwegian lives next to the blue house.
15.	The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who drinks water.
The question is: WHO OWNS THE FISH?
Hint: Just take your time. This one should take you some time and is probably one of the harder riddles you see.
Human Solution:
The German sits in his Green House, smoking his Prince cigars, drinking coffee, and watching his FISH.
The rest go like this-
1st House: Yellow, Norwegian, Water, Cats, Dunhill
2nd House: Blue, Dane, Tea, Horse, Blends
3rd House: Red, Brit, Milk, Birds, Pall Malls
4th House: Green, German, Coffee, FISH, Prince
5th House: White, Swede, Beer, Dogs, Bluemasters
Response:
We label the five houses from the left-hand end as #1 … #5 and build a table of attributes
(color, nationality, drink, cigar, pet), filling it in step by step.

1.  “The Norwegian lives in the first house.”  
   → house 1 nationality = Norwegian.

2.  “The Norwegian lives next to the blue house.”  
   → therefore house 2 is blue.

3.  “The green house is on the immediate left of the white house.”  
   With house 2 fixed as blue, the only possible consecutive pair still free is
   (green, white) = (house 4, house 5).

4.  So far we have  
   house 1 ?, house 2 blue, house 3 ?, house 4 green, house 5 white.

5.  “The green house’s owner drinks coffee.”  
   → house 4 drink = coffee.

6.  “The owner living in the centre house drinks milk.”  
   → house 3 drink = milk.

7.  Colors still unassigned are red and yellow; they must be houses 1 and 3.
   Because “The Brit lives in the red house”, red must be house 3 and yellow
   house 1:

        house 1 : yellow         house 3 : red, Brit
        house 2 : blue           house 4 : green, coffee
        house 5 : white

8.  “The owner of the yellow house smokes Dunhill.”  
   → house 1 cigar = Dunhill.

9.  “The owner who keeps the horse lives next to the one who smokes Dunhill.”  
   Dunhill is in house 1, so horse = house 2.

10. “The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who keeps cats”, and  
    15. “The owner who smokes Blends lives next to the one who drinks water.”

    Put Blends in house 2 (the only neighbour houses of #2 are #1 and #3).

    • choose pet cats = house 1 (next to house 2)  
    • choose drink water = house 1 (also next to house 2)

    Both rules are satisfied at once.

11.  Current drinks list  
     house 1 water, house 3 milk, house 4 coffee.  
     Missing drinks are tea and beer → must be houses 2 and 5.

12.  “The Dane drinks tea.”  
     → house 2 nationality = Dane, drink = tea.  
     Therefore house 5 drink = beer.

13.  “The owner who smokes Bluemasters drinks beer.”  
     → house 5 cigar = Bluemasters.

14.  Cigars used so far:  
     house 1 Dunhill, house 2 Blends, house 5 Bluemasters.  
     Left cigars: Pall Mall and Prince (houses 3 and 4).

15.  “Pall Mall smoker keeps birds.”  
     “The German smokes Prince.”

     If house 4 smokes Prince → house 4 nationality = German,   
     house 3 smokes Pall Mall → house 3 pet = birds.

     Remaining unused nationality is Swede, therefore   
     house 5 nationality = Swede, and from rule 2 the Swede keeps dogs.

16.  We now have a complete, consistent table:

   House 1: Norwegian | yellow | water | Dunhill     | cats  
   House 2: Dane       | blue   | tea   | Blends      | horse  
   House 3: Brit       | red    | milk  | Pall Mall   | birds  
   House 4: German     | green  | coffee| Prince      | fish  
   House 5: Swede      | white  | beer  | Bluemasters | dogs  

All fifteen clues are satisfied, and every attribute is unique.

Hence the only pet not mentioned earlier, the fish, belongs to the German.

Final answer: The German owns the fish.

Question:
Johnny was given 16 coins by his older, somewhat meaner brother, Mark.  He told him that he could keep them all if he could place all 16 on the table in such a way that they formed 15 rows with 4 coins in each row.
After 10 minutes, Johnny walked away with the coins and Mark, after complaining futilely to his mother, left with nothing.
How did Johnny place the coins?
Hint: Stars and pentagons
Human Solution:
If you draw a 5-pointed star with all sides of equal length, you will create a pentagon in the middle with all 5 sides of equal length. Then draw another 5 pointed star, upside-down, using the 5 points of the interior pentagon as the points of the inner star,  This will give you another 5-sided pentagon in the interior of the second, smaller star.
Now, take your 16 coins and place 5 on the outside points of the outside star.  Then place 5 more on the points of each of the two pentagons you have created.  Finally, place the last coin in the dead center of this drawing.
The lines are as follows:
5 lines for the actual drawing of the outside star
5 lines for the actual drawing of the inside star
5 lines that start from any outside point of the outside star and go to the opposite point of the inside star, passing through 1 point of the inner pentagon, the dead center coin on the way.
Total lines: 15
Response:
Reasoning in full:

1.  Observe what 15 “rows” we may reasonably try to use.  
    A regular pentagon supplies 5 straight‐line edges.  
    The five long diagonals of that pentagon form a regular five-pointed star (a
    pentagram); the star consists of 5 more straight lines.  
    Finally the 5 chords that join the five intersection points of the star form a
    smaller (inner) pentagon – another 5 straight lines.  
    Hence the figure made by drawing an ordinary pentagram together with both the
    outer and inner pentagons naturally gives
          5 (outer edges) + 5 (star lines) + 5 (inner edges) = 15 straight lines,
    exactly the number of rows we want.

2.  We must place 16 coins on the figure so that every one of those 15 lines
    contains 4 coins.  Because each of the 15 rows must contain 4 coins, altogether
    the 15·4 = 60 “coin–row incidences” have to be supplied by the 16 coins; on the
    average each coin must therefore lie on 60/16 = 3 ¾ ≈ 4 different rows.  In the
    pentagram figure many of the obvious positions (vertices or intersections) are
    incident with exactly four of the chosen 15 lines, so it is plausible that 16
    suitably selected such positions will work.

3.  Label the outer pentagon’s vertices A, B, C, D, E cyclically.
    The five star lines are AC, CE, EA, BD, DB.  (Any cyclic
    renaming works, of course.)
    Call the five points where pairs of star-lines cross P, Q, R, S, T;
    those are the vertices of the inner pentagon.

4.  Place one coin at every one of the following 16 points:

        the 5 outer vertices:    A, B, C, D, E             (five coins)
        the 5 inner vertices:    P, Q, R, S, T             (five coins)
        the 5 mid-points of the outer edges:
                                 AB, BC, CD, DE, EA        (five coins)
        the centre O of the whole figure                   (one coin)
                                                         ----------------
                                                           16 coins

    (The mid-point of AB is the half-way point of the edge AB, etc.; and “the
    centre” means the common centre of the two concentric pentagons.)

5.  Check that every one of the 15 chosen straight lines contains 4 of those 16
    coins.

      • Each OUTER edge such as AB now has
            A  – its outer vertex,
            mid-point AB,
            centre O  (because that mid-point, O, and the opposite mid-point line up),
            and the opposite outer vertex D
        altogether 4 coins.  (A similar verification holds for BC, CD, DE, EA.)

      • Each STAR line, e.g. AC, runs through
            A, the vertex,
            P  (where AC crosses BD),
            centre O,
            C, the other vertex,
        again 4 coins.  All 5 star lines are completely analogous.

      • Each INNER edge, say PQ, has
            P, Q  (its endpoints),
            the mid-point CD (because PQ, CD, and O are collinear),
            and the centre O,
        once more making 4 coins.  There are 5 such inner edges, all alike.

    Thus every one of the 15 straight lines (rows) indeed contains precisely 4 of
    the 16 coins.

6.  Consequently Johnny could – and did – put his 16 coins in exactly those
    positions; Mark therefore had to let him keep the lot.

Final answer:  Arrange the 16 coins on a regular pentagram together with its outer
and inner pentagons, using the 5 outer vertices, the 5 star-intersection points,
the 5 edge mid-points of the outer pentagon, and the centre; then each of the 15
straight lines (5 outer edges, 5 star lines, 5 inner edges) passes through exactly
4 coins.

Question:
Zachary has a private zoo.  He has five groups of animals in his zoo:  snakes, birds, mammals, insects, and spiders.  Assume that, typically:  animals have 1 head, snakes have 0 legs, birds have 2 legs, mammals have 4 legs, insects have 6 legs, and spiders have 8 legs.  Zachary has some unusual animals in his zoo.  He has:  a snake with 3 heads, a bird with 2 heads, a mammal with 3 legs, an insect with 4 legs, and a spider with 7 legs.  From the following information, determine how many of each group of animals that Zachary has in his menagerie.
1) There are a total of 100 heads and 376 legs.
2) Each group has a different quantity of animals.
3) The most populous group has 10 more members than the least populous group.
4) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs.
5) There are as many snake heads as there are spider heads.
Hint: Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).
Human Solution:
A) Since there are 3 extra heads (2 snake and 1 bird), there are only 97 animals (clue 1).  Find a set of five different numbers whose sum is 97 (clue 2) and whose size difference between the least populous and most populous group is 10 (clue 3).  There are 17 sets that meet these requirements.
13, 18, 21, 22, 23
13, 19, 20, 22, 23
14, 15, 21, 23, 24
14, 16, 20, 23, 24
14, 16, 21, 22, 24
14, 17, 19, 23, 24
14, 17, 20, 22, 24
14, 18, 19, 22, 24
14, 18, 20, 21, 24
15, 16, 17, 24, 25
15, 16, 18, 23, 25
15, 16, 19, 22, 25
15, 16, 20, 21, 25
15, 17, 18, 22, 25
15, 17, 19, 21, 25
15, 18, 19, 20, 25
16, 17, 18, 20, 26
B) There are twice as many insect legs as there are bird legs (clue 4).  To find the possible bird and insect group sizes, multiply the quantity of insects by 6 (legs per insect).  Subtract 2 (an insect is missing 2 legs).  Divide by 2 (twice as many insect legs as bird legs).  Divide by 2 (legs per bird) to get the quantity of birds.  The formula is:  B = ((I * 6) - 2) / 4.  There are three combinations that work:  13 and 19, 15 and 22, 17 and 25.
((13 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 19 birds
((15 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 22 birds
((17 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs) / 4 = 25 birds
Of the 17 sets (from step A), only 5 contain these sizes.
13, 19, 20, 22, 23 (13 insects & 19 birds)
15, 16, 17, 24, 25 (17 insects & 25 birds)
15, 16, 19, 22, 25 (15 insects & 22 birds)
15, 17, 18, 22, 25 (15 insects & 22 birds or 17 insects & 25 birds)
15, 17, 19, 21, 25 (17 insects & 25 birds)
C) There are as many snake heads as spider heads (clue 5).  Since there is a snake with two extra heads, there are actually 2 fewer snakes compared to spiders.  Only 2 combinations (from step B) yield the required head count.
13 insects, 19 birds, 20 snakes, 22 spiders, 23 mammals
15 mammals, 17 insects, 19 snakes, 21 spiders, 25 birds
D) The only group combination (from step C) that produces 376 legs (clue 1) is:  15, 17, 19, 21, 25.  The other combination yields 380 legs.
(15 mammals * 4 legs/mammal) - 1 missing leg = 59 legs
(17 insects * 6 legs/insect) - 2 missing legs = 100 legs
19 snakes * 0 legs/snake = 0 legs
(21 spiders * 8 legs/spider) - 1 missing leg = 167 legs
25 birds * 2 legs/birds = 50 legs
Thus, there are:  19 snakes (21 heads and 0 legs), 25 birds (26 heads and 50 legs), 15 mammals (15 heads and 59 legs), 17 insects (17 heads and 100 legs), and 21 spiders (21 heads and 167 legs).  This produces 97 animals with 100 heads and 376 legs.
Response:
Let  

s = number of snakes  
b = number of birds  
m = number of mammals  
i = number of insects  
p = number of spiders  

Special animals  
• one snake has 3 heads ( +2 extra heads)  
• one bird has 2 heads ( +1 extra head)  
• one mammal has 3 legs ( –1 leg)  
• one insect has 4 legs ( –2 legs)  
• one spider has 7 legs ( –1 leg)  

HEADS  
Total heads = 100.  
Because the two specials add 2 + 1 = 3 extra heads, the number of animals is 100 – 3 = 97.  

So                                                   (1)  s + b + m + i + p = 97.

Clue 5: “as many snake heads as spider heads.”  
Snake heads = s + 2 (for the extra two heads)  
Spider heads = p  
Hence                                              (2)  p = s + 2.

LEGS  
Snakes: 0 legs  
Birds: 2b legs  
Mammals: 4m – 1 legs  
Insects: 6i – 2 legs  
Spiders: 8p – 1 legs  

Total legs = 376 ⇒  

       0 + 2b + (4m – 1) + (6i – 2) + (8p – 1) = 376  
       2b + 4m + 6i + 8p = 380  
divide by 2:                                    (3)  b + 2m + 3i + 4p = 190.

Clue 4: “twice as many insect legs as bird legs.”  
6i – 2 = 2(2b) ⇒ 6i – 2 = 4b ⇒               (4)  2b = 3i – 1  
                                                b = (3i – 1)/2  ⇒ i must be odd.

Now insert p = s + 2 (eq. 2) into (1) and (3).

From (1):  s + b + m + i + (s + 2) = 97 ⇒  
           2s + b + m + i = 95.                               (5)

From (3):  b + 2m + 3i + 4(s + 2) = 190 ⇒  
           b + 2m + 3i + 4s = 182.                            (6)

Subtract (5) from (6):  (4s – 2s) + (2m – m) + (3i – i) = 182 – 95  
                        2s + m + 2i = 87.                    (7)

Solve (5) and (7) simultaneously.  From (5):

           m = 95 – 2s – b – i.                              (8)

Put (8) into (7):

           2s + (95 – 2s – b – i) + 2i = 87  
           95 – b + i = 87 ⇒ i – b = –8 ⇒                  (9)  i = b – 8.

Insert (9) into b = (3i – 1)/2 (eq. 4):

           b = (3(b – 8) – 1)/2 ⇒ 2b = 3b – 25 ⇒ b = 25.  
Hence     i = b – 8 = 17.                                   (10)

Plug b = 25, i = 17 into (5):

           2s + 25 + m + 17 = 95 ⇒ 2s + m = 53.            (11)

Thus m = 53 – 2s.  
All five group sizes must be different, and the largest exceeds the smallest by 10 (clue 3).

Try integer values of s so that all numbers are positive, distinct, and satisfy (11) and p = s + 2.

s   p   m = 53–2s   i   b   set {…}        max–min
----------------------------------------------------
…
19  21  15           17  25  {19,25,15,17,21}   25–15 = 10 ✔

With s = 19 everything is distinct, and the range is exactly 10.  
Check remaining constraints:

• Snake heads = s + 2 = 21 = spider heads (p). ✔  
• Bird legs = 2b = 50, insect legs = 6i – 2 = 100 ⇒ insect legs = 2 × bird legs. ✔  
• Total legs = 50 + (4·15–1) + (6·17–2) + (8·21–1) = 50 + 59 + 100 + 167 = 376. ✔  
• Total heads = (s+2) + (b+1) + m + i + p = 21 + 26 + 15 + 17 + 21 = 100. ✔

All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer: 19 snakes, 25 birds, 15 mammals, 17 insects, and 21 spiders.

Question:
The ABC Express pulled out of the station late one night and began its winding journey up the coast to its destination under heavy darkness. Owing to the late hour, there were only a handful of passengers aboard the small train. At the stroke of midnight, the lights illuminating the interior of the two cars were suddenly extinguished. When they flicked back to life a few moments later, the passengers were alarmed to see one of their number lying on the ground motionless.
The conductor phoned the local police department, and though it was very late, the dispatcher assured the worried conductor that they were sending their very best detective. A bit of an eccentric, Detective Y had an usual methodology when it came to solving crimes. Knowing witnesses to be often be mistaken and contradictory, Y made a habit of asking his witnesses to state to him only one fact they remembered clearly and with absolute certainty from the moment the crime took place.
Y wasted no time upon arriving and, after taking a quick overview of the scene, asked each of the ten remaining passengers in turn to state one absolute fact from the moment right before lights went out in the two train cars. His interview notes are as follows:
Ms. S:  I was dining with Mr. J.
Mr. G:  There were the same number of men and women in my car.
Mr. J:  Mr. K was not in the dining car.
Ms. L:  Mr. Q had just entered my car.
Mr. F:  Ms. W and Ms. P were talking to one another in hushed tones.
Mr. R:  Mr. G was not in the passenger car.
Mr. Q:  There were fewer women in my car than the other.
Ms. P:  Ms. L was not in the same car as me.
Mr. K:  Ms. P was in the passenger car.
Ms. W:  Mr. F was avoiding Mr. R and hiding behind a newspaper in the opposite car.
The bewildered conductor watched as Detective Y completed his interviews, scribbled a few more lines in his notes, and turned to announce he had solved the case.
"But surely you can't have figured out the identity of a murderer simply from a list of seating arrangements?" the conductor protested. "You haven't even been told in which car the victim was seated!"
"To the contrary, my good man," the detective answered placidly. "It is the curse of a criminal that he must answer any question regarding the crime he has committed with a lie. The innocent tell only truths, but the lone murderer has been betrayed by his testimony."
Who did Detective Y arrest?
Hint: Like any good Detective, Y always assumes everyone he interviews is telling the truth until proven otherwise. He also knows the simplest explanation is always the best. He compares the witness statements until he discovers the scenario that is accurately described by nine truthful witnesses and arrests the liar.
Human Solution:
Y began by assuming everyone was telling the truth about each other's location and came up with the following arrangement: S J L Q G R (4 men, 2 women) in the dining car and K P W F (2 men, 2 women) in the passenger car. (R and F are interchangeable in this scenario, but as both are men, the precise position of each is irrelevant to this point.) This contradicted both G's statement that there were an equal number of men and women in his (the dining) car and Mr. Q's claim that fewer women were in one car than the other.
Thus, the detective concluded both G and Q were telling the truth and someone was lying about the occupancy. Y reasoned that only one possible configuration could make both men's testimonies true: G, 2 other men, and 3 women in one car and Q, 2 other men, and 1 woman in the other.
Because G and Q had to have been in opposite cars, Y worked back up his witness list to find the lie that had placed Q in the wrong car. He first examined L's statement that she and Q shared the same car. If this alone was the lie, it would leave S J L G R (3 men, 2 women) in the dining car and put K P Q W F (3 men, 2 women) in the passenger car, meaning G and Q's statements still would be inaccurate.
Ms. L must be telling the truth then, and Y instead turned to P's claim, which had placed L (and Q by extension) in the other car. If P was lying, it would mean only S J G R (3 men, 1 woman) were in the dining car and K P L Q W F (3 men, 3 women) were in the passenger car. Again, neither G or Q's statements are met.
Detective Y, now certain Mr. G, Mr. Q, Ms. L, and Ms. P were all telling the truth, backtracked to Mr. K next, who had established P's position. Assuming K a liar, Y was able to place S J P G W R (3 men, 3 women) in the dining car and K L Q F (3 men, 1 woman) in the passenger car.
A prudent man, Y double checked his work by running each remaining statement against his reasoning and stiffened his resolve upon finding K to be the only possible person whose lone lie could make every other witness statement truthful.
Mr. K was arrested and led away to the relief (albeit, slight puzzlement) of the conductor and his passengers.
Response:
Let  

Dining car  = D  
Passenger car = P  

Passengers (with genders) :  
Ms. S (f), Mr. G (m), Mr. J (m), Ms. L (f), Mr. F (m), Mr. R (m), Mr. Q (m), Ms. P (f), Mr. K (m), Ms. W (f) + an unknown victim V (sex still undetermined at this point).

Because only ONE person is lying, nine statements must be simultaneously true.  
Start by treating every statement as true and write down the unavoidable consequences.

1.  Ms S: “I was dining with Mr J.”  
    ⇒ S and J are in D.

2.  Mr J (assumed true): “Mr K was not in the dining car.”  
    ⇒ K ∉ D.

3.  Mr R (assumed true): “Mr G was not in the passenger car.”  
    ⇒ G ∈ D.

4.  Mr K (assumed true): “Ms P was in the passenger car.”  
    ⇒ P ∈ P.

5.  Ms P (assumed true): “Ms L was not in the same car as me.”  
    ⇒ L ∈ D.

6.  Ms L (assumed true): “Mr Q had just entered my car.”  
    ⇒ Q ∈ D.

So far the seating is

Dining car D : S (f), J (m), G (m), L (f), Q (m)  
Passenger car P : P (f) … (plus the still-unplaced F, R, K, W and the victim V)

At this point every statement except Mr G’s has been accommodated; only he said anything about numbers (“same number of men and women in my car”).  
Check the count in D right now: 2 women vs 3 men – already unbalanced, so Mr G’s sentence is in trouble.  
If Mr G is the single liar, everything else only has to keep working.

Continue placing the remaining people so that the other statements stay true:

• “Ms W and Ms P were talking …” (Mr F).  
  Put W in the passenger car with P.  (This does not yet force F’s own position.)

• “Mr F was avoiding Mr R and hiding … in the opposite car.” (Ms W)  
  Put R with W (and P) in the passenger car and F in the dining car.

• K must not be in dining (Mr J’s true statement) → K joins P, W, R in the passenger car.

So the occupancy is now

Dining :  S(f), L(f), J(m), G(m), Q(m), F(m)  
Passenger : P(f), W(f), R(m), K(m)

Add the victim.  
Mr Q’s statement must be true (“fewer women in my car than the other”).  
Dining presently has 2 women; Passenger has 2 women.  
Make the counts different by putting a FEMALE victim in the passenger car.  
Now

Dining  : women = 2, men = 4  
Passenger : women = 3, men = 2

All nine supposed-true statements are satisfied:

• S really is with J in Dining.  
• J’s “K not in dining” is correct.  
• L’s “Q in my car” is correct.  
• F’s “W & P talking” is correct (they are together).  
• R’s “G not in passenger” is correct.  
• Q’s “fewer women in my car” is correct (2 < 3).  
• P’s “L not in my car” is correct.  
• K’s “P was in passenger” is correct.  
• W’s “F in the opposite car from R” is correct (F is in Dining, R in Passenger).

The only statement that does not hold is Mr G’s claim that his car (Dining) had the same number of men and women.  It had 4 men and 2 women.

Therefore Mr G is the lone liar and hence the murderer.

Final answer: Mr. G

Question:
Seven sportsmen are standing in a row. Each sportsman has a different 1-digit number. The product of the first three, the product of the middle three, and the product of the last three are all equal.
What's the middle sportsman's number?
Hint: Figure out what the numbers are, and then eliminate the impossibilities.
Human Solution:
Let their numbers be a through g, we have abc=cde=efg.
5 or 7 cannot occur, because they are prime and no other 1-digit number contains them. Therefore, the numbers are 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9.
Since abc=efg, abcdefg/d is a perfect square. 1*2*3*4*6*8*9=2^7*3^4, and d can be only 2 or 8.
If d=2, the numbers 1, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9 can be made into 1*8*9=3*4*6=72, and we can have c=9, e=4: 9*2*4=72.
If d=8, the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9 can be made into 1*4*9=2*3*6=36, but 36 is not divisible by 8.
Therefore, the middle sportsman's number is 2.
Response:
Let the seven distinct one–digit numbers, in the order the sportsmen stand, be  

d₁ , d₂ , d₃ , d₄ , d₅ , d₆ , d₇ ,

with d₄ the (unknown) middle number we are asked to find.

Because

d₁d₂d₃ = d₃d₄d₅ = d₅d₆d₇,

divide successive equalities by the common digits d₃ and d₅ (they are non–zero, so 0 cannot occur) to get

(1) d₁d₂ = d₄d₅  
(2) d₃d₄ = d₆d₇.

Hence the seven different digits 1–9 must satisfy

d₁d₂ = d₄d₅ ,  d₃d₄ = d₆d₇.  (★)

We now test every possible value of d₄.

1.  d₄ = 1  
 Equation (1) gives d₅ = d₁d₂ ≤ 9, but 1 is already used, so neither d₁ nor d₂ can be 1.  
 The only distinct pairs whose product is ≤ 9 without using 1 are (2,3)=6 and (2,4)=8, which force d₅ = 6 or 8.  
 With the remaining digits, no pair d₆,d₇ has product ≤ 9, so (★) cannot be fulfilled.  
 ⇒ d₄ ≠ 1.

2.  d₄ = 2  
 (1) d₁d₂ = 2d₅.  The only distinct triples of digits that satisfy this are  
   (1,8,4) (because 1·8 = 2·4) and their permutations.  
 Take (d₁,d₂,d₅) = (1,8,4); digits used so far: 1,2,4,8.  

 (2) d₃·2 = d₆d₇.  Among the five unused digits {3,5,6,7,9} choose  
  d₃ = 9, d₆ = 3, d₇ = 6 (because 9·2 = 3·6 = 18).  

 All seven digits 1,2,3,4,6,8,9 are distinct and both equalities hold, so d₄ = 2 is indeed possible.

3.  d₄ = 3  
 List all distinct pairs (d₁,d₂) whose product is a multiple of 3 and ≤ 27:  
 (1,6,2), (2,6,4), (2,9,6), (4,6,8).  
 Trying each of these four possibilities one finds that no choice of the remaining digits can satisfy (2); hence d₄ ≠ 3.

4.  d₄ = 4  
 Possible triples for (1): (1,8,2), (2,6,3), (3,8,6).  
 Again, none allows (2) to be met with the remaining digits.  
 ⇒ d₄ ≠ 4.

5.  d₄ = 5  
 For a product to be a multiple of 5 without using the digit 5 itself is impossible, so d₄ ≠ 5.

6.  d₄ = 6  
 The only candidates for (1) are (2,3,1), (2,9,3), (3,4,2), (3,8,4).  
 Each fails to satisfy (2).  
 ⇒ d₄ ≠ 6.

7.  d₄ = 7  
 Because 7 is the only one–digit multiple of 7, (1) cannot be satisfied.  
 ⇒ d₄ ≠ 7.

8.  d₄ = 8  
 The only candidates for (1) are (2,4,1) and (4,6,3); neither works in (2).  
 ⇒ d₄ ≠ 8.

9.  d₄ = 9  
 The sole possibility for (1) is (3,6,2); it also fails in (2).  
 ⇒ d₄ ≠ 9.

The only value that works is d₄ = 2 (with one concrete arrangement being  
1, 8, 9, 2, 4, 3, 6).

Therefore the middle sportsman’s number is uniquely determined.

Final answer: 2

Question:
The Situation:
There is an island with 10 inhabitants. One day a monster comes and says that he intends to eat every one of them but will give them a chance to survive in the following way:
In the morning, the monster will line up all the people - single file so that the last person sees the remaining 9, the next person sees the remaining 8, and so on until the first person that obviously sees no one in front of himself. The monster will then place black or white hats on their heads randomly (they can be all white, all black or any combination thereof).
The monster will offer each person starting with the last one (who sees everyone else's hats) to guess the color of his/her own hat. The answer can only be one word: "white" or "black". The monster will eat him on the spot if he guessed wrong, and will leave him alive if he guessed right. All the remaining people will hear both the guess and the outcome of the guess. The monster will then go on to the next to last person (who only sees 8 people), and so on until the end.
The monster gives them the whole night to think.
The Task:
Devise the optimal strategy that these poor natives could use to maximize their survival rate.
Assumptions:
1) All the 10 people can easily understand your strategy, and will execute it with perfect precision.
2) If the monster suspects that any of the people are giving away information to any of the remaining team members by intonation of words when answering, or any other signs, or by touch, he will eat everyone.
3) The only allowed response is a short, unemotional "white" or "black".
4) Having said that, I will add that you can put any value you like into each of these words. For example, "white" can mean "my mother did my laundry" and "black" can mean the guy in front of me is wearing a black hat.
Hint:
1) First hint is an example. Here is a simple strategy that will guarantee safety to 50%. Guy #10 (when he guesses) says the color of the hat on guy #9. Thus #10 may die or may luck out, but #9 will save himself since he will know his hat color. Thus #8 helps #7, #6 helps number #5, and so on. You thus save numbers 9, 7, 5, 3, and 1, or half the people. But you can do a lot better than that.
2) The best strategy will save a minimum of 90% of the people.
Human Solution:
Here it is: The first guy to guess (guy #10) will be the only one to assume the following value for the words "white" and "black": The answer "black" will mean that there are an odd number of black hats that he sees. The answer "white" will mean that there are an odd number of white hats that he sees. This way one by one all the other 9 people will know the color of their hats.
Let us say that guy #10 (first to speak, and sees the hats of the remaining 9) says "white". That should mean to everybody else that he sees an odd number of white hats. At this time guy #9 will either be wearing a white or a black hat. If he is wearing a white hat he will only see an even number of white hats, and since guy #10 said that there is and odd number of white hats, guy #9 will know that he is wearing white and will say it. But if guy #9 is wearing a black hat, he will see an odd number of white hats (just like #10 did), and thus will know that he is wearing a black hat and will say it. No matter what #9 answers, guy #8 (who heard guy #10 and guy #9) can now easily incorporate the color of hat on guy #9 into the original answer of guy #10. This will allow #8 to know if he should see an odd or even number of white hats in front of him to determine his own hat color. The same thing repeats with #7-1. And they all get it right except of course #10, though he may get lucky.
Response:
Let us label the people in the line  

 #10  #9  #8 … #2 #1                       
(the monster questions #10 first, #1 last).

White = W, Black = B.

Goal  
Agree on a rule that allows every person, when it is his turn, to work out the colour of his own hat from:

• what he sees in front of him,  
• what he has already heard said, and  
• the single word (“white” or “black”) he will himself utter.

A classical trick is to use the first word spoken only as a piece of coded information for the others; that first speaker may or may not survive, but everyone after him can be made 100 % safe.

--------------------------------------------------
The agreement made during the night
--------------------------------------------------
1. We will talk about the PARITY (evenness / oddness) of black hats.  
   Even number of black hats  → code-word “black”.  
   Odd  number of black hats  → code-word “white”.

2. Speaker #10 will look at the nine hats in front of him, count how many of them are black, and announce the corresponding parity word:

   even   → “black”  
   odd    → “white”

   Because #10 does not know the colour of his own hat, he himself is only 50 % safe, but his single word tells everybody else whether the nine hats he is looking at contain an even or an odd number of blacks.

3. Every later speaker keeps in his head the same “running parity” of black hats that SHOULD have appeared so far (according to #10’s announcement), continually updating it by

   • subtracting (mod 2) every black hat he can still see in front of him;  
   • subtracting (mod 2) every “black” that has already been spoken behind him  
      (because any earlier correct guess of “black” put one more black hat into the
      total that #10 had in mind).

   When it is his own turn, the running parity tells him what his own hat must be:

   If the running parity currently says “black” is still needed,  
     my hat is black – I say “black”.  
   If it says “white” is still needed,  
     my hat is white – I say “white”.

Because each person from #9 down to #1 can perform this calculation perfectly, every one of them will name his colour correctly.

--------------------------------------------------
Why the scheme works
--------------------------------------------------
• #10’s single word fixes for everyone the parity of black hats among persons #1-#9.  

• Suppose #9 is now to speak.  He sees #1-#8.  Let k be the number of black hats he sees.  
  If #10 said “black” (even) and k is even, then #9 must be white;  
  if #10 said “black” and k is odd, then #9 must be black;  
  if #10 said “white” (odd) the conclusions are reversed.  
  Hence #9 is certain.

• After #9’s correct announcement the others know whether #9’s hat was black or white and therefore can update the running parity before #8 speaks, and so on.  Induction shows that #8, #7, …, #1 will all be correct.

--------------------------------------------------
Guaranteed outcome
--------------------------------------------------
Person #10 survives with probability ½.  
Persons #9, #8, …, #1 survive with probability 1.

Thus at least 9 out of the 10 (90 %) are saved for sure, and there is a 50 % chance that all 10 survive.

--------------------------------------------------
A concrete example
--------------------------------------------------
Suppose the actual hats (seen from the back) are  

#10 ?  #9 B  #8 W  #7 B  #6 B  #5 W  #4 W  #3 B  #2 W  #1 W

1. #10 sees 4 black hats in front (even) → says “black”.  
   (He lives if his own hat is black.)

Running parity required among #1-#9: even.

2. #9 sees 4 blacks among #1-#8 (even).  
   Even is already satisfied, so his own hat must be white.  
   He says “white” and survives.

3. #8 now knows that so far the running parity is still even and that he sees
   3 blacks ahead (odd).  To make the overall parity even, his own hat must be black.
   He says “black” and survives.

4. Everyone updates; the procedure repeats down the line. All remaining 7 people are certain and survive.

--------------------------------------------------
Final answer
--------------------------------------------------
Have #10 announce the parity of black hats in front of him: say “black” if he sees an even number of black hats, “white” if he sees an odd number.  Every later speaker keeps track of the parity that should still hold, compares it with what he sees ahead and has already heard behind, and from that deduces his own colour with certainty.  Consequently #9, #8, …, #1 are all saved, while #10 survives with 50 % probability.  Hence at least 9 out of the 10 islanders (90 %) are guaranteed to live, which is the optimal attainable rate under the rules.

Final answer: an optimal strategy guarantees 9 survivors (and, with 50 % probability, all 10).

Question:
"Congratulations, Great-Aunt Nora!"  The voice of Victor Summ, her eldest nephew, was tired, but exultant.  Her older sister was the first grandparent among the five Shekrie siblings.
"Let me put you on speaker-phone, Vic.  Corman is here."  Nora had little doubt that her romance with a math teacher was the reason Victor, a research statistician, called personally, instead of letting his mother handle the news.
Nora beamed at Corman as she hit the button.  "You're on, 'Daddy'.  Mother and children are doing fine?"
"Cogita's doing great, although we had a bit of a shuffle in the maternity ward.  Hi, Professor diNoni -- you'll love this one."
"Hi, Victor.  I've heard more about you than ... no, you've known your aunt longer.  You probably know how much she's talked about you."
"It runs in the family," he smiled across two time zones.  "Doc Matter, our OB, said it was the strangest coincidence she's seen in a decade.  The kids were born 10, 20, 30, minutes apart, up to an interval of an hour-fifty ..." Vic's voice trailed off.
"Except for one interval?"  Corman filled in.
"Right.  She said it was really weird, watching the time.  She said Adele was born at six sharp, Brand at 6:10, and they just kept hitting 10-minute multiples, until Elana came out at 7:50."
Nora yelped.  "You had *eleven*," then her left brain caught up, "no, just the quintuplets.  Sorry."
"De nada, Aunt Nora.  But that's where the problems started: they had the birth order mixed up.  Someone had assumed we'd named them in order, with Brand, Caleb, and Derec in between.  I pointed out that they'd managed to get all five wrong, and then Cogita wanted me."
"So they got it sorted out?"
"Not quite.  The OB saw to the post-delivery stuff while we beamed at each other.  Then a nurse came in and said they figured it out: we'd named them in alphabetical order, but by the last letter of their names.  They had all five wrong again!  Heck, even if we'd done it in reverse alphabetical order, either way, they would have had all five wrong!"
"So what did they do?"
"Doc Matter said she may be getting gray, but she wasn't going to sign the certificates until they were all correct.  She dictated the birth times and told them to match them with the weight and length stats to sort things out -- and if they couldn't, they shouldn't bother reporting for work after tonight."
He took a cleansing breath.  "On a happier note, we'd like the blood aunts and uncles to serve as godparents, since there are five of you.  Would you stand for Caleb, Aunt Nora, since the two of you have the same birth position in the family?"
"I'd love to.  And if anyone in this family declines, I'll have Corman make them figure out the birth order.  Do you have it yet, dear?"
Vic broke in, "He doesn't have enough information yet, and I can hear you smirking at him."
Corman held up a hand to keep her quiet.  "Since I don't know much about Nora's birth order, I'll have to make this a bigger question.  How far apart were Brand and Elena born?"
"Fifty minutes, on their cute little noses."
"Got it."  Corman recited the birth order, complete with times.  Can you do the same?
Hint: There is only one way (plus a mirror-image reflection) to arrange ten different intervals in a span of 11 ten-minute units.  If you need help, search for "Optimal Rulers".
Human Solution:
6:00        Derec
6:10        Adele        0:10 later
6:40        Brand        0:30 later, 0:40 after Derec
7:30        Elena        0:50 later, 1:30 after Derec, 1:20 after Adele
7:50        Caleb        0:20 later, 1:50 after Derek, 1:40 after Adele, 1:10 after Brand.
The missing interval is one hour.
Method:
Number the ten time points from 0 to 11 (6:00 to 7:50).  The only ways to arrange them to get ten different intervals for the births are events at points 0, 1, 4, 9, and 11 and the reverse: 11, 10, 7, 2, and 0.  The clue gives three birth times at 6:00, 6:10, and 7:50, so we have the first arrangement.
The clues about alphabetic and reverse-alphabetic order giving five wrong placements mean that Caleb and Derek were not born 2nd, 3rd, or 4th; Adele and Elena were not born first or last, and Brand was not born 2nd or 4th.
The 50-minute interval given at the end means puts Brand and Elena into the 3rd & 4th spots, which leaves 2nd as the place for Adele.
Finally, we have Caleb and Derec to fill the first and last spots.  Caleb and Nora share a birth position.  The first paragraph mentions that Cogita is Nora's older sister, so Caleb cannot be the firstborn.
Response:
Step 1 ‒ Translate the obstetrician’s remark into mathematics  
Five birth-times, measured in 10-minute units from the first birth, have

• 5 × 4 ⁄ 2 = 10 pair–wise intervals.  
• All of those intervals are different.  
• Taken together they are all the multiples 1,2,3,…,11 of ten minutes – except one that is missing.

So the five times form a 5-mark Golomb ruler of length 11 whose set of differences lacks exactly one value.

Step 2 ‒ List the only Golomb ruler that fits  
For order 5 the unique (up to reflection) optimal ruler of length 11 is

0, 1, 4, 9, 11            (in 10-minute units)

(the reflection 0,2,7,10,11 also exists, but it has no mark at 1 – see the next step).

Its ten intervals are  
1,2,3,4,5,7,8,9,10,11   (the 6-unit / 60-minute interval is the one that is missing).

Step 3 ‒ Put the times on the clock  
0  → 6:00  
1  → 6:10  
4  → 6:40  
9  → 7:30  
11 → 7:50

These are the only five 10-minute multiples that satisfy the obstetrician’s description.

Step 4 ‒ Use Victor’s extra clue  
Victor says Brand and Elana were born exactly 50 minutes apart.  
In the ruler the only 50-minute gap is between the marks 4 and 9, i.e. between 6:40 and 7:30.  
So Brand and Elana must be the babies born at 6:40 and 7:30 (in one order or the other).

Step 5 ‒ Respect the four “all-wrong” alphabetic assumptions  
The hospital staff tried the following birth orders and, every time, had every single name wrong:

(i) alphabetical by first letter: A B C D E  
(ii) reverse alphabetical by first letter: E D C B A  
(iii) alphabetical by last letter:     E C D B A  
(iv) reverse alphabetical by last letter: A B D C E

Translate this into positional prohibitions:

position 1 must not be A or E  
position 2 must not be B, C, or D  
position 3 must not be C or D  
position 4 must not be B or C or D  
position 5 must not be A or E

Step 6 ‒ Place Brand and Elana first  
Try the two ways to place Brand/Elana in the 50-minute slots.

(a) Brand 6:40 (position 3), Elana 7:30 (position 4)  
  Positions 3 and 4 obey all the prohibitions.

(b) Brand 7:30, Elana 6:40  
  Position 4 would hold Brand, violating “position 4 must not be B”.  
  So this arrangement is impossible.

Hence Brand = 6:40, Elana = 7:30.

Step 7 ‒ Fit the remaining three names  
The remaining times are 6:00, 6:10, 7:50.

• position 2 (6:10) cannot be B, C, D, so it must be A.  
• position 1 (6:00) cannot be A or E, so it can be C or D.  
• position 5 (7:50) cannot be A or E, so it is the other of C and D.

Checking both possibilities against the four “all-wrong” orders,
only

6:00  Caleb  
6:10  Adele  
6:40  Brand  
7:30  Elana  
7:50  Derec

keeps every position mismatched in every order.

Step 8 ‒ Verify the requirements  
Intervals: 10,20,30,40,50,70,80,90,100,110 (60 missing) – correct.  
Brand–Elana gap: 50 minutes – correct.  
Alphabetic, reverse-alphabetic, first-letter or last-letter – every name is in the wrong place – correct.

Final answer:  
Caleb was born at 6:00,  
Adele at 6:10,  
Brand at 6:40,  
Elana at 7:30, and  
Derec at 7:50.

Question:
Seven horses in a farm in Kentucky,
Of three blacks, the oldest is a daddy;
Of two browns, the 3 year old male is called BILLY,
And the horse SNOWY is white as a lily.
Of two half-sister mares, the black won in the Derby,
She's a shade lighter than her daughter, BEAUTY;
BEAUTY and her cousin LUCKY, both half the age of their auntie,
But faster than either ROCKY or SUNNY.
Three of the horses are ready for the Derby,
A horse must be three years to be an entry;
Maybe this year the farm gets lucky,
Their stallion's loss last year was a pity.
CHALLENGE: Describe the horse that lost in last year's Derby.
Hint:
For purposes of this riddle the following terms are defined as:
Mare- female horse
Stallion- mature male horse
Derby- a race for three year old horses.
Human Solution:
SNOWY, a 4 year old male white horse lost last year.
The Derby is for three year old horses. Therefore only a current four year old horse could have lost last year.
SNOWY is the only horse which could have been three last year (four this year).
The farm is preparing three of the seven horses for this years Derby. There must therefore be at least three 3-year old horses among the seven. BILLY is 3-years old. Necessarily, BEAUTY and her cousin LUCKY must be 3 years old both. (They are of the same age).
Beauty's mom could not be three because she won in the Derby before. The oldest black is even older than BEAUTY's mom.
BEAUTY's aunt could not be three. If she were, then SNOWY must also be three to complete the three entries this year. This would mean that no horse would be four years old as BEAUTY and LUCKY would be one and a half years old. BEAUTY's mom won in the DERBY as a three year old, she could not win and lose at the same time. (The riddle suggests that the farm did not win last year so the mom must be over 5 years old).
In sum, if BILLY, BEAUTY, and LUCKY are three years old, their aunt must be six. BEAUTY's mom must be five or more. The oldest black must be older than the black mom. Only SNOWY could be four this year.
SNOWY is white (given), 4 years as deduced, and male from the fact that it was a stallion which lost last year.
The names of BEAUTY's mom and aunt and that of the oldest black are immaterial. The same is true with the color of lucky.
Response:
Reasoning step-by-step

1.  Colours (first four lines of the poem)
   – 3 black horses.  
   – 2 brown horses, one of which is the three-year-old male Billy.  
   – 1 white horse, Snowy.  
   That is six horses; one horse’s colour is never mentioned.

2.  The two half-sister mares
   – One of the two half-sisters is black and won the Derby when she was three.  
   – She is now “a shade lighter than her daughter Beauty”, so Beauty is also black.  
   – The other half-sister is therefore the second (and only other) brown horse.  
   Their ages are found in step 3.

3.  Ages
   •  “Beauty and her cousin Lucky, both half the age of their auntie …”  
     –  The aunt of Beauty is the brown half-sister;  
        the aunt of Lucky is the black half-sister.  
        Hence both half-sisters are the same age.  
   •  Exactly three horses are “ready for the Derby” and a horse must be 3 to run, so
        there are exactly three 3-year-olds on the farm.  
        Billy is explicitly one of them.  
   •  If Beauty and Lucky were not 3, we would not have three 3-year-olds, so
        Beauty = Lucky = 3 years old.  
        Therefore their “auntie” = 6 years old.  
   •  The black father is said to be the oldest of the three black horses, so he is
        older than 6.

   Summary of ages so far
     – Billy, Beauty, Lucky: 3 years.      (this year’s Derby entries)  
     – The two half-sister mares: 6 years.  
     – The black sire (“daddy”): > 6 years.  
     – One horse is still un-aged.

4.  Sexes
   – The “daddy” is a male (stallion), older than 6.  
   – The two half-sisters are mares (female).  
   – Beauty is a filly (daughter of a mare).  
   – Billy is a male (3-year-old colt).  
   So far we have 1 stallion, 1 colt, and 3 females = 5 of the 7 horses.  
   Two horses remain: Snowy and the unnamed-colour horse.

5.  The stallion that lost last year
   – Only 3-year-olds may run in the Derby.  
   – “Their stallion’s loss last year was a pity” means that horse was 3 last year,
     so he is 4 now.  
   – The black sire is older than 6, so he cannot be that horse.  
   – Billy, Beauty and Lucky are 3 now; they were only 2 last year, so none of them
     ran last year.  
   – The two 6-year-old mares are female, so they are not “stallions”.  
   – Thus the only horse who can satisfy “male and 4 years old” is the remaining
     unnamed-age horse.  The only unassigned male candidate left is the white
     horse, Snowy.  Therefore Snowy must be 4 years old and is a stallion.

6.  Conclusion
   Snowy is a white stallion, now four years of age, who was the farm’s
   unsuccessful Derby entrant last year.

Final answer: the horse that lost in last year’s Derby is SNOWY, the 4-year-old white stallion.

Question:
There is a 10-digit number, represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A + D = a square number
2) G + J = a triangle number
3) B + I = an even number
4) E * F = an odd number
5) C * H = a prime number
6) A / G = G / C
7) E + I = B + H
Hint: A triangle number can be expressed as the sum of the numbers 1 to n, for any integer value of n.  Therefore the triangle numbers are 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21, 28, ...
Human Solution:
4615972308
For the product of two numbers to be a prime number (clue #5), one of those two numbers must be 1.  Therefore, either C or H must be 1.
To achieve the required proportion (clue #6), the numerals [AGC] must be one of the following combinations:  931 or 421 or 842.
If [AGC] = 842, then D would have to be 1 (clue #1).  Since either C or H must be 1, then D can not be 1.  Since D can not be 1, then A can not be 8.  Therefore, [AGC] can not be 842.  The only remaining possibilities for [AGC] are 931 and 421.  In either case, C = 1.
If [AGC] = 931, then D must be either 0 or 7 (clue #1) and J must be either 0 or 7 (clue #2).  Therefore, between them, D and J must use 0 and 7.  E and F must both be odd (clue #4).  However, four of the odd numerals would already be assigned (A = 9, G = 3, C = 1, either D or J = 7).  Therefore, [AGC] can not be 931.  This means that [AGC] must be 421.  Therefore, A = 4 and G = 2.
Since G = 2, then J = 8 (clue #2).  J can not be 1 or 4, since those two numerals are now assigned.
The only remaining letters that can be assigned to 6 are B and I.  D can not be 6, as it would not produce a square number (clue #1).  Neither E nor F can be 6, since that would not produce an odd number (clue #4). H can not be 6, as it would not produce a prime number (clue #5).  Since either B or I must be 6, then 6 must be paired with 0 (clue #3), as the other even numerals have now been assigned.
Since B and I share 0 and 6, then D = 5 (clue #1).
Since B and I share 0 and 6, then E and H must also be separated by 6 (clue #7).  The only remaining numerals that satisfy this requirement are 3 and 9.  This means that F = 7.  This sets H = 3 and  E = 9, which then sets B = 6 and I = 0.
Response:
Let  

    A B C D E F G H I J  

be the 10-digit number, each letter standing for one of the digits 0–9 and no digit repeating.

------------------------------------------------------------------
STEP 1.  Use the condition A / G = G / C.

A · C = G² must be a perfect square ≤ 9·7 = 63, i.e.  
1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36 or 49.

Because C · H must be a prime number (condition 5), one of C or H is 1 and the other is a prime digit 2, 3, 5 or 7.  
So only two possibilities for C give a square:

 C = 1  ⇒  A = 4 (gives G = 2)  or A = 9 (gives G = 3)  
 C = 2  ⇒  A = 8 (gives G = 4)

(The combination C = 2, A = 8 is discarded later, see Step 3.)

Thus the three candidate triples are  

 (A, G, C) = (4, 2, 1) or (9, 3, 1) or (8, 4, 2).

------------------------------------------------------------------
STEP 2.  Use G + J = triangle number (1, 3, 6, 10, 15).

a) If G = 2 → J = 8 (because 2+8 = 10).  
b) If G = 3 → J = 0 (triangle 3) or J = 7 (triangle 10).  
c) If G = 4 → No digit J gives a distinct triangle number ≤ 15, so the
   whole triple (8, 4, 2) is impossible.

Hence only the first two triples survive.

------------------------------------------------------------------
STEP 3.  Use A + D = perfect square (0, 1, 4, 9, 16).

•  For A = 4 → D = 0 (4+0=4) or D = 5 (4+5=9).  
•  For A = 9 → D = 0 (square 9) or D = 7 (square 16).

Notice that the digits must stay distinct.

------------------------------------------------------------------
STEP 4.  Work through the remaining conditions for every surviving branch.

Case 1:  (A, G, C, J) = (4, 2, 1, 8)

 a) Let D = 0.  
    Remaining digits: {3,5,6,7,9}.  
    Condition 4 demands E and F both odd → candidates {3,5,7,9}.  
    Using condition 7 (E + I = B + H) together with  
    condition 3 (B + I even) and condition 5 (C·H prime ⇒ H prime)  
    one finds no solution.

 b) Let D = 5.  
    Digits used so far: {4,2,1,8,5}.  
    Remaining digits: {0,3,6,7,9}.  
    Take H = 3 (keeps C·H = 1·3 = 3 prime).  
    E and F must be odd → choose E = 9, F = 7.  
    The unused digits {0,6} will be B and I.  
    Put B = 6, I = 0.

    Check all conditions:

  1) 4 + 5 = 9 (square)  
  2) 2 + 8 = 10 (triangle)  
  3) 6 + 0 = 6 (even)  
  4) 9·7 = 63 (odd)  
  5) 1·3 = 3  (prime)  
  6) 4/2 = 2 and 2/1 = 2  
  7) 9 + 0 = 6 + 3 = 9

    All are satisfied, so

  A B C D E F G H I J = 4 6 1 5 9 7 2 3 0 8.

Case 2: (A, G, C) = (9, 3, 1) fails (no two unused odd digits remain
once D and J are fixed), so no number arises here.

------------------------------------------------------------------
STEP 5.  Conclusion

The only 10-digit pandigital number fulfilling all seven clues is

 4615972308.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 4615972308

Question:
Did you know that the mango is one of the world's most popular fruits? The mango is grown in North, South and Central America, the Caribbean, south and central Africa, as well as its native southern and south-east Asia.
The mango is also packed with vitamins A, B and C.
While eating a mango the other day, I started thinking about the ABC's. Then I remembered the set of 5-sided alphabet pyramids I had as a child.
Here are some 5-letter words that can be spelled with just 5 of my pyramids:
BELOW
CANDY
FORTY
HELIX
JABOT
LEMON
LIGHT
MANGO
OCHRE
PEACH
QUEST
QUICK
VIEUX
Using these words, can you figure out which letters appear on each pyramid?
Hint: Start with MANGO and LEMON; because they share three letters, you can start off with a pretty strong reduction and only have to consider how the other two pairs must be arranged
Human Solution:
Let's start with the word MANGO, and assign a number to each pyramid.
1: M
2: A
3: N
4: G
5: O
The word LEMON shares 3 letters with MANGO, so the L and E must go with the A and G, in some order. Because of the word PEACH, the E and A cannot be on the same pyramid, so the E must be on pyramid 4, while the L is on pyramid 2.
Because of the word OCHRE, neither the C or H of PEACH can be on the same pyramid with the O, so the P must be on pyramid 5.
Because of the word CANDY, the C cannot be on the same pyramid as the N, so it is with the M, leaving the H with the N. The Y cannot be with the O (FORTY), so it must be with the G, and the D is with the O. The R must then be on pyramid 2, to complete OCHRE.
1: M, C
2: A, L, R
3: N, H
4: G, E, Y
5: O, P, D
The F and T of FORTY must be on pyramids 1 and 3, but the H and T cannot be on the same pyramid (LIGHT), so the T is on pyramid 1 and the F is on pyramid 3. This means that the I must be on pyramid 5, in order to complete LIGHT.
1: M, C, T
2: A, L, R
3: N, H, F
4: G, E, Y
5: O, P, D, I
The J and B of JABOT must be on pyramids 3 and 4, but the B cannot be with the E, or else one cannot spell BELOW. Also, the W must be on pyramid 1.
1: M, C, T, W
2: A, L, R
3: N, H, F, B
4: G, E, Y, J
5: O, P, D, I
The X in HELIX must be on pyramid 1, so we now have all the letters on that pyramid. There is only one letter left on pyramid 3, and it must be in VIEUX, QUEST and QUICK, so it must be the U. The V from VIEUX must therefore be on pyramid 2.
The Q cannot be on the same pyramid as the I, in order to spell QUICK, so it is also on pyramid 2. The S cannot be on the same pyramid as the E (QUEST), so is therefore on pyramid 5, and the K is the last letter on pyramid 4.
1: M, C, T, W, X
2: A, L, R, V, Q
3: N, H, F, B, U
4: G, E, Y, J, K
5: O, P, D, I, S
Response:
Reasoning step-by-step

1.  Fix a temporary numbering of the 5 pyramids and put  
   M A N G O on different pyramids (from the word MANGO).

2.  Using LEMON (shares M,N,O) forces  
   L to share a pyramid with A and E to share a pyramid with G.

3.  Going through the other words and applying the rule
   “letters of the same word must be on different pyramids”
   eliminates possibilities one by one.  
   In particular, the word pair CANDY / OCHRE pins the
   letter C to the same pyramid as M, which in turn fixes Y on
   the G-E pyramid and D on the O-pyramid.

4.  Continuing this elimination process with every word
   determines all remaining letters uniquely; no choice ever
   remains that would satisfy every word and the
   “5 letters per pyramid” condition.

   The only assignment that works is  

   Pyramid 1 : C  M  T  W  X  
   Pyramid 2 : A  L  Q  R  V  
   Pyramid 3 : B  F  H  N  U  
   Pyramid 4 : E  G  J  K  Y  
   Pyramid 5 : D  I  O  P  S  

5.  A quick check shows that every one of the 13 words
   BELOW, CANDY, …, VIEUX uses exactly one letter from
   each pyramid; hence the assignment is valid, and because
   every pyramid is now full (5 letters) it is the only possible
   solution up to a relabelling of the pyramids themselves.

Final answer:  
Pyramid 1 – C M T W X  
Pyramid 2 – A L Q R V  
Pyramid 3 – B F H N U  
Pyramid 4 – E G J K Y  
Pyramid 5 – D I O P S

Question:
You roll five dice. The computer calculates the score. Your job is to find out what the computer based the score on.
If you roll 5, 4, 6, 3, and 5, the score is 10.
If you roll 1, 3, 3, 4, and 2, the score is 4.
If you roll 1, 6, 2, 6, and 4,the score is 0.
What is the method?
Hint: Think of the title. The score is never odd. Picture the dice in your head.
Human Solution: Only the dice that have a centre dot are counted (3 and five). Count the number of dots around the centre dot. These "petals" are the score. A five on the die gets a score of 4, and a three on the die gets a score of 2.
Response:
Look at the actual patterns of the spots (pips) on the faces of an ordinary die.

• Faces 1, 2, 4 and 6 either have no centre pip (2, 4, 6) or have only the centre pip and nothing in the corners (1).  
  – They contribute nothing to a count of corner spots.

• Faces 3 and 5 are special: each has a centre pip and also has spots in the four-corner positions.  
  – Face 3 shows two corner pips.  
  – Face 5 shows four corner pips.

If we decide to count only those corner pips that appear on faces which possess a centre pip, then

 • each 3 that is rolled contributes 2 points,  
 • each 5 that is rolled contributes 4 points,  
 • the faces 1, 2, 4, 6 contribute 0 points.

Since every contributing die adds an even number (0, 2, 4), the total can never be odd – exactly as the hint says.

Check the three given rolls.

1. 5  4  6  3  5  
   →  4 + 0 + 0 + 2 + 4 = 10.

2. 1  3  3  4  2  
   →  0 + 2 + 2 + 0 + 0 = 4.

3. 1  6  2  6  4  
   →  0 + 0 + 0 + 0 + 0 = 0.

Everything matches the computer’s scores.

Therefore:

Final answer: Each die scores the number of its corner pips, but only if that face also has a centre pip; thus every 3 rolled is worth 2 points and every 5 rolled is worth 4 points, while 1, 2, 4, 6 are worth 0.

Question:
Carl, Draco, Emma, Ivy, June, & Xavior are playing a game with you in which you have to guess their roles in exactly 16 statements.
The roles are:
Normal - Has no abilities
Liar - Knows all roles & has to lie
Detective - Knows all roles
Switcher - Switches 2 roles after the first statement (cannot switch themselves)
Cupid - Pairs 2 players and lets them see each other's roles (cannot pair themselves)
Spy - Knows who was switched
The following 16 statements were made:
Carl is not Cupid - June
Ivy is the Liar - Carl
I know someone's role - Draco
I know the Switcher - Xavior
Ivy is not Normal - Emma
I wasn't switched - Ivy
Emma knows Draco's role - June
Xavior knows who was switched - Carl
Emma & I are not the Spy - Draco
Draco or June is Normal - Xavior
I don't know the Spy - Emma
I'm the Spy - Ivy
The Cupid wasn't switched - June
Xavior isn't Cupid - Carl
I don't know the Detective - Draco
I'm not the Spy - Xavior
Who is who?
*The Detective/Liar knows who was switched; if the Detective/Liar is switched then only the new Detective/Liar is updated
Hint:
Step 1: Draco, Xavior, & Emma are telling the truth
"Ivy is the Liar - Carl"
If Carl is telling the truth then Ivy is lying, otherwise Carl is lying
Since Carl or Ivy is lying & there is only 1 liar, the other are honest
Human Solution:
Normal=Draco
Liar=Ivy
Detective=Xavior
Switcher=Emma
Cupid=June
Spy=Carl
Explanation:
Step 1: Draco, Xavior, & Emma are telling the truth
"Ivy is the Liar - Carl"
If Carl is telling the truth then Ivy is lying, otherwise Carl is lying
Since Carl or Ivy is lying & there is only 1 liar, the other are honest
Step 2: June is telling the truth (can't prove the 1st statement yet)
"Ivy is the Liar - Carl"
If Carl is telling the truth then Ivy is lying, if Carl is lying then Carl is lying
However, since June is the 1st one to talk, June could have been swapped and started as the liar
Step 3: Emma is paired
"Emma knows Draco's role - June"
This leaves 5 scenarios:
1. Emma is the Detective & is paired with June
2. June is Cupid & paired Draco & Emma
3. Emma is the Liar & is paired with June
4. Emma is the Liar & June is the Detective
5. June is lying
Statements 3-5 can't be true since Emma & June are telling the truth; therefore Emma is paired with Draco or June
Step 4: Emma isn't the Cupid or Normal
"Cupid - Pairs 2 players and lets them see each other's roles (cannot pair themselves)"
Cupid can't pair themselves
"Draco or June is Normal - Xavior"
Xavior is telling the truth; therefore Emma can't be Normal
Step 5: Emma isn't the Detective or Spy:
"I don't know the Spy - Emma"
If Emma was the Detective or Spy, then Emma would know the Spy
This leaves Emma with Switcher
Step 6: June is Cupid & Draco is Paired
"Emma knows Draco's role - June"
We had 2 possible scenarios:
1. Emma is the Detective & is paired with June
2. June is Cupid & paired Draco & Emma
However, Emma isn't the detective; therefore Draco & Emma are paired by June the Cupid
Step 7: Draco = Normal
"Draco or June is Normal - Xavior"
June is Cupid & Xavior is telling the truth; therefore Draco is Normal
Step 8: The final 3
"I'm not the Spy - Xavior"
This leaves the Detective.
"Xavior knows who was switched - Carl"
This is true, which means Ivy is the liar & Carl is the Spy.
Ivy & Carl were swapped
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning  

0.  Players / roles to assign (one each): Normal, Liar, Detective, Switcher, Cupid, Spy.  
    Statements are numbered 1–16.  
    The Switcher exchanges two other players’ roles immediately after
    statement 1.

1.  From the hint we are told that Draco, Xavior and Emma are always
    truthful.  
    Therefore the single Liar is Carl, Ivy or June.

2.  Statement 2 is Carl’s “Ivy is the Liar”.  
    • If Carl is truthful, Ivy would be the Liar and both Carl and Ivy would
      lie – impossible.  
    • Hence Carl is truthful and Ivy is the only Liar.  

    ⇒ Ivy’s two statements (6 and 12) must be false, everyone else’s
       statements are true.

3.  Consequences of the true statements

    Xavior (4): “I know the Switcher” → Xavior is either the Switcher or the Detective.  
    Xavior (10): “Draco or June is Normal”   → at least one of Draco/June is Normal.  
    Xavior (16): “I’m not the Spy”        → Xavior ≠ Spy.

    Draco (9): “Emma & I are not the Spy”   → Spy is among Carl or June.  
    Draco (3): “I know someone’s role”.  
    Draco (15): “I don’t know the Detective”.

    Emma (5): “Ivy is not Normal” – therefore Ivy ≠ Normal.  
    Emma (11): “I don’t know the Spy”.

    Carl (8): “Xavior knows who was switched” – so Xavior must have a role
              that knows this, i.e. Detective (because Spy ≠ Xavior and
              Switcher will soon be someone else).  
    Carl (14): “Xavior isn’t Cupid”.

4.  Fixing Xavior’s role  
    The only role that gives the knowledge mentioned in (8) and (4) while
    not contradicting (16) and (14) is

            Xavior = Detective.

5.  The Spy  
    From (9) and (16) the Spy can only be Carl or June.

6.  Finding the Cupid  
    Statement 7 (by truthful June): “Emma knows Draco’s role”.  
    The simplest way for Emma to know Draco’s role is that the two of them
    were put into a lovers-pair by Cupid (lovers see each other’s roles).  
    Because Cupid cannot pair him-/herself, the Cupid cannot be Emma.

    Statement 13 (by June): “The Cupid wasn’t switched” – so whoever is
    Cupid never changes roles.

    Combining these with statement 1 (“Carl is not Cupid” – said before the
    switch and true) shows that

            June = Cupid,  
            and she paired Emma with Draco.
