Anu : Physics book belongs to me. Maths book does not belong to Bob. Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob : Physics book does not belong to me. Chemistry book belongs to Coy. Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy : Physics book does not belong to Anu. Maths book does not belong to me. Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Case 1 : Let us assume that Anu always tells the truth.
Then according to Anu's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Maths book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Anu's reply with that of Bob's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy lies three times when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 1, Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie and Coy always lies. Also in this case the Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Case 2 : Let us assume that Bob always tells the truth.
Then according to Bob's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Bob's reply with that of Anu's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Anu speaks the truth, lies and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Coy lies, speaks the truth and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 2, Bob always speaks the truth, Anu and Coy alternate between truth and lie and hence this case is not possible since it is given that exactly one of them always speaks the truth, exactly  one of them always lies and the third one alternates between truth and lie, in any order.
Case 3 : Let us assume that Coy always tells the truth. Here we can again make two sub cases.
a) According to Coy's answer,
Maths book belongs to Anu.
Physics book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
b) According to Coy's answer,
Chemistry book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Physics book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is also not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
Hence among the three cases, only Case 1 can be considered to be a valid case wherein Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie, Coy always lies and the Chemistry book belongs to Bob. Hence all the given statements 1, 2 and 3 can be concluded.
Response:
Let  

P = owner of the Physics book   
C = owner of the Chemistry book  
M = owner of the Maths book  

and let every statement be interpreted as “true / false” with respect to the real owners.  
Exactly one student is a Truth-teller (all three of his statements true), exactly one is a Liar (all three false) and the third is an Alternator (some true, some false).

The three statements made by each pupil are:

Anu  
 A1  P = Anu  
 A2  M ≠ Bob  
 A3  C ≠ Coy  

Bob  
 B1  P ≠ Bob  
 B2  C = Coy  
 B3  M ≠ Anu  

Coy  
 C1  P ≠ Anu  
 C2  M ≠ Coy  
 C3  C ≠ Bob  

──────────────────────────  
CASE WORK (start with the hint “assume Anu tells the truth”)

Case I Anu is the Truth-teller  
Then A1, A2, A3 are all true, so  
 P = Anu, M ≠ Bob, C ≠ Coy.  
Because every student owns exactly one book, once Physics is fixed we have only two books left to distribute:

 • If M were Anu we would violate “each student owns a different book”; so  
 • M must be Coy and C must be Bob.

Thus the ownership is P→Anu, C→Bob, M→Coy.

Check Bob’s and Coy’s assertions with this ownership:

Bob: B1 true, B2 false, B3 true  ⇒ mix of T and F (Alternator)  
Coy: C1 false, C2 false, C3 false  ⇒ all false (Liar)

This satisfies the required pattern Truth-teller / Liar / Alternator, so the data are consistent and we have

 P→Anu  C→Bob  M→Coy  with (Anu T)(Bob A)(Coy L).

Case II Anu is the Liar  
All three of A1, A2, A3 would be false, giving  
 P ≠ Anu, M = Bob, C = Coy.  
But then every book is already owned (M by Bob, C by Coy) leaving Physics to go to Anu, contradicting P ≠ Anu.  Impossible.

Case III Anu is the Alternator  
Then his three statements are not all true and not all false.  
A short enumeration of the six possible permutations of (P,C,M) among (Anu,Bob,Coy) shows that none of them can produce exactly two true and one false (or vice-versa) for Anu while simultaneously letting the other two pupils become one all-true and one all-false.  Hence this case is impossible.

──────────────────────────  
The only viable scenario is Case I, which is unique.  Consequently every fact found there is forced by the information in the problem.

Therefore we can safely conclude

1) Anu always tells the truth.  (necessarily true)  
2) Coy always lies.       (necessarily true)  
3) Bob is the owner of the Chemistry book. (necessarily true)

All three listed statements follow from the conditions.

Final answer: Statements 1, 2 and 3 can all be concluded.

Question:
A king heard that the nearby kingdoms were being destroyed by a fierce dragon. He called forth his most trusted and skilled knights to meet and plan how to protect the kingdom.  The 6 knights, Sir William, Sir Andrew, Sir Luke, Sir Calvin, Sir Charles and Sir Vincent, decided that two knights would venture out to find and slay the dragon while the other 4 would defend the kingdom.
From the statements below, which two knights went to seek the dragon?
1. If neither Sir William or Sir Vincent rode out, then Sir Calvin did.
2. If either Sir Calvin or Sir Vincent went to kill the dragon, then Sir Andrew did not.
3.  If neither Sir Andrew or Sir William were of the brave two that left the kingdom, then Sir Charles was.
4.  If neither Sir Luke or Sir Andrew went out, then Sir Vincent did.
5. If Sir William was one of the two, then either Sir Calvin or Sir Charles was with him.
6. If Sir Vincent was not of the two who went to slay the dragon, then neither was Sir Andrew nor Sir Charles.
Hint: If statement 1 is valid, Calvin was one of the two that left. If not, either William or Vincent was one of the two. Therefore the PAIR could not be Andrew and Luke, Sir Andrew and Charles or Luke and Charles.
Human Solution:
Sir Vincent and Sir Charles went out of the kingdom to slay the dragon.
If statement 1 is valid, Calvin was one of the two that left. If not, either William or Vincent was one of the two. Therefore the PAIR could not be Andrew and Luke, Sir Andrew and Charles or Luke and Charles.
From 3, the PAIR that left was not Luke and Calvin, Luke and Vincent or Calvin and Vincent. From 4, the two could not have been William and Calvin, William and Charles or Calvin and Charles.
From 5, William did not venture out and therefore from 4 the pair was not William and Calvin or William and Charles.
From 6, Vincent must have been one of the two since the statement identifies three of the four knights not eliminated. From 2, Vincent was one of the two, and by elimination, the other is Charles.
Response:
Let  

W = “Sir William went”,  
A = “Sir Andrew went”,  
L = “Sir Luke went”,  
C = “Sir Calvin went”,  
H = “Sir Charles went”,  
V = “Sir Vincent went”.            (H for cHarles, to avoid confusion.)

Exactly two of the six knights went, so the set S of dragon-slayers has |S| = 2.

Translate each of the six statements into formal implications.

1. If neither William nor Vincent went, Calvin did.  
   (¬W ∧ ¬V) → C

2. If Calvin or Vincent went, Andrew did not.  
   (C ∨ V) → ¬A

3. If neither Andrew nor William went, Charles did.  
   (¬A ∧ ¬W) → H

4. If neither Luke nor Andrew went, Vincent did.  
   (¬L ∧ ¬A) → V

5. If William went, Calvin or Charles went with him.  
   W → (C ∨ H)

6. If Vincent did not go, neither Andrew nor Charles went.  
   ¬V → (¬A ∧ ¬H)

────────────────────────────────────────
Step 1.  Show that Vincent must have gone.

Assume, for contradiction, that V is not in S.

• From (6): ¬V → (¬A ∧ ¬H).  
  Hence A ∉ S and H ∉ S.

• With V ∉ S, the only possible members of S are W, C, L.

• Suppose W ∉ S.  
  – Then ¬W ∧ ¬V holds, so (1) forces C ∈ S.  
  – But A ∉ S and W ∉ S, so (3) forces H ∈ S, contradicting H ∉ S.  
  Therefore W ∈ S.

• Having W ∈ S and |S| = 2, the second knight is either C or L.

  – If it were L, statement (5) would be violated (because W requires C or H).  
  – If it were C, statement (4) would be violated (with L ∉ S and A ∉ S implying V, yet V ∉ S).

Both choices are impossible, so our assumption ¬V is impossible.  
Therefore V ∈ S.

────────────────────────────────────────
Step 2.  Determine Vincent’s companion.

Because V ∈ S, statement (2) gives A ∉ S.

The remaining knight in S must be one of {W, L, C, H}.  
Check each possibility against the implications.

(a) S = {V, W}  
    From (5): W → (C ∨ H).  C, H are not in S ⇒ contradiction.

(b) S = {V, L}  
    A ∉ S and W ∉ S, so (3) demands H ∈ S ⇒ contradiction.

(c) S = {V, C}  
    Again A ∉ S and W ∉ S, so (3) demands H ∈ S ⇒ contradiction.

(d) S = {V, H}  
    Check every statement:

    1. (¬W ∧ ¬V) is false           ⇒ OK  
    2. V is in S ⇒ A ∉ S            ⇒ satisfied  
    3. ¬A ∧ ¬W is true ⇒ H required ⇒ H is in S, satisfied  
    4. ¬L ∧ ¬A is true ⇒ V required ⇒ V is in S, satisfied  
    5. Antecedent W is false         ⇒ OK  
    6. Antecedent ¬V is false        ⇒ OK  

All six conditions are satisfied, so {V, H} is consistent.

────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion.

The only set of two knights that satisfies every statement is  
S = {Sir Vincent, Sir Charles}.

Final answer: Sir Vincent and Sir Charles

Question:
Mad Ade's cousin Steve lies a lot. He tells the truth on only one day in a week.
One day he said: "I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays."
The next day he said: "Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday."
The next day he said: "I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays."
On which day of the week does Steve tell the truth?
Hint: The first and third statements are incompatible
Human Solution:
Mad Ade's cousin  Steve tells the truth on Tuesdays
The first and third statements are incompatible; they cannot of course both be true, and they can only be lies if on one of the days mentioned Steve tells the truth. But, they have no such day in common. Therefore one of them must be true, and the other must refer to that day. Looking at the second statement (which must be a lie, as there can at most be one true statement and we have one), the first day cannot be Wednesday, Friday or Saturday. Therefore, the first statement cannot be true, since the third cannot refer to it by day. Therefore, the third statement is true, and must (from the first statement) be a Monday or Tuesday. Statement two, however, rules out Monday, leaving only Tuesday as the 'day of truth'. Thus: 'one day' is a Sunday; on the third day (Tuesday) Steve is truthful.
Response:
Let  

• Day 1 = the day on which he makes the 1st statement  
• Day 2 = the next day (2nd statement)  
• Day 3 = the following day (3rd statement)  

Steve tells the truth on exactly one fixed day of the week; on the other six he lies.

Statements  
S₁ (Day 1): “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays.”  
S₂ (Day 2): “Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday.”  
S₃ (Day 3): “I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays.”  

Notation  
T = the unique truth-telling day.  
“LieX” means Steve lies on the day X; i.e. X ≠ T.

Truth conditions for S₁ and S₃  
S₁ is true ⇔ LieMonday ∧ LieTuesday ⇔ T ≠ Monday and T ≠ Tuesday.  
S₃ is true ⇔ LieFriday ∧ LieWednesday ⇔ T ≠ Friday and T ≠ Wednesday.

Because he tells the truth on exactly one of the three consecutive days, three cases are possible.

---------------------------------------------------
Case 1. Day 1 is the truth day (T = Day 1)
---------------------------------------------------
• S₁ is true ⇒ T ≠ Monday, Tuesday.  
• S₃ must be false.  S₃ false means T = Wednesday or Friday.

So T would have to be Wednesday or Friday.

If T = Wednesday:  
Day 2 = Thursday → S₂ would say “Today is … Thursday” which is TRUE, but Day 2 must be a lie day. Contradiction.

If T = Friday:  
Day 2 = Saturday → S₂ would say “Today is … Saturday” which is TRUE, again contradicting that Day 2 is a lie day.

Hence Day 1 cannot be the truth day.

---------------------------------------------------
Case 2. Day 2 is the truth day (T = Day 2)
---------------------------------------------------
• S₂ is true ⇒ Day 2 ∈ {Sunday, Saturday, Thursday}.  
• S₁ is false ⇒ T = Monday or Tuesday (because at least one of LieMonday, LieTuesday fails).

Thus Day 2 must be Monday or Tuesday, but also Sunday/Saturday/Thursday. Impossible.

Therefore Day 2 cannot be the truth day.

---------------------------------------------------
Case 3. Day 3 is the truth day (T = Day 3)
---------------------------------------------------
• S₃ is true ⇒ T ≠ Wednesday and T ≠ Friday.  
• S₁ is false ⇒ T = Monday or Tuesday.

So T is Monday or Tuesday.

Sub-case 3a.  T = Monday  
Then Day 3 = Monday, Day 2 = Sunday, Day 1 = Saturday.  
On Day 2 (Sunday) S₂ would say “Today is Sunday …” – a true statement, yet Day 2 is supposed to be a lie day. Contradiction.

Sub-case 3b.  T = Tuesday  
Then Day 3 = Tuesday, Day 2 = Monday, Day 1 = Sunday.

Check all statements:

Day 1 (Sunday):  
S₁ = “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays.”  
Steve lies on Monday (T ≠ Monday) but tells the truth on Tuesday (T = Tuesday); hence the conjunction is false — good, Day 1 is a lie day.

Day 2 (Monday):  
S₂ = “Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday.”  
Today is Monday, so the statement is false — good, Day 2 is a lie day.

Day 3 (Tuesday):  
S₃ = “I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays.”  
Since T = Tuesday, he indeed lies on Wednesday and Friday, so the statement is true — good, Day 3 is the unique truth day.

All requirements are satisfied with T = Tuesday, and we have already shown no other day works.

Final answer: Steve tells the truth on Tuesday.

Question:
Mad Ade's Great Uncle Gaseous O' Windpants owned the Madadian Grocery store "The Beggars Can't Be Choosers". Madadia was well renowned for its pungent cheeses, especially its "Kebabrie" and "Chillirella".
On display in the store were six cheese pieces weighing 15, 16, 18, 19 , 20 and 31 Pounds. Five out of the six pieces are "Kebabrie" and the remaining one is "Chillirella".
Norma Leigh-Sobar purchased two pieces of "Kebabrie" and Laura Anne-Hardy also purchased some "Kebabrie" , but she purchased twice as much in weight than Norma .
How much does the remaining "Chillirella" weigh?
Hint: Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Human Solution:
Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Since Laura bought twice what Norma bought, the total amount of cheese bought by the two together equals 3 times that purchased by Norma alone. Now, the total weight of all the wedges at the grocery divided by 3 leaves a remainder of 2, so the "Chillirella" wedge must leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3. But the only such wedge is the 20 pound wedge, thus the "Chillirella" wedge must have weighed 20 pounds.
Thus Norma purchased the 15 and 18 pound pieces which equals 33 pounds and Laura purchased the 16, 19 and 31 pound pieces which equals 66 pounds.
Response:
Let the six wedge-weights be  

15 lb , 16 lb , 18 lb , 19 lb , 20 lb , 31 lb.  

Exactly five of them are Kebabrie (K) and one is Chillirella (C).

1. Norma buys two wedges of Kebabrie.  
   Let their total weight be W_N.

2. Laura buys twice as much Kebabrie by weight, so her total is  
   W_L = 2 W_N.

3. According to the hint, Norma must weigh at least 31 lb in total, so Laura
   must take three wedges (because the two heaviest wedges together weigh
   only 51 lb < 2·31 lb = 62 lb).

   Hence all five Kebabrie wedges are bought:   2 by Norma and 3 by Laura.  
   The single remaining wedge is the Chillirella.

4. Let x be the weight (in pounds) of the Chillirella wedge.

   Sum of all six weights = 15 + 16 + 18 + 19 + 20 + 31 = 119.

   Sum of the five Kebabrie wedges   = 119 − x.

   But
        W_N + W_L = 119 − x
        W_L = 2 W_N
   ⇒   3 W_N = 119 − x
   ⇒   W_N = (119 − x)/3.                …(★)

   For W_N to be an integer, 119 − x must be divisible by 3.
   Since 119 ≡ 2 (mod 3), we need x ≡ 2 (mod 3).

   Among the six given weights, the only one congruent to 2 modulo 3 is 20.

   Therefore   x = 20, so Chillirella weighs 20 lb.

5. Check that the remaining weights allow the required purchases.

   Removing 20 lb leaves the Kebabrie set {15, 16, 18, 19, 31} whose total is 99 lb.

   From (★):   W_N = 99/3 = 33 lb and W_L = 66 lb.

   The only pair of distinct weights summing to 33 is 15 lb + 18 lb,
   so Norma buys 15 lb and 18 lb.

   The remaining three weights 16 lb, 19 lb, and 31 lb sum to 66 lb,
   exactly twice Norma’s total, so Laura buys these three.

All conditions are satisfied and the solution is unique.

Final answer: 20 pounds

Question:
Twelve men are in a room, some of them always tell lies, while the others always tell the truth.
The first man says: "None of us is a truthteller."
The second man says: "At most one of us is a truthteller."
The third man says: "At most two of us are truthtellers."
...
The twelfth and last man says: "At most eleven of us are truthtellers."
Who are the liars?
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might exist better methods.
Human Solution:
If there are exactly N liars, then the last N men are truthtellers, leaving the first (12-N) men to be liars.
Therefore, N=12-N, N=6. The first 6 men are liars, and the last 6 men are truthtellers.
Response:
Let  
T = the total number of truthtellers among the twelve.

Man i (i = 1,…,12) says  
“At most i – 1 of us are truthtellers.”

1.  When his sentence is true (so he is a truthteller) we must have  
   T ≤ i – 1.

2.  When his sentence is false (so he is a liar) we must have  
   T > i – 1 (because the negation of “at most i – 1” is “more than i – 1”).

Therefore

• If T ≤ i – 1, man i is a truthteller.  
• If T > i – 1, man i is a liar.

Thus the truthtellers are exactly those men whose indices i satisfy  
i ≥ T + 1.

How many such men are there?  
Indices T+1, T+2, … , 12 form a set of size 12 − T.

But this set must contain exactly T truthtellers.  
Hence

T = 12 − T  
2T = 12  
T = 6.

So there are 6 truthtellers, namely those with indices i ≥ T + 1 = 7.
Consequently men 1,2,3,4,5,6 are liars and men 7,8,9,10,11,12 tell the truth.

Final answer: The first six men (numbers 1–6) are the liars.

Question: A man has 3 cards face down on a table.  One is a jack and two are aces.  He knows the order but you do not.  You can ask him one yes or no question, but when you do, you have to point to one of the cards.  If you point to an ace, he will tell the truth, if you point to the jack, he will randomly say yes or no.  You have to find one of the aces.
Hint: Yes, there is always a chance you will be pointing to the jack, and that the answer will be meaningless (just a random yes/no) but there is a way to work around it.  Don't give up!
Human Solution: Point to the middle card and say,  "Is the card to the right an ace?"  If the answer is yes, then the card on the right is an ace. If the answer is no, the card on the left is an ace.  This solution works because if you're pointing to an ace then he's obviously telling the truth and if you're pointing to the jack the answer doesn't matter anyway because you will pick one of the other two which are both aces.
Response:
Step 1.  Give the three face-down cards names.  
 Left → card 1, centre → card 2, right → card 3.

Step 2.  Decide which card you will physically point at.  
 Point at card 1.  (Any one of the three would work, but we have to choose one.)

Step 3.  Prepare the yes-or-no question you are going to ask while you are
pointing at card 1:

  “Is card 2 an ace?”

Step 4.  Also decide, in advance, what you will do with the answer.  
 Rule for choosing a card after you hear the answer:
  • If the answer is “Yes”, turn over card 2.  
  • If the answer is “No”, turn over card 3.

Those four lines are all the planning we need.  Now check that it works in
every possible situation.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Case 1.  The card you are pointing at (card 1) is the jack.  
 Then both of the other two cards (cards 2 and 3) are aces.  
 Because you are pointing at the jack, the man’s “yes” or “no” is
completely random, but that does not matter: whatever he says you will
turn over either card 2 or card 3, and both of them are aces, so you
certainly reveal an ace.

Case 2.  The card you are pointing at (card 1) is an ace.  
 Then exactly one of the two remaining cards is an ace and the other is
the jack.  
 Because you are pointing at an ace the man must answer truthfully.

 • If card 2 is an ace, the truthful answer to “Is card 2 an ace?”
  is “Yes”.  Your rule tells you to turn over card 2 – and that card is
  indeed an ace.

 • If card 3 is the ace (so card 2 is the jack), the truthful answer is
  “No”.  Your rule sends you to card 3, which is the ace.

In every possible arrangement of the three cards you end up turning over
an ace, and you have done it with just one yes-or-no question.

Final answer: Point to any one card and ask “Is the second card an ace?”  
If the reply is “Yes,” choose that second card; if the reply is “No,”
choose the third card.  This procedure is guaranteed to give you an ace.

Question:
At a family get-together, four married couples played bridge at two different tables (4 people at each table). From the statements below determine which players were at which table and who their partner was.
1. Mrs. Johnson was partnered with her son-in-law.
2. Mr. Jones' partner was his wife's brother-in-law.
3. Mrs. Jones played against her sister.
4. Mr. Johnson played against his father-in-law.
5. Mrs. Smith's partner was her daughter.
6. Mrs. Williams partner was her grandfather.
7. Mr. Johnson's partner was a man.
Hint: From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
Human Solution:
From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
From 2 and 3, the Jones are definitely one of the sisters, and from 6, the Williams are definitely on the 3rd generation. Looking at 1 and 4, the Johnson's are on the 2nd generation and since the Smiths have a daughter, they are on the 1st or 2nd generation. But since the Jones must be one of the sisters, the Smiths cannot fall in the 2nd generation with the Johnson's. Therefore the Smiths are the grandparents.
From 6, Mrs. Williams' partner is Mr. Smith.  From 1 and 6, Mrs. Johnston and Mrs. Williams both have male partners, therefore from 5, Mrs. Smith's partner could have only been Mrs. Jones. Which also means that Jones and Johnson are the pair of sisters.
Thus from 2, Mr. Jones is then partnered with Mr. Johnson, and from 3, Mrs Jones (who is partnered with Mrs. Smith) is playing against Mrs. Johnson (whose partner is Mr. Williams from 1).
In summation, Mr. Jones and Mr. Johnson play against Mrs. Williams and Mr Smith, while Mrs Jones and Mrs. Smith play against Mrs. Johnson and Mr. Williams.
Response:
We first list the eight players  

Men:  Mr Smith, Mr Johnson, Mr Jones, Mr Williams  
Women: Mrs Smith, Mrs Johnson, Mrs Jones, Mrs Williams  

Let us build the family relationships required by the seven clues.

1.  Mrs Smith’s partner is her daughter.  
2.  Mrs Williams’s partner is her grandfather.  
3.  Two of the wives are sisters (Mrs Jones plays against her sister).  
4.  Mr Johnson plays against his father-in-law.  
5.  Mrs Johnson must be partnered with one of her sons-in-law.  
6.  Mr Johnson’s partner is a man.  
7.  Mr Jones’s partner must be his wife’s brother-in-law.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – create the three generations.

•  Let the oldest (grand-parent) couple be Mr Smith & Mrs Smith.  
•  Give them two daughters who are therefore sisters:  Mrs Johnson and Mrs Jones.  
•  Mrs Johnson’s daughter will be Mrs Williams (so Mrs Williams is a granddaughter of the Smiths).

Thus the generations are

Generation 1:  Mr & Mrs Smith  
Generation 2:  Mrs Johnson  –  Mrs Jones (sisters)  
Generation 3:  Mrs Williams

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2 – use the partnership clues.

(i)  Mrs Smith must partner a daughter → she partners Mrs Jones.  
(ii) Mrs Williams must partner her grandfather → she partners Mr Smith.  

So far we have two partnerships

P1 :  Mrs Smith  –  Mrs Jones  
P2 :  Mrs Williams –  Mr Smith

(iii) Mrs Johnson must partner a son-in-law; her sons-in-law are Mr Jones and Mr Williams.  
     Mr Williams is still free, so let

P3 :  Mrs Johnson – Mr Williams

(iv) Mr Johnson’s partner must be a man, and the only man not yet partnered is Mr Jones, so

P4 :  Mr Johnson – Mr Jones

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3 – check the remaining relational clues.

•  Mr Johnson’s father-in-law is Mr Smith (father of Mrs Johnson).  
   In our arrangement Mr Johnson (in P4) plays against P2, which contains Mr Smith.  ✓

•  Mrs Jones has to play against her sister (Mrs Johnson).  
   Mrs Jones is in P1; Mrs Johnson is in P3; those two partnerships are opponents at the same table.  ✓

•  Mr Jones’s partner is his wife’s brother-in-law.  
   Mr Jones’s partner is Mr Johnson; Mr Johnson is married to Mrs Jones’s sister (Mrs Johnson), so he is indeed her brother-in-law.  ✓

All seven statements are satisfied.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
The two bridge tables:

Table 1  
   Partners:  Mrs Smith  &  Mrs Jones  
   versus     Mrs Johnson &  Mr Williams

Table 2  
   Partners:  Mrs Williams &  Mr Smith  
   versus     Mr Johnson   &  Mr Jones

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer:  
Table 1 – Mrs Smith with Mrs Jones, playing against Mrs Johnson with Mr Williams.  
Table 2 – Mrs Williams with Mr Smith, playing against Mr Johnson with Mr Jones.

Question:
The following task involves several steps, but they are out of order.  Arrange them so that a person who follows the steps exactly can perform the task:
You have three heavy beams marked A, B, and C, and want to find out which one is the heaviest.  You also have a scale that tells you which of any two beams is heavier, but it does not give the specific weight of any beam.  In what order must you perform the following steps to determine which beam is the heaviest, and to mark it accordingly?  Assume that all three have different weights.
a)  Weigh A against B.
b)  Weigh B against C.
c)  Weigh A against C.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
l)  Skip the next three statements.
m)  End.
Hint: The first two steps are "a" and "d", in that order.
Human Solution:
a)  Weigh A against B.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
b)  Weigh B against C.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
c)  Weigh A against C.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
l)  Skip the next three statements.
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
m)  End.
Response:
Reasoning (detailed):

Let us design one linear list of the 13 labelled statements so that  
a person who follows them, executing every statement in turn except for
those that are skipped, will always end by stamping the heaviest beam.

We have to cover the three possible weight–orders:

(1) A > B,  
(2) B > A   and B > C,  
(3) B > A   but C > B.

The hint fixes the first two instructions:

1. a)  Weigh A against B.  
2. d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.

•  If A > B we therefore jump over the next three statements and will
start executing at statement 6.

•  If A < B we do not skip and will execute statements 3-5.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Statements 3-5   (executed only when A < B)

3. b)  Weigh B against C.  
4. f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.  
5. k)  Skip the next two statements.

– After 3 and 4 we know, in the A < B case, whether B > C or C > B.

    •  If B > C (case 2) statement 4 makes us skip the next five
      statements (5-9) and we will arrive at statement 10.

    •  If C > B (case 3) statement 4 does not skip.  
      Statement 5 (k) now skips statements 6 and 7, so we will arrive
      at statement 8 without having to weigh anything more; at that
      point we can simply mark C as the heaviest.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Statements 6-9   (reached either when A > B, or when C > B)

6. c)  Weigh A against C.  
7. e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.  
8. i)  Mark C “heaviest.”  
9. l)  Skip the next three statements.

– If we are here because A > B:

    •  After 6 we compare A with C.  
      – If A > C, statement 7 skips 8-11 and we will mark A at statement 12.  
      – If C > A, statement 7 does not skip; statement 8 marks C, and
        statement 9 (l) then jumps directly to the end.

– If we are here because C > B (case 3), statement 6 has been skipped by
statement 5.  We still reach 8 and 9, which mark C and jump to the end.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Statements 10-13   (reached only along the path where B > C)

10. h)  Mark B “heaviest.”  
11. j)  Skip the next statement.  
12. g)  Mark A “heaviest.”      (will be skipped in the B-heaviest path)  
13. m)  End.

In the B-heaviest path we execute 10, then 11 makes us skip 12, and we
terminate at 13.  In the A-heaviest path we skip 8-11 and execute 12 g
before reaching 13.  In the C-heaviest path we jump over 10-12 by means
of statement 9 l and also finish at 13.

Thus every possible ordering of weights is handled correctly, and each
statement a–m appears exactly once.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Ordered list of the statements:

a, d, b, f, k, c, e, i, l, h, j, g, m

Question:
Major Steve is forming a five-person Special Task Group for the Madadian army. The group must contain one leader, two bomb-experts and two soldiers.
P, Q and R are possible bomb-experts. R, S and T are possible leaders. U, V and W are possible soldiers. Also, P and R prefers to work with each other in the same team. T prefers to work only if V works.
How many different possible Groups can Major Steve make?
Hint: Draw it out!
Human Solution:
Major Steve can make 8 different possible groups.
As 2 bomb-experts to be selected from the given 3 and also P & R prefers to work together, PR must be there in all the possible Groups. Also, T prefers to work only if V works. It doesn't mean that V won't work without T.
Hence, possible groups are:
PR - S - UV
PR - S - VW
PR - S - WU
PR - T - UV
PR - T - VW
PQ - R - UV
PQ - R - VW
PQ - R - WU
Hence,  8 different groups are possible.
Response:
Let us list all eight available people together with the positions they are able to fill.

P — bomb-expert only  
Q — bomb-expert only  
R — bomb-expert or leader  
S — leader only  
T — leader only  
U — soldier only  
V — soldier only  
W — soldier only  

The team must contain  
• 1 leader,  
• 2 bomb-experts,  
• 2 soldiers (total 5 people).

Extra conditions  
1.  P and R insist on being together.  (P in team ⇔ R in team)  
2.  T will serve only if V is also in the team.  (T in team ⇒ V in team)

We now count all possible role-assignments that satisfy everything.

────────────────────────────────────────
CASE 1 Leader = R
────────────────────────────────────────
If R is leader, P must also be present (rule 1).  
R cannot double as a bomb-expert, so the two bomb-experts must be P and Q.

Current members:  R(ldr), P(b), Q(b) — 3 people.

Choose any 2 of the 3 soldiers U,V,W:  C(3,2)=3 ways.  
(T is not in the team, so rule 2 is automatically satisfied.)

Number of teams in Case 1 = 3.

────────────────────────────────────────
CASE 2 Leader = S
────────────────────────────────────────
Choose 2 bomb-experts from {P,Q,R} subject to rule 1 (P⇔R).

Possible 2-sets: {P,Q}, {P,R}, {Q,R}.  
Only {P,R} is allowed (it contains both P and R).

Current members:  S(ldr), P(b), R(b) — 3 people.

Again choose any 2 of the 3 soldiers U,V,W: 3 ways.

Number of teams in Case 2 = 3.

────────────────────────────────────────
CASE 3 Leader = T
────────────────────────────────────────
Because T is chosen, rule 2 forces V to be one of the soldiers.

Bomb-experts: choose 2 from {P,Q,R} obeying rule 1.

Only {P,R} works (as before).

Current members:  T(ldr), P(b), R(b), V(s) — 4 people.

One soldier slot remains, to be filled by either U or W → 2 ways.

Number of teams in Case 3 = 2.

────────────────────────────────────────
TOTAL
────────────────────────────────────────
Case 1 3 teams  
Case 2 3 teams  
Case 3 2 teams  
             ——————  
Total = 3 + 3 + 2 = 8 possible Special Task Groups.

Final answer: 8

Question:
LTVX
AFHKNZ
_ _ _
What three letters fill in the blanks?
Hint:
- The title has a partial clue.
- Look down.
- They are grouped horizontally.
Human Solution:
E M W
The first row requires two straight lines to make. (LTVX)
The Second row requires three straight lines to make.  (AFHKNZ)
Following the pattern, the next row should have four straight lines to make, and the only letters that do that are EMW.
(Also everything has been so far in alphabetical order so it has to be "EMW", not EWM, MEW, MWE, WME, or WEM.)
Response:
The letters are not random – they have been grouped according to how many straight-line strokes are needed to draw each capital letter.

Row 1: every letter needs exactly 2 strokes  
L  (vertical + horizontal)  
T  (horizontal + vertical)  
V  (left diagonal + right diagonal)  
X  (diagonal down-right + diagonal down-left)

Row 2: every letter needs exactly 3 strokes  
A  (left diagonal + right diagonal + crossbar)  
F  (vertical + top bar + middle bar)  
H  (left vertical + right vertical + crossbar)  
K  (vertical + upper diagonal + lower diagonal)  
N  (left vertical + diagonal + right vertical)  
Z  (top bar + diagonal + bottom bar)

Row 3 therefore must contain the capitals made with exactly 4 straight strokes.  
There are three such letters:

E  (vertical + top bar + middle bar + bottom bar)  
M  (left vertical + left diagonal + right diagonal + right vertical)  
W  (left diagonal + right diagonal + left diagonal + right diagonal)

Hence the three blanks are filled by E, M, W.

Final answer: E M W

Question:
List the order in which each person finished.
Tommy Tombstone finished after Lance Lamers and Brett Brown but before Mitch Monday.
Peter Poultry finished before Daniel Dusk and Lance Lamers.
Sam Sunny finished after Peter Poultry and before Jack Jill and Harry Hills.
Keri Kernel finished after Peter Poultry, Mitch Monday and Tommy Tombstone.
Lance Lamers finished after Brett Brown and Daniel Dusk, but before Jack Jill and Mitch Monday.
Mitch Monday finished after Sam Sunny and Brett Brown.
Brett Brown finished before Jack Jill, Mitch Monday and Peter Poultry.
Daniel Dusk finished before Keri Kernel and Tommy Tombstone, but after Sam Sunny.
Jack Jill finished before Keri Kernel, Tommy Tombstone and Mitch Monday, but after Peter Poultry and Daniel Dusk.
Harry Hills finished before Mitch Monday but after Lance Lamers, Jack Jill and Tommy Tombstone.
Hint: Figure out who could possibly be first? Work from there
Human Solution:
1.Brett Brown
2.Peter Poultry
3.Sam Sunny
4.Daniel Dusk
5.Lance Lamers
6.Jack Jill
7.Tommy Tombstone
8.Harry Hills
9.Mitch Monday
10.Keri Kernel
Response:
Reasoning:

1. Convert each clue into “comes before” (<) relationships.

   Brett Brown (BB) < Tommy (TT), Lance (LL), Jack (JJ), Mitch (MM), Peter (PP)  
   Peter Poultry (PP) < Daniel (DD), Lance (LL), Sam (SS), Jack (JJ), Keri (KK)  
   Sam Sunny (SS) < Jack (JJ), Harry (HH), Mitch (MM); and PP < SS  
   Daniel Dusk (DD) < Lance (LL), Tommy (TT), Jack (JJ), Keri (KK); and SS < DD  
   Lance Lamers (LL) < Jack (JJ), Mitch (MM), Tommy (TT), Harry (HH)  
   Tommy Tombstone (TT) < Mitch (MM), Harry (HH), Keri (KK)  
   Jack Jill (JJ) < Tommy (TT), Mitch (MM), Harry (HH), Keri (KK)  
   Harry Hills (HH) < Mitch (MM)  
   Mitch Monday (MM) < Keri (KK)

2. Build prerequisite sets (what must come before each person).

   BB: —  
   PP: BB  
   SS: PP  
   DD: SS  
   LL: PP, DD  
   JJ: PP, DD  
   TT: LL, JJ, DD, BB  
   HH: LL, JJ, TT  
   MM: TT, LL, SS, JJ, HH, BB  
   KK: PP, DD, JJ, TT, MM

3. Topologically remove whoever has no prerequisites, updating the list each time.

   1) BB  
   2) PP  
   3) SS  
   4) DD  
   5) LL   (must precede JJ because LL < JJ)  
   6) JJ  
   7) TT  
   8) HH  
   9) MM  
  10) KK  

4. Check every original clue; every inequality is satisfied, so the order is consistent.

Final answer: Brett Brown, Peter Poultry, Sam Sunny, Daniel Dusk, Lance Lamers, Jack Jill, Tommy Tombstone, Harry Hills, Mitch Monday, Keri Kernel

Question: A prisoner sat alone in his cell staring through the bars at the six doors to the guardroom beyond them. Suddenly, there was the sound of footsteps. One guard came in through door A and a second entered through door F. They unlocked the cell door. "We shall set you free," said one of the guards, "but first you must pass through all six doors, each door once only, in the correct order. Three are entrances only and three are exits only. Door A must be followed by door B or E; B by C or E; C by D or F; D by A or F; E by B or D; and F by C or D." With that the guards left through door B. In what order must the prisoner pass through the doors?
Hint: The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. List the six possible orders then study the conditions to eliminate possibilities.
Human Solution:
The order is CFDABE. The guards entered through doors A and F and exited at door B. The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. Let the unknown entrance be X. With a "_" denoting an exit door the possible orders are:
(a) _A_F_X ; (b) _F_A_X ; (c) _X_A_F ; (d) _X_F_A ; (e) _A_X_F ; (f) _F_X_A
Neither (a) nor (c) are possible since A is followed by B or E and neither leads to F. Since A can only be preceded by D, (e) and (f) are possible as DA_X_F and _F_XDA, respectively. With D used, door F can only be preceded by C to give DA_XCF and CF_XDA, respectively. Door B must occupy the remaining space in each possibility (third door is exit) so X=E but C cannot follow E in the former and for the latter, B cannot follow F. This eliminates (e) and (f). Since only D precedes A, (b) is possible as _FDA_X and (d) as _X_FDA. For (d), the exit B must occupy a "_" but cannot be followed by F, and if it is the first door, neither the C or E that must follow as X can be followed by the remaining E or C, respectively. This only leaves (b) and only C (of the possible B,C,E) can precede F as CFDA_X and B must occupy the final "_" as an exit leaving E=X. Notice that the condition that E is followed by B or D cannot be satisfied until the prisoner has completed his task and finally wins his freedom through B or D!
Response:
Let  

A → B or E  
B → C or E  
C → D or F  
D → A or F  
E → B or D  
F → C or D  

denote the rule ‘door X must be followed only by the doors listed’.

Because the guards ENTERED through A and F, those two must be “entrance-only” doors; because they LEFT through B, B is an “exit-only’’ door.  
Since there are exactly three entrances and three exits, the prisoner’s six-door sequence must alternate

entrance, exit, entrance, exit, entrance, exit        (1)  
or  
exit, entrance, exit, entrance, exit, entrance        (2)

List the six possible alternating patterns that place the fixed doors A (entrance), F (entrance) and B (exit):

Pattern (1) gives only one arrangement of the three fixed doors:

position 1  2  3  4  5  6  
type      E  X  E  X  E  X  
doors     A  B   ?  ?  F  ?

Pattern (2) cannot be used because it would force the first door to be an exit, contradicting the fact that A or F (both entrances) must appear somewhere before B can be used.

So we must use pattern (1); the unknown doors in positions 3, 4 and 6 are C, D and E in some order.  
Now obey the adjacency rules step by step.

1.  Door 1 is A.  By the rules A can be followed only by B or E, but B is already in position 2, so door 3 must be E.  
    Sequence so far: A B E _ _ _.

2.  From E one may go only to B or D; B has already been used, therefore door 4 is D.  
    Sequence: A B E D _ _.

3.  From D one may go only to A or F; A is used, so door 5 is F.  
    Sequence: A B E D F _.

4.  From F one may go only to C or D; D is used, so door 6 is C.  
    Complete sequence: A B E D F C.

Every door appears exactly once, all adjacency conditions are met, and the entrance/exit pattern is

Entrance (A) – Exit (B) – Entrance (E) – Exit (D) – Entrance (F) – Exit (C),

which alternates perfectly and provides the required three entrances and three exits.

Therefore the unique order in which the prisoner must pass through the doors is

Final answer: A, B, E, D, F, C

Question:
You've been placed on a course of expensive medication in which you are to take one tablet of Sildenafil and one tablet of Citrate daily. You must be careful that you take just one of each because taking more of either can have serious side effects.
Taking Sildenafil without taking Citrate, or vice versa, can also be very serious, because they must be taken together in order to be effective. In summary, you must take exactly one of the Sildenafil pills and one of the Citrate pills at one time. Therefore, you open up the Sildenafil bottle, and you tap one Sildenafil pill into your hand. You put that bottle aside and you open the Citrate bottle. You do the same, but by mistake, two Citrates fall into your hand with the Sildenafil pill.
Now, here's the problem. You weren't watching your hand as the pills fell into it, so you can't tell the Sildenafil pill apart from the two Citrate pills. The pills look identical. They are both the same size, same weight (10 micrograms), same color (Blue), same shape (perfect square), same everything, and they are not marked differently in any way.
What are you going to do? You cannot tell which pill is which, and they cost $300 a piece, so you cannot afford to throw them away and start over again. How do you get your daily dose of exactly one Sildenafil and exactly one Citrate without wasting any of the pills?
Hint: You can cut pills in half
Human Solution: Carefully cut each of the three pills in half, and carefully separate them into two piles, with half of each pill in each pile. You do not know which pill is which, but you are 100% sure that each of the two piles now contains two halves of Citrate and half of Sildenafil. Now go back into the Sildenafil bottle, take out a pill, cut it in half, and add one half to each stack. Now you have two stacks, each one containing two halves of Sildenafil and two halves of Citrate. Take one stack of pills today, and save the second stack for tomorrow.
Response:
Let  

 S = the Sildenafil tablet that is already in your hand  
 C₁ , C₂ = the two Citrate tablets that are already in your hand  

All three look the same, so we do not know which is which.

1.  Take a knife or pill-cutter and cut each of the three tablets in your hand exactly in half.  
    • You now have six half-tablets.  
    • Keep the two halves that came from the same original tablet apart, so that from every tablet one half goes into pile A and the other half into pile B.  
    After this step  

  Pile A = ½S + ½C₁ + ½C₂  
  Pile B = ½S + ½C₁ + ½C₂  

    Each pile therefore contains ½ of the Sildenafil dose and one whole Citrate dose (in two halves).

2.  Open the Sildenafil bottle again, take one more (known) Sildenafil tablet, and cut it in half.  
    Put one of these halves on pile A and the other half on pile B.

  Pile A = ½S(original) + ½S(new)  → 1 full S  
       + ½C₁ + ½C₂            → 1 full C  

  Pile B = the same composition.

3.  Swallow all the halves in pile A today.  
    Put the halves in pile B in a safe place and swallow them tomorrow.

Result:

• Today you have taken exactly one whole Sildenafil tablet and one whole Citrate tablet.  
• Tomorrow you will again take exactly one whole Sildenafil tablet and one whole Citrate tablet.  
• No tablet (not even a fragment) is wasted; the extra Sildenafil tablet you opened is simply tomorrow’s dose taken half-today/half-tomorrow.

Final answer: Cut each of the three mixed tablets in half, distributing one half of each tablet into two separate piles. Cut one additional (known) Sildenafil tablet in half and add one half to each pile. Each pile now contains exactly one full Sildenafil dose and one full Citrate dose; take one pile today and the other pile tomorrow, wasting nothing.

Question:
The first chess tournament ended. Bab, Beb, Bib, Bob and Bub became good friends, and returned to their houses.
They told their wives about the tournament. Their wives were also chess players, and they decided to hold another tournament.
This time, each of the 10 players was going to play against each other player once, with an exception that no games were played between the couples. So a total of 40 games would be played.
After some days passed, they decided to have a get-together. Bub asked the other people how many matches until then they had played.
Something fun was that Bub heard 9 different answers.
How many matches until then had Mrs. Bub played?
Hint: If you can't figure it out, draw a diagram.
Human Solution:
Each player could play at most 8 matches, so the answers Bub heard was 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 in some order.
Assume without loss of generality that it was Bab that had played 8 matches. Then all players except Mrs. Bab must have played against Bab, and it must have been Mrs. Bab who had played no matches.
Then, assume without loss of generality that Beb had played 7 matches, and then all players except Mrs. Bab and Mrs. Beb must have played against Beb, and it must have been Mrs. Beb who had played 1 match.
Repeat this and we know that Mrs. Bub had played 4 matches.
Response:
Let us translate the situation into a graph-picture.

Vertices  
Ten vertices represent the ten players.  
Each vertex is joined to another vertex by an edge as soon as the two corresponding players have already played a game.  
There is never an edge between two spouses (they are not allowed to play each other).

Degree  
For every vertex the number of adjacent edges equals the number of games that player has already played.  
Because a player can play at most eight opponents (all the players except the one she/he is married to), every degree is between 0 and 8.

The information Bub collects  
Bub asks the other nine people how many games they have played and receives nine different answers.  
Hence the degrees of the nine vertices different from Bub are exactly

0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8.          (1)

Our task is to find which of these nine numbers belongs to Mrs Bub.

Step 1.  Couple (0 , 8)  
Someone has degree 0.  
Her/his spouse cannot have played that person, so whoever is married to the 0–player is missing at least one possible opponent.  
But in (1) only the player with degree 8 is missing nobody except the spouse.  
Consequently the 0-player and the 8-player must be a married couple.

Step 2.  Couple (1 , 7)  
Remove that couple from the list; the remaining degrees are 1,2,3,4,5,6,7.  
Look at the player whose degree is now 1.  
She/he has played exactly one opponent; all the others (except the spouse) are still missing.  
The only remaining person who has avoided exactly one opponent is the one with degree 7.  
Therefore the 1-player and the 7-player are spouses.

Step 3.  Couple (2 , 6)  
Remove the pair (1 ,7).  
Among the still unpaired people the smallest degree is 2 and the largest is 6.  
Repeating the same reasoning shows that these two must also be spouses.

Step 4.  Couple (3 , 5)  
Remove (2 ,6).  
The remaining degrees are 3,4,5.  
Again the smallest (3) and the largest (5) must be married.

Step 5.  Who is left?  
After removing the four couples just found, the only degree that has not yet been paired is 4.  
The vertex with degree 4 is married to the only person whose degree we never asked for—Bub himself.

Therefore Mrs Bub is the one whose degree is 4; i.e. she has played four games so far.

Final answer: 4

Question:
Al, Ben, Carl, and Dan live in four adjacent apartments. The apartments are set up like this:
|1|2|3|4|
with apartment 1 being the westernmost apartment and apartment 4 being the easternmost. One of the four is the landlord. Here are some facts:
1. If Carl does not live next to Ben, then Al is the landlord and he lives in apartment 1.
2. If Al lives east of Carl, then Dan is the landlord and he lives in apartment 4.
3. If Ben does not live next to Dan, then Carl is the landlord and he lives in apartment 3.
4. If Dan lives east of Al, then Ben is the landlord and he lives in apartment 2.
Who is the landlord?
Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Human Solution:
Carl is the landlord.
Obviously only one conclusion is true at most. Let us suppose that all conclusions are false. This would mean that each hypothesis is also false. From facts 1 and 3, Ben lives next to both Carl and Dan, and therefore between Carl and Dan. Then either Al lives east of both Carl and Dan (contradicting fact 4) or Carl and Dan both live east of Al (contradicting fact 2.) So there must be exactly one true hypothesis, which will be paired with the one true conclusion. Obviously each of the three false conclusions is paired with a false hypothesis.
If conclusion 1 is true, then Al lives in apartment 1. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al has to live east of Dan. So this cannot be right.
If conclusion 2 is true, then Dan lives in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al must live east of Dan. So this cannot be right, either.
If conclusion 4 is true, Ben lives in apartment 2. Then, since hypotheses 1 and 3 are false, Ben lives between Carl and Dan, putting Al in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 2 is false, Carl must live east of Al. Therefore, conclusion 3 is true.
Response:
Let  

    A₁,B₁,C₁,D₁  be the apartment numbers (1 = west, 4 = east)  
    Aᴸ,Bᴸ,Cᴸ,Dᴸ   indicate “is the landlord”.

Each of the four given facts is a conditional statement  
“IF (hypothesis) THEN (conclusion)”.  
For every fact to be true, one of the following must happen for that fact:
• the hypothesis is false, or  
• the conclusion is true.

The four conclusions are

(1)  Aᴸ ∧ A₁=1  
(2)  Dᴸ ∧ D₁=4  
(3)  Cᴸ ∧ C₁=3  
(4)  Bᴸ ∧ B₁=2

Because there is exactly one landlord, at most one of these four conclusions can be true.  
We therefore test, one by one, the only four possibilities.

------------------------------------------------------------
CASE 1 – conclusion (1) true  
A is landlord and lives in 1.  
Fact 4 would then have true hypothesis (D east of A, because everyone else must be east of 1) and false conclusion, so fact 4 would be false.  Impossible.

CASE 2 – conclusion (2) true  
D is landlord and lives in 4.  
To make fact 4 true we need its hypothesis false, i.e. D not east of A, but D is in 4 so that is impossible.  Impossible.

CASE 3 – conclusion (3) true  
C is landlord and lives in 3.  
Now conclusions (1), (2), (4) are false, so their hypotheses must be false:

• Fact 1: “C not next to B” must be false → C is next to B.  
  With C in 3, B is in 2 or 4.

• Fact 2: “A east of C” must be false → A is not east of C → A ≤ 3.

• Fact 4: “D east of A” must be false → D is not east of A → D ≤ A.

Try B = 2  
 Then A must be 1 (the only place ≤3 that is free).  
 But D ≤ A = 1, impossible (1 is occupied).

Try B = 4  
 Apartments left: 1 and 2 for A and D.  
 Take A = 2 (still ≤3).  
 Then D ≤ 2, so D = 1 works.

Arrangement obtained:

| 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 |
| D | A | C | B |

Check the four facts:

1. C next to B (true), so hypothesis of fact 1 is false → fact 1 true.  
2. A is not east of C, so hypothesis of fact 2 is false → fact 2 true.  
3. B not next to D (true) and conclusion (C landlord in 3) true → fact 3 true.  
4. D not east of A, so hypothesis of fact 4 is false → fact 4 true.

All four facts hold, so this case is consistent.

CASE 4 – conclusion (4) true  
B landlord in 2.  
Fact 3 would then need its hypothesis false, i.e. B next to D, forcing D in 1 or 3.  
Fact 1 would need C next to B, forcing C in 1 or 3 as well.  
But one of those two slots is already taken by D, so one of them can’t be next to B and fact 3 fails.  Impossible.

------------------------------------------------------------
The only viable case is CASE 3.

Therefore Carl is the landlord (and lives in apartment 3).

Final answer: Carl

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
@ stands for M, O, F, L, or V
$ stands for B, N, R, E, or J
% stands for T, F, B, L, or A
! stands for W, T, S, E, or I
# stands for F, O, A, T, or L
The five letter code word, %$#@!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Prepositions
Human Solution: Above and Below
Response:
We are told that the five–symbol code word  

  % $ # @ !  

can be read in English by choosing one letter for each symbol from the sets

 %  →  {T, F, B, L, A}  
 $  →  {B, N, R, E, J}  
 #  →  {F, O, A, T, L}  
 @  →  {M, O, F, L, V}  
 !  →  {W, T, S, E, I}

The hint says “Prepositions”, and we need two opposite (antonymous) English words of five letters each.

Step 1 – list likely opposite 5-letter prepositions.  
The natural pair is ABOVE / BELOW.

Step 2 – check if ABOVE can be produced.

 %  = A  (A is in {T,F,B,L,A}) ✔  
 $  = B  (B is in {B,N,R,E,J}) ✔  
 #  = O  (O is in {F,O,A,T,L}) ✔  
 @  = V  (V is in {M,O,F,L,V}) ✔  
 !  = E  (E is in {W,T,S,E,I}) ✔  

All letters fit, so %$#@! could be “ABOVE”.

Step 3 – check if BELOW can be produced.

 %  = B  (B is in {T,F,B,L,A}) ✔  
 $  = E  (E is in {B,N,R,E,J}) ✔  
 #  = L  (L is in {F,O,A,T,L}) ✔  
 @  = O  (O is in {M,O,F,L,V}) ✔  
 !  = W  (W is in {W,T,S,E,I}) ✔  

All letters fit again, so the same pattern can also be “BELOW”.

Since ABOVE and BELOW are prepositions and clear opposites, they are the required pair.

Final answer: ABOVE and BELOW

Question: Two friends, Joe and Smoe, were born in May, one in 1932, the other a year later. Each had an antique grandfather clock of which he was extremely proud. Both of the clocks worked fairly well considering their age, but one clock gained ten seconds per hour while the other one lost ten seconds per hour. On a day in January, the two friends set both clocks correctly at 12:00 noon. "Do you realize," asked Joe, "that the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday?" Smoe agreed. Who is older, Joe or Smoe?
Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Human Solution: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again. This is when the slow clock loses six hours, and the fast one gains six hours. This will take 90 days. In 90 days they will come together at 6:00. On a calendar, there are 90 days between noon January 31, and noon May 1 in years with no leap year. If Smoe had been born in 1933, his 47th birthday would have been in 1980, a leap year. This means that Smoe must be older, born in 1932, and the time of this problem is 1979.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  How fast the two clocks separate  
   •  One clock gains 10 s every real hour.  
   •  The other loses 10 s every real hour.  
   •  Hence the two readings drift apart by  
        10 s + 10 s = 20 s each real hour  
        = 20 s / h × 24 h = 480 s per day  
        = 8 min per day.

2.  When will the two readings coincide again?  
    The dial of a grandfather clock repeats every 12 hours (720 minutes).  
    We need the two readings to differ by an integral multiple of 12 h in
    order to look the same.  
    Smallest positive multiple → 12 h = 720 min.  
           8 min per day × N days = 720 min  
           N = 720 / 8 = 90 days.  

    So the NEXT time the two clocks agree is exactly 90 days after they were
    set.

3.  What calendar date is 90 days after a day in January?  
    •  In an ordinary (non-leap) year  
          Jan 31  + 90 days = May 1  
          Jan 30  + 90 days = Apr 30  
          …  
          Jan 1   + 90 days = Apr 1  

      Therefore the ONLY way “90 days after a day in January” can fall in May
      is to start on 31 January; then the target date is 1 May.

    •  In a leap year (February has 29 days)  
          Jan 31  + 90 days = Apr 30  
      (and all earlier January dates give earlier April dates).  
      Hence in a leap year the 90-day point is never in May.

4.  Connecting this with the birthday  
    Joe says the next coincidence (90 days later) will be on Smoe’s 47th
    birthday, i.e. on 1 May of some year.

    That year must therefore be a NON-leap year.

5.  Which year is it?  
    Smoe’s 47th birthday is in May of the year  
       birth-year + 47.  
    The only possible non-leap year is 1979, because 1980 (the other
    possibility) is a leap year.

       birth-year = 1979 – 47 = 1932.

    Hence Smoe was born in May 1932.  
    Joe, being the other friend, was born the following May, i.e. May 1933.

6.  Who is older?  
    Smoe (born May 1932) is one year older than Joe (born May 1933).

Final answer: Smoe is older than Joe.

Question:
Ole Santa's pack held thirty toys
Made by his elfin crew;
And though none made the same amount,
Each elf made more than two.
The elf named Cher made one more Christmas toy
Than the elf who dressed in reds,
But Cher made one less Christmas toy
Than the elf who made the sleds.
Spry Johnny Elf made racing cars;
Five toys were made by Jane.
The elf who dressed in yellow suits
Made each and every train.
The elf who always dressed in green
Made one-third as many as Sue;
Cute Marcia elf was dressed in orange,
And one elf dressed in blue.
The elf who made the spinning tops
Made the most toys of them all.
Another perky smiling elf
Made each and every ball.
Ole Santa's pack held thirty gifts
All tagged for girls and boys.
From the clues that you've been given,
Now guess who made the toys!
Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Human Solution:
Cute Marcia was in orange and made seven sleds.
Sue was in blue and made nine spinning tops.
Jane was in red and made five balls.
Spry Johnny was in green and made three racing cars.
Cher was in yellow and made six trains.
Response:
We look for 5 different positive integers (>2) that sum to 30, belong to 5 elves, and satisfy all the numerical clues.

1.  “Cher made one more than the elf in red, and one less than the elf who made the sleds.”  
   ⇒ three consecutive numbers n , n+1 , n+2   
      red-elf = n  Cher = n+1  sled-elf = n+2.

2.  “The green elf made one-third as many as Sue.”  
   ⇒ a pair g , 3g (g = green-elf, 3g = Sue).

3.  “Jane made 5 toys.”  So 5 is one of the five numbers.

Listing all sets of 5 distinct numbers > 2 whose sum is 30 gives  
{3,4,5,6,12}, {3,4,5,7,11}, {3,4,5,8,10}, {3,4,6,7,10}, {3,4,6,8,9}, {3,5,6,7,9}, {4,5,6,7,8}.

Only two of these contain a 1:3 pair:
• {3,4,5,6,12} (4 & 12)  
• {3,5,6,7,9}  (3 & 9)

The first set fails because it forces Cher and Jane to share the same number.  
The second set {3,5,6,7,9} works perfectly:

   numbers  3  5  6  7  9  
   roles   green red Cher sled Sue (=tops, biggest)

Now assign names, colours and toys:

• Green elf (3) must be Johnny (he builds the racing cars).  
• Red elf (5) is Jane (she has 5) and her remaining unassigned toy is balls.  
• Cher (6) therefore builds the trains; the clue makes her the yellow-suited elf.  
• The sled-maker (7) is Marcia, who must be dressed in orange.  
• The remaining colour, blue, goes to Sue (9), who makes the spinning tops.

Everything now satisfies every clue:

Johnny – 3 toys – green – racing cars  
Jane   – 5 toys – red   – balls  
Cher   – 6 toys – yellow – trains  
Marcia – 7 toys – orange – sleds  
Sue    – 9 toys – blue   – spinning tops

Final answer:  
Johnny (green) made 3 racing cars; Jane (red) made 5 balls; Cher (yellow) made 6 trains; Marcia (orange) made 7 sleds; Sue (blue) made 9 spinning tops.

Question:
You are back on the same game show with four other contestants. You didn't realise last time that the winner gets another appearance on the show! You now have another chance to win half a million dollars and become a millionaire! The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues. The first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response:
We translate the eight clues one by one, keeping the hint “??-??-66-??” in mind.

1.  Third set is 66 (from the hint).
2.  The first digit of the third set is 6.  
    Clue 1: 6 + (second digit of 2nd set) < 8 ⇒ second digit of 2nd set = 1.

Thus the second set is of the form 𝑥1.

3.  Clue 4: (second set) × 4 = (fourth set) reversed.  
   Candidates for the second set (no 0, ≤ 90): 11, 21, 31, 41, 61, 81, 91.
   • 11 × 4 = 44  → fourth set 44 (no 8 → violates clue 8)  
   • 21 × 4 = 84  → fourth set 48  (contains the single required 8) ✔  
   • 31 × 4 = 124 (three digits) ✖  
   • 41 × 4 = 164 (three digits) ✖  
   • 61 × 4 = 244 (three digits) ✖  
   • 81, 91 forbidden (contain 8 or > 90).

So the second set is 21 and the fourth set is 48.

4.  Digits now used: 2,1,6,6,4,8.  
    Clue 2 says the only digits not used anywhere are 5 and 7, so we still need 3 and 9.

5.  Determine the first set from clues 3 and 6.  
    • Product of its digits: 20 < product < 30.  
      Possible digit pairs (1–9, no 5 or 7, may repeat): (4,6)=24 or (3,9)=27.  
    • Sum of its digits ≠ 10.  
    • Set itself must be ≤ 90 (clue 5).

    If we choose 46: sum 10 (violates clue 3) and digits 3 or 9 would still be missing.  
    Therefore choose 39.  39 ≤ 90, 3 + 9 = 12 ≠ 10, and 3·9 = 27 (between 20 and 30).  
    Now every digit except 5 and 7 is represented.

6.  Verify all clues:
    – 39-21-66-48 uses only digits 1,2,3,4,6,8,9 (no 5 or 7).  
    – 6 + 1 = 7 (< 8).  
    – Only one 8, in the last set.  
    – 3 + 9 ≠ 10.  
    – 39 ≤ 90, 21 ≤ 90, 66 ≤ 90, 48 ≤ 90.  
    – 3×9 = 27 (between 20 and 30).  
    – 21 × 4 = 84, and 48 reversed is 84.  
All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Restate the problem in “yes / no” (black / white) language  
   • Give every hat a value: 0 = black, 1 = white.  
   • Each prisoner can see all the values except his own.  
   • After seeing them, he must announce a 0 or a 1 (his guess for his own hat).  
   • They win if either      (a) every announced value equals the real value, or  
                               (b) every announced value is the opposite of the real value.  
     (So being all right or being all wrong is equally good.)

2.  Why the hint points to parity (even / odd)  
    With two people the only global fact both can compute from what they see is  
    “are the two hats equal or different?”.  
    With three (or more) people the strongest common fact everybody can compute is  
    “is the total number of white hats I see even or odd?”.  
    The crucial observation:  
       What a white-hatted prisoner sees and what a black-hatted prisoner sees  
       differ in parity by exactly one.

3.  The strategy the prisoners adopt during their pre-game meeting  
    • Each prisoner silently counts how many white hats he sees.  
    • If he sees an even number he will say “black”.  
      If he sees an odd number he will say “white”.  
      (They can of course agree on the opposite convention; it doesn’t matter.)

4.  Why this works – the formal proof  
    Let H₁, H₂, … , Hₙ be the real hat colours (0 = black, 1 = white).  
    Let P = H₁ + H₂ + … + Hₙ (mod 2) be the parity of the total number of white hats.  

    What prisoner k can see is  
            Sₖ = H₁ + … + Hₖ₋₁ + Hₖ₊₁ + … + Hₙ   (mod 2)  
          = P − Hₖ (mod 2).  

    His announced guess Gₖ is  
            Gₖ = 0  if Sₖ is even        →  Gₖ = Sₖ  
                 1  if Sₖ is odd         →  Gₖ = Sₖ  

          So  Gₖ = Sₖ = P − Hₖ   (mod 2)  
          ⇒  Gₖ = Hₖ  when P = 0 (total number of whites even)  
          ⇒  Gₖ = 1 − Hₖ when P = 1 (total number of whites odd).

    Therefore  
        • If P = 0, every Gₖ equals Hₖ  → everybody is right.  
        • If P = 1, every Gₖ equals 1 − Hₖ → everybody is wrong.  

    In either case the whole group satisfies the warden’s release condition.

5.  Why the warden cannot foil them  
    Whatever assignment of hats the warden chooses fixes the parity P.  
    Their rule automatically puts them in the “all right” state when P = 0  
    and in the “all wrong” state when P = 1.  
    The warden has no third option, so he cannot prevent their escape.

6.  Example with five prisoners  
    Actual hats: 1 0 0 1 1  (three whites → P = 1, odd).  
    Everybody counts whites he sees:  
        Prisoner 1 sees 0,0,1,1 → two whites → even → says 0 (black)  
        Prisoner 2 sees 1,0,1,1 → three whites → odd  → says 1 (white)  
        Prisoner 3 sees 1,0,1,1 → three whites → odd  → says 1 (white)  
        Prisoner 4 sees 1,0,0,1 → two whites  → even → says 0 (black)  
        Prisoner 5 sees 1,0,0,1 → two whites  → even → says 0 (black)  
    Announcements: 0 1 1 0 0, i.e. the exact opposite of 1 0 0 1 1 – they are all wrong, hence they go free.

Final answer:  
All agree in advance that each prisoner will count the number of white hats he sees.  
If he sees an even number he will announce “black”; if he sees an odd number he will announce “white” (or the opposite convention).  
Then, when the hats are placed, either the total number of white hats is even—in which case every prisoner’s announcement matches his real hat—or it is odd—in which case every announcement is the opposite of his real hat.  Thus the whole group is either entirely right or entirely wrong, guaranteeing their escape.

Question:
Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Let  

      SD = The Silver Dream  
      GP = The Golden Pleasure  
      DL = The Devine Lightning  
      RB = The Rusting Bucket  

and let  

      D = Derek, B = Berrick, M = Merick, E = Eric.  

Rewrite every statement of the form  
      “X will not get car C unless …”  
as the implication  

      If X gets C, then the stated conditions hold.  

1.  D=GP  ⇒  (B=SD  and  E=RB)  
2.  B=RB  ⇒  (M=DL and D=SD)  
3.  E=DL  ⇒  (D=GP and B=SD)  
4.  D=SD  ⇒  (M=DL and E=RB)  
5.  B=SD  ⇒  (D=DL and E=RB)  
6.  D=DL  ⇒  (B=GP and M=SD)  
7.  M=DL ⇒  (B=GP and D=RB)  
8.  D=RB ⇒  (B=DL and E=GP)  
9.  M=SD ⇒  E=GP  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – Use the hint (rule 9).  
Assume Eric gets GP.  
Then by rule 9, M must get SD:  

          E = GP, M = SD.

Cars left for D and B are DL and RB.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2 – Decide what Derek can receive.  

• Suppose D = DL.  
  Rule 6 would force B = GP, but GP is already Eric’s.  
  Hence D cannot be DL.

Therefore D must take the remaining car RB:

          D = RB.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3 – Decide what Berrick receives.  
Only DL is still unassigned, so  

          B = DL.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4 – Check every rule with  
          (D,RB) (B,DL) (M,SD) (E,GP).

Rule 1: D≠GP  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 2: B≠RB  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 3: E≠DL  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 4: D≠SD  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 5: B≠SD  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 6: D≠DL  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 7: M≠DL  (satisfied vacuously)  
Rule 8: D=RB ⇒ B=DL and E=GP (both true)  
Rule 9: M=SD ⇒ E=GP (true)

All nine statements are satisfied.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 5 – Show no other assignment is possible.  
If Eric did not get GP, then by rule 9 Merick could not have SD.  
A complete case-by-case check of E=SD, E=DL, and E=RB shows each leads
to a violation of at least one rule (details omitted here but carried
out systematically), so E must be GP.  
With E=GP the reasoning above is forced, giving the unique solution.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer:  
Derek gets The Rusting Bucket,  
Berrick gets The Devine Lightning,  
Merick gets The Silver Dream,  
Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.

Question:
Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Think of the thirty places in the bus-circle as being numbered 1,2,3,…,30 clockwise, with the driver standing at place 1 when he starts to count.  
Exactly the same thing as the driver’s procedure is the classical Josephus problem “(30,9)” – with 30 people in a circle and every 9-th one removed.

1.  Simulate the counting.

   Start at place 1, count 9 people (1,2,…,9); the 9-th (place 9) is put off the bus.  
   Begin again with the next person and keep eliminating every 9-th one:

   1. 9
   2. 18
   3. 27
   4. 6
   5. 16
   6. 26
   7. 7
   8. 19
   9. 30
   10. 12
   11. 24
   12. 8
   13. 22
   14. 5
   15. 23

   After exactly fifteen removals the driver stops, leaving fifteen people on the bus.

2.  Read off the numbers that are still on the circle.

   The surviving places are

   {1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29}.

3.  Seat the supporters.

   Put yourself and the other 14 supporters of your team on precisely those fifteen places; put the rival supporters on the other fifteen places.  For instance:

   1 – your team (you)  
   2 – your team  
   3 – your team  
   4 – your team
